PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators in the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatization and de-regulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.
Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatization, de-regulation, timed local calls, and directory assistance charging.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance. That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments. That we express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances for the purpose of food irradiation and disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
That the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
That the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honorable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Schools: South Belconnen Region, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Canberra respectfully shows:

The ACT Schools Authority has acted in an unfair and improper manner in rejecting, without notice or justification, the Planning Criteria of its Draft Plan ``Community Schools for Canberra 1989-2000'', in which context it had invited communities to respond, and in reaching decisions that conflict completely with those criteria.

The ACT Schools Authority, by acting in this way, has set a precedent for arbitrary school reorganization throughout the whole of Canberra, in which schools can be closed at any time without prior notice or consultation, and without effective justification.

The Page Community has been denied natural justice by the decision to close its neighbourhood school, because that decision was made without warning, without consultation, and without right of appeal.
The Page Community is the only one in Canberra that has been given no opportunity to respond to a specific draft proposal for closure of its school.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Senate note our strong and united protest at the ACT Schools Authority's decision to close Page Primary School.

Noting that, the ACT Schools Authority identified only two options for school reorganization in the South Belconnen area, and that it has chosen to implement neither, and that the people of the ACT are shortly to be given the possibility of self government; the Senate resolve that no South Belconnen schools be closed until the ACT Schools Authority has:
(a) developed a complete and integrated plan for the educational needs of the South Belconnen area;
(b) developed and publicized educational and social criteria for maintaining, relocating, reorganizing or closing schools;
(c) assessed all schools against these criteria;
(d) presented these results for public review, with a full range of options; and
(e) allowed reasonable time for community consultation prior to decisions being taken and implemented.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-1986 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First World Zone of Peace in Tibet
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that it is 37 years since the Chinese military occupation of Tibet, during which time the Chinese government has acted with little regard for Tibetans' human rights or national sovereignty, has involved the Tibetan people and their region in the production of nuclear weapons and is currently planning a programme to dump nuclear waste in Tibet, none of which-as indicated by recent civil unrest in the region-is in keeping with the wishes of the Tibetan people.

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, urge the Australian Government to undertake all steps within its power in support of the First World Zone Of Peace in Tibet, as proposed by His Holiness the Dalai Lama of Tibet.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my notice of intention given yesterday, I now withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 2 relating to Meat Inspection (Victoria) Orders.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that immediately after Question Time I shall withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for this day for disallowance of the public rental housing assistance program. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The public rental housing program is one of a number of very important quasi-legislative instruments recently made to regulate the administration of public housing in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee raised with the Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, MP, a number of questions concerning the scope of Administrative Appeals Tribunal review rights, the protection of personal privacy and the powers of the Commissioner for Housing to act in the the public interest. The Minister has given the Committee undertakings to extend appeal rights; to better protect personal privacy and reduce the discretion of the Commissioner to release certain private information to a more specific level. In three matters the Minister was reluctant to confer particular review rights where he thought that this would be inappropriate. The Committee has asked that these particular matters be the subject of a reassessment by the Committee and the Minister in 12 months time to determine whether there is a need for avenues of redress to remedy any particular types of grievance that may tend to arise. The programs which the Committee scrutinised are significant and the Minister's letter is an important statement of his attitude on them. I therefore seek leave to incorporate the Minister's letter in Hansard for the information of honourable senators and others.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations & Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins
I refer to your letter of 21 April 1988 in which you raise a number of issues in relation to various programs Gazetted under the Housing Assistance Ordinance 1987.

I appreciate the detail with which you have outlined the Committee's concerns and your examples of how some matters of a similar nature have been dealt with in the past. Because of the number of matters raised, I think it best if I deal with each in turn.
PUBLIC RENTAL HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM: REVIEW RIGHTS

You have encouraged me to consider an appropriate amendment to give AAT appeal rights in regard to three matters. I understand from your letter that you are concerned that persons subject to these decisions are not given a right of appeal to the AAT.

In regard to the first, the power to move refugees from temporary accommodation, I have been informed by the Commissioner for Housing that this power has a very specific function in moving refugees from emergency, short term accommodation, into the regular public housing scheme. A notional number of properties are kept free for refugees (see clause 12 (3)). When this temporary housing is provided, refugees must be eligible and are therefore required to make application for public rental housing in the normal way (see clause 12 (2)). This involves being placed on a waiting list. When accommodation becomes available in the usual way, subclause 12 (4) enables the transfer of the refugee applicant to another property if appropriate. In every case, the person's needs and preferences are discussed with the person and every effort is made, within the guidelines, to meet any request.

From the above, it may be seen that the practical use of the power is unlikely to cause grievance. Indeed, its effect is even less likely to have a serious impact upon a person's business, reputation or livelihood.

Nevertheless, I am mindful of the Committee's concern that welfare recipients be given appeal rights in a manner which is clearly apparent to them. I have therefore directed the Commissioner for Housing to prepare a variation of the program to make a decision under paragraph 12 (4) (b) subject to the appeal rights in clause 21.

I turn now to the Commissioner's discretion to transfer a tenant. I am informed that there are a variety of circumstances under which the power in paragraph 19 (1) (b) to transfer a tenant is required. It may be necessary where the Commissioner has decided to dispose of a property or to redevelop the site, where the site has become uninhabitable because of fire or burst water mains or other service problems, or when the Commissioner becomes aware of changed circumstances in the household such as marital breakdown. It may also be used, as a last resort, to remove a person or persons who have been a source of tension and disturbance in the neighbourhood.

I have decided to direct that the Program be varied so that every exercise of this power except a decision to dispose of or redevelop a property may be reviewed by the AAT. Relevant criteria will be set out in the Program.

A decision of the Commissioner to sell or redevelop a property is a different but complementary aspect of the Commissioner's role in providing housing assistance generally in the ACT (see principle 2 (b) of Schedule 1 to the Ordinance). I consider that as a manager of Commonwealth assets the Commissioner should be free to take full advantage of a commercial opportunity or to make a decision on the upgrading or alteration of any particular site. Of course, such a decision would be subject to compliance with the general law concerning planning and building standards.

I do not say that tenants should have no rights of appeal in these circumstances. On the contrary, I propose that persons thus affected should have rights of appeal to the AAT in relation to the standard and location of the housing to which it is proposed they be transferred.

The third case you mention is subclause 21 (3) which provides that the Commissioner may of his or her own motion reconsider and affirm, vary or revoke a previous decision on an application. This provision enables the Commissioner to review previous decisions in the light of further information. I agree that the provision should be amended to provide for review rights where the Commissioner revokes or varies an earlier decision in a way which has unfavourable consequences for a person.

Nevertheless, I do not think that an appeal should lie from a decision under clause 21 (3) affirming an earlier decision or a decision that no ``sufficient reason exists for reassessing a decision'' (note the distinction between these two types of decisions in Bannister v See (1982) 45 ALR 146). There are two reasons for this. First, the original unfavourable decision could have been appealed under clause 21. To allow a subsequent appeal is really to extend the time for appealing indefinitely. Secondly, if new circumstances have arisen a fresh appealable application may be lodged at any time: I have asked the Commissioner to ensure that pamphlets on appeal rights explain this.
The restriction of review rights to only those decisions to vary or revoke a previous favourable decision has legislative precedent: see Veteran's Entitlement Act 1986 s. 31 (11).
Uncertainty of Laws

You have expressed concerns about the potential inconsistency between clauses 16 and 17 of the Program and 15 (1) of the Ordinance. Subclause 16 (1) is transitional. Rent reviews are due to be completed shortly on all dwellings thus exhausting any remaining effects of the provision. Subclauses 16 (2) and 17 (1) which empower the Commissioner to determine the amount of rent payable must of course be read as being subject to the provision of the Ordinance. To make this abundantly clear, I have asked that the Program be amended accordingly.

As a matter of interest, I am advised that rents were at the time of the commencement of the Ordinance higher than any figure arrived at from the application of Schedule 2 criteria. No inconsistency with the requirements of Schedule 2 therefore has arisen in practice.
Public Interest
In relation to clause 23 you raise questions about:
(i) the sanction intended for disclosure by Public Servants of private information obtained in relation to the program;
(ii) the nature of the information which may be divulged under paragraphs 23 (3) (b) and 23 (3) (c); and
(iii) the use of ``the public interest'', as certified by a statutory official, as the criteria for disclosure of information under paragraph 23 (3) (a).
It is intended that unauthorised breaches of privacy be dealt with under the provision of the Crimes Act 1914 which you mention.
With respect to paragraphs 23 (3) (b) and 23 (3) (c), I agree that these provisions require clarification.
I have noted your comments regarding the certification of ``public interest'' by the Commissioner for Housing. I also agree that this procedure is not suitable in this context.

I am prepared to vary the Program by removing clause 23 and replacing it with a clause which specifically identifies the organisations to which information may be given, the type of information which may be released, and the circumstances in which such release may occur. There would then be no ``public interest'' provision.

I assure the Committee that I am no less concerned than they regarding the proper protection of confidential personal information. I do, however, believe that there is a legitimate and proper use of such information in the prevention or detection of criminal activity. I note in this regard the reported comments of Mr Ian Temby QC, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, who said ``it was absurd that fraud against the Commonwealth could be made easier by secrecy provisions and an enforced lack of communication between agencies'' [Canberra Times Tuesday 3 May 1988 at page 1].

I would expect the variation to the program to provide in similar terms to the recommendations of the government's fraud review; that is that the information to be released should relate to law enforcement and be connected with the investigation and prosecution of an alleged offence. In this respect it is my opinion that the categories of `prescribed authorities' (see clause 3 of the Program) should be widened to include the National Crime Authority and the Director of Public Prosecutions. In addition, I believe that the current absolute prohibition on production of this material in Court proceedings is inappropriate and I propose to amend that provision also.

Of course, information relating to a person's own affairs would remain available to that person or their agent under the Freedom of Information Act or to their agent or attorney when so authorised. I would also expect the aggregated statistical information would not breach the secrecy provision.
I have directed the Commissioner for Housing to act, subject to the Ordinance, in accordance with these principles in the period prior to such a variation being made.
Drafting
I recognise the force of the Committee's remarks on this point and have asked the ACT Administration to note the Committee's comments.
DEFENCE FORCE RENTAL HOUSING
ASSISTANCE PROGRAM

Your question concerning the Commission's power to deal with Defence Force housing perhaps arises because of the naming of the program. A slightly more accurate but somewhat cumbersome title for the program would be: Public Rental Housing (Defence Force) Program and similarly the Public Rental Housing Assistance Program could alternatively be titled: Public Rental Housing (General Assistance) Program. These alternative titles emphasise that the programs relate to the stock of public rental housing owned or administered by the Commissioner. The Defence Force Rental Housing Assistance Program is thus authorised under paragraph 8 (1) (a) of the Housing Assistance Ordinance as being a program in relation to public rental housing.

The reference in paragraph 8 (1) (a) to ``public rental housing'' (emphasis added) is a reference to the stock of houses under the Commissioner's ownership and control rather than a reference to rental housing for the public at large. This is apparent from a comparison with paragraph 8 (1) (c) which, among other things, refers to programs from income-related assistance to tenants. Such a reference would be unnecessary if paragraph 8 (1) (a) had the latter meaning. The phrase `public rental housing' and similar related phrases are also used extensively in Schedule 1 of the Ordinance (see eg. Principle 2 (b)) where it is clearly used to refer to government-owned, as opposed to privately-owned, housing.

I should add that this program is a continuation of a program which has been operating administratively since the early 1970s. Under those arrangements and now by authorisation of the program, an agreed number (not specific dwellings) of public rental dwellings are made available and divided between the three Defence Services.

With regard to your question about clause 5; I note that allocation of housing requires the assessment of the competing needs of other persons. An appeal on the merits, given that there is a limited stock of public housing, would require a consideration of the merits of other applications before the Commissioner rather than solely the merits of the particular applicant. On that basis therefore, it is arguable that a decision by the Commissioner to allocate a person to a particular house within the public housing stock should not be the subject of merits review: it would be necessary to allow the other applicants who were considered to cross appeal.
If, however, the Committee insists that decisions regarding allocation of housing should be subject to external review, I am prepared to amend the Program.

Having raised these concerns, I note that arguably the present Public Rental Housing Program provides for AAT review of decisions as to allocation of housing (see clause 8) as well as eligibility for assistance (see clause 4) on the basis that the allocation decision is made on the application (see clause 21). Whatever the position, I agree that there should be consistency between programs on this point.
Clause 8 is in identical terms of clause 19 of the Public Rental Housing Assistance Program. I propose to amend it in the same manner.
COMMUNITY ORGANISATIONS RENTAL
HOUSING ASSISTANCE PROGRAM

For the purposes of the program, it is the Commissioner who makes decisions under it. In practice, applications by Community Organisations are assessed by a committee of persons comprising relevant officers of the ACT Housing Trust and officers of the welfare area of the ACT Administration. This Committee brings a recommendation to the Commissioner.

It is true that clause 4 has discretionary elements and decisions under subclause 5 (3) could have some effect on an organisation's priority in obtaining an allocation. However, the discretions are not so much directed towards the needs of the applicant but to a judgement as to the overall benefit to the community; in other words, to policy considerations.

The Commissioner must not only be satisfied that the organisation is constituted in such a manner that the intended public benefit is properly secured, but also that the benefit is one which meets an unfilled need in the ACT in a manner which is consistent with the Commissioner's obligations under Schedule 1 of the Ordinance. This includes the Commissioner's obligation to give priority for those in greatest need, to co-ordinate programs and to maximise the social benefit of all assistance provided to the community. I do not believe that such an assessment involving as it does these policy issues, is appropriate for review by the AAT.

I recognise that there may be differences of opinion in regard to the above. If the Committee is unable to agree with the conclusion I have reached and considers that the matter is sufficiently clear to warrant it, I am prepared to direct that a variation be made to the Program to provide appeals to the AAT under this clause.

Regarding decisions under subclause 5 (3), I am advised that the properties made available are those which most nearly meet the requirements of the organisation. They are taken from the normal public rental stock as and when the property becomes available. It is unfair to prospective tenants and detrimental to the revenue of the ACT Housing Trust to hold the property available for longer than 14 days. Should an organisation seek to accept an offer of a property after this time and it has been allocated to a family who has been advised of its availability, it would be improper to alter that decision. Should such a situation occur, the organisation should be made to wait until another property becomes available.
It would be open to the organisation in such a case to make a further application.
LONG STAY CARAVAN PARK HOUSING
ASSISTANCE PROGRAM

I have previously mentioned my reservations about the suitability of AAT review for decisions to allocate a particular site from a limited stock to a particular person. However, if the Committee insists, I will arrange for the variation of the Program to provide AAT review rights in relation to these decisions.
I trust that this information is of assistance to the Committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PROVISIONS OF INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon the provisions of the Industrial Relations Bill 1988 concerning the registration and amalgamation of organisations.
(2) That, in considering the provisions of the Bill, the Committee give particular consideration to:
(a) the desirability or otherwise of the restrictions on registration of organisations contained in the Bill; and
(b) whether the provisions on registration and amalgamation contained in the Bill will produce a union structure that reduces demarcation disputes and is conducive to improved industrial relations.
(3) That the Committee report to the Senate on the first sitting day in August 1988.

(4) (a) That the Committee consist of six Senators, three being Government Senators, and three being Senators who are not Government Senators nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.

(b) That the nominations of the Opposition or any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators be determined by agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question as to the representation on the Committee be determined by the Senate.
(5) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(6) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(7) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(8) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(9) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(10) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(11) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(12) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(13) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

Bill read a second time.
Supply Bills

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first Bill for debate in the committee stage is the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89. Of course we shall have similar comments to make in respect of its companion Supply Bills, the Supply Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and the Supply Bill (No. 2) 1988-89. After this Bill and indeed its accompanying Supply Bills were introduced in the House of Representatives, the Government moved in that House to amend the schedule for the Bill, on page 4, division 102, by adding to the previously existing paragraph (b) subparagraph (i) the words:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) Was erroneously omitted from, or understated in, the Bill for this Act;

The effect of this amendment in the House of Representatives was to widen significantly the category of expenditures which can be met from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. As honourable senators are aware the purpose of the Advance to the Minister for Finance item in each of the Supply Bills, and indeed corresponding items in the annual Appropriation Bills, is to act as a contingency provision from which what we have always referred to as urgent and unforseen expenditures can be met. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is therefore an item which is of considerable constitutional significance. The Parliament has developed extensive procedures to ensure that public moneys are not expended in the absence of specific appropriations for them having been approved in advance by the Parliament, whether by way of annual appropriations in the shape of the Appropriation Bills, which we finished dealing with last night, or special appropriations contained in the relevant appropriation clauses of the various statutes concerned which have the effect of appropriating under those statutes moneys from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the purposes of the statute question.
Supply Bills

The significance of the Advance to the Minister for Finance is that it provides the Minister with authority to make certain expenditures other than in accordance with those carefully laid down procedures. It does so because all governments from time to time have genuinely urgent and unforeseen claims on their Budgets which it is necessary to meet before those claims can be covered by a specific appropriation item. Nevertheless, because the use of this item departs from the normal practice, the Parliament has developed strict procedures to ensure that the Advance is administered and used correctly.

Accordingly, the Opposition has looked very closely at the amendment, moved by the Government in the House of Representatives after the Supply Bills had been introduced, to the traditional wording of this item and has inquired into the reasons for the proposed change. I may say that our investigations might have been facilitated had the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) taken the Opposition into his confidence in proposing this amendment in the first place. Particularly for that reason, I think it is important to put into the record of the Senate the chain of events which has led to this outcome. It has, I suggest, a number of rather unsatisfactory features but it is all the more important, for that reason, that it be recorded.

The first link in the chain appears to have been report No. 289 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the Advance to the Minister for Finance. In the course of its examination of that appropriation item, the Committee became aware of certain guidelines issued to departments by the Department of Finance governing departments' use of the Advance. In particular, the Committee became aware that, in interpreting the basic criterion that to be eligible for such financing the expenditures in question must be `urgently required and unforeseen', the Department of Finance had included the guideline that expenditure may be regarded as unforeseen:

(iii) where, due to clerical error, or inadvertence, no amount or an insufficient amount has been provided in an Appropriation Bill, for particular expenditure, and funds are required to pay accounts from creditors.

The Joint Committee sought from the Attorney-General's Department a legal opinion about that guideline and some other matters. That legal opinion is included, as appendix 4, in the report of the Joint Committee. In brief, as recorded on page 38 of the Committee's report, the legal opinion in respect of this particular matter, provided by Mr P. J. Clay for the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, reads as follows:
Where, due to clerical error or inadvertence only, an amount for an expenditure has been omitted to be included in an Appropriation Bill, or an incorrect (and insufficient) amount has been included,
I-
that is, Mr Clay-
do not think the expenditure can be regarded as having been unforeseen.
Mr Clay went on to say:
The wording of the Advance should, in my view, be amended if it is intended to apply in such cases.

Some might think that a single opinion from an officer of the Attorney-General's Department hardly settles a matter of such moment as this. It is clearly a matter of interpretation or opinion. Indeed, the very fact that the alternative practice has been in existence for a number of years confirms that view. I think one could, without undue difficulty, argue a cogent case to the contrary of that which has been argued in this case by the Attorney-General's Department. Be my opinion on that matter as it may, it is interesting that the Joint Committee itself was apparently also not persuaded by the view of the Attorney-General's Department in this matter, because at paragraph 2.29 of its report it said:
Although the Attorney-General's Department suggested amending the wording of the Advance if it is intended that clerical inadvertence be regarded as unforeseen, the Committee is not-
I repeat, not-
in favour of widening the use of-
the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The Committee went on to say, in the following paragraph, 2.30:
The Committee considers that amendment of the guidelines-
that is, the Department of Finance guidelines-
and stricter documentation requirements will reinforce that expenditure from the Advance must be for both `urgent' and `unforeseen' circumstances as specified by the Parliament.
At the same time the Joint Committee of Public Accounts took the view, in paragraph 2.17 of its report, that:
To facilitate early Parliamentary review more information should be included in the monthly statement of moneys made available from the AMF-
which, as honourable senators are aware, is tabled in this place each month. Accordingly, pursuant to that view, the Committee went on to recommend in paragraph 2.18 of its report:
The Committee recommends that:

the monthly statement from the Department of Finance to the Parliament have appended applications made on the standard forms for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance so that the Parliament can see clearly for what purpose advances are applied.

That is, of course, a move by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, one of the most highly respected committees of the Parliament, to render transactions financed from this unusual contingency item in the Appropriations, or in this case the Supply Bills, transparent-to use a word from another jurisdiction.

The Committee reported accordingly on 23 March of this year, and so far, one might say, so good. In due course, on 20 April this year to be precise, the Supply Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives, and the item Advance to the Minister for Finance, which was included in those Bills as originally introduced, was in the same form as had been customary, I think since 1981 or thereabouts. But on 26 April 1988 the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, wrote to the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Mr Tickner, MHR, to inform him that the Government proposed to amend the three Supply Bills in the committee stage of the Bills in the House of Representatives in the light of, as he put it, the report of the Committee. The Minister said in his letter:

We consider the amendments necessary in the light of legal advice regarding the definition of the `urgent' and `unforeseen' criteria which are required to be met before an issue may be made from the Advances to the Minister for Finance, the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
He went on to say, after referring to the Committee's report which I have just quoted from:
You-
that is, Mr Tickner-

state in that Report that the purpose of the contingency Advances is to allow for the smooth running of a Government by providing it with some flexibility. We consider that not to have access to funds because of inadvertence or clerical error would disrupt financial administration, is contrary to the intended purpose of the Advances and would certainly add to the burden of Parliamentary business.
Somewhat gratuitously, perhaps, the Minister went on to say:

We have made the assumption that the Parliamentary Departments would not wish to be so hampered in their financial administration and have proposed the same amendment to the Advances in the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89.

It is not clear from the Minister's letter whether he consulted either the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives before going about their business for them in that way. Perhaps it would be convenient if I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full text of the Minister's letter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Mr R. E. Tickner, MP
Chairman
Joint Committee of Public Accounts
Parliament House
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Tickner

Attached for your information is a copy of proposed amendments to the Supply Bills (Nos 1 and 2) 1988-89 and the Supply (Parliamentary) Departments Bill 1988-89 which my Government proposes to be moved in the Committee stages of the Bills, expected to be Wednesday or Thursday of this week. The Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on Wednesday 20 April.

We consider the amendments necessary in the light of legal advice regarding the definition of the ``urgent'' and ``unforeseen'' criteria which are required to be met before an issue may be made from the Advances to the Minister for Finance, the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives. The opinion was obtained by your Committee and is reproduced at Appendix 4 of Report 289 on the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

You state in that Report that the purpose of the contingency Advances is to allow for the smooth running of a Government by providing it with some flexibility. We consider that not to have access to funds because of inadvertence or clerical error would disrupt financial administration, is contrary to the intended purpose of the Advances and would certainly add to the burden of Parliamentary business. The only alternative to an amendment to the wording of the present clauses in Appropriation Acts would be the introduction, for urgent passage, of additional Appropriations Bills to meet individual cases where a Government is inextric- ably committed to meet payments.

We have made the assumption that the Parliamentary Departments would not wish to be so hampered in their financial administration and have proposed the same amendment to the Advances in the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89.

I would be happy to make officers of my Department available to explain in more detail the type of administrative difficulties which would be encountered should the amendments not be included in all future Appropriation and Supply Bills.
Yours sincerely
PETER WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. On the following day, 27 April, the Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts replied to the Minister for Finance. He did so after convening a special meeting of his Committee to consider the Minister's letter. The key passage in Mr Tickner's letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: It is acknowledged by the Committee that there are circumstances where inadvertence or clerical error occurs where it is appropriate that the Advance should be used.
He was, therefore, accepting the Minister's proposal. He continued:
It is in this light therefore that the Committee supports the proposed amendments, however-
this is the key point-
This support is conditional upon the second recommendation of the Committee being accepted.
That is the one to which I referred earlier. He continued:
This recommendation states:

The monthly statement from the Department of Finance to the Parliament have appended applications made on the standard forms for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance so that the Parliament can see clearly for what purposes advances are applied . . .

Apparently the Minister did not accept that condition laid down by the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Therefore, the Opposition proposes to correct this oversight by moving to amend the relevant items of the three Supply Bills before us in each case in terms of the amendments which the Opposition has had cause to be circulated in this chamber. I seek leave to move three amendments together to the Supply (Parliamentary Department) Bill.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Schedule, page 4, Division 102, paragraph (b) of the statement of purpose set out in the Division, after ``Parliament'' insert: ``in respect of each month as soon as practicable after the end of the month, in a document including a copy of each application, made in accordance with guidelines and a form of application determined by the President, for the expenditure of funds from this advance, and a copy of those guidelines''.

(2) The Schedule, page 4, Division 104, paragraph (b) of the statement of purpose set out in the Division, after ``Parliament'' insert: ``in respect of each month as soon as practicable after the end of the month, in a document including a copy of each application, made in accordance with guidelines and a form of application determined by the Speaker, for the expenditure of funds from this advance, and a copy of those guidelines''.

(3) The Schedule, page 5, Division 108, paragraph (b) of the Statement of purpose set out in the Division, after ``Parliament'' insert: ``in respect of each month as soon as practicable after the end of the month, in a document including a copy of each application, made in accordance with guidelines and a form of application determined by the President and the Speaker, for the expenditure of funds from this advance, and a copy of those guidelines''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone has moved three amendments which are identical in wording; certainly, they are identical in their effect. The subclause was added to the Supply Bill by way of amendment in the House of Representatives, as Senator Stone has said, and for the reasons he has given. That is, an Attorney-General's Department opinion had been received that the urgent and unforeseen provisions did not cover items which had been erroneously omitted. Some people question whether that opinion from Attorney-General's was in fact sound, but the Government made the judgment that it was too important to run the risk of letting it be tested at some later stage and, therefore, included in the Bill, by way of amendment, the addition to state explicitly that items erroneously omitted from or understated in a Supply or Appropriation Bill at the appropriate time would be explicitly covered by the Advanced to the Minister for Finance (AMF).

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting for the record that the guidelines defining urgent and unforeseen, as approved by then Senator Guilfoyle in 1979, I think, explicitly recognised that they should cover errors of omission. The one item we know of now which was omitted from the Supply Bill, and indeed it is still not explicitly covered in it, was an advance of some $620,000 to the Australian Institute of Sport. There may well be other errors of omission which have not yet been discovered. Therefore, I go back to my original point: knowing that clerical error is always possible, that uncertainty prompted the Government to move the amendment it has moved.

Let me outline a few facts regarding the specific amendments which Senator Stone has moved. Firstly, for all individual items in excess of $50,000, on the first available sitting day following the end of the month, which is usually within one week of the end of the month, provided Parliament is sitting, a list of those individual items is tabled. The smaller amounts are set out in detail when the final charge from the Advance to the Minister for Finance is appropriated. The maximum time delay could be as much as five or six months.

The effect of Senator Stone's proposition is that all items, not just the individual items above $50 000, be tabled at the same time and in the same way as the items in excess of $50 000 are now tabled. There is nothing wrong with that in principle, but there are some practical difficulties in implementing it, both in regard to the amount of paperwork which would be floating around and the clerical work which lies behind it. I am informed that 381 copies of the monthly AMF report are produced for tabling and circulation. If the average of 50 or so individual AMF applications per month were added to the number which is already published, that would increase paper requirements by a factor of 10. In other words, 20,000-odd additional pieces of paper would be required to be published each month, as well as, of course, the clerical effort and cost which would lie behind circulating that volume of paper. Our view is that it is not justified, particularly when the details, albeit with a longer time lag, are ultimately available. Therefore, the Government will not accept the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) for his response. With respect, I do not believe that the major part of his response addressed the nature of the amendments which the Opposition is moving. The Minister described for the benefit of honourable senators the present procedures in relation to the monthly tabling of the statement in relation to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Of course, we are familiar with those procedures. He enumerated the fact that the monthly advice contains a list-I repeat the word `list'-of items greater than $50,000 where the Advance has been used. As he also added, the smaller items-that is, amounts of less than $50,000-are rounded up, so to speak, at the end of the year. The Minister went on to say that if the Parliament were to accept the Opposition's amendments there would be a great multiplication of paperwork. To be fair to the Minister, that is to some degree true. There would be some additional paperwork. I have no doubt that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts took that into consideration when it made the proposal to which the amendments are directed to give effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The key point which was omitted from the Minister's response is that what the Public Accounts Committee recommended, and what the amendments that are now before this Committee would have the effect of providing, is that the monthly statement would have appended to it the actual applications made on the standard forms by the various departments for funds from the Advance so that the Parliament-I quote from the Committee recommendations-`can see clearly for what purpose advances are applied'. I have not had any opportunity to discuss this matter with the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Mr Tickner. However, from my discussions with another member of that Committee, it is clear to me that what the Joint Committee of Public Accounts had in mind was that the present use of the Advance, including any inadvertently omitted purposes, has become rather too casual. There is perhaps an assumption that the Advance is there to be used and it should be used.

I have no doubt whatsoever that, as in many other areas, the belief in the minds of the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was that to expose those concerned who are involved in making those applications to some parliamentary scrutiny of what the actual applications are for-after all, it is proposed that they be made on standard forms-would provide some kind of disincentive to that rather cavalier approach to the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. It is entirely appropriate and it is exactly what the surveillance procedures of the Parliament are at their best in being used for. I would hope that the Minister would not continue to resist the proposal, because it is a proposal which would help him and his Department in their attempts to exercise greater discipline on the use by departments of this contingency item.

Everybody accepts that the contingency item, the Advance to the Minister for Finance, is there to be used in appropriate and proper circumstances. But what I think the Committee is perhaps pointing to-and what we certainly support it in pointing to-is that the approach to the use of that item may have grown a little sloppy. If people in the departmental structure became aware that their applications, in the form in which they are made to the Department of Finance, will actually be submitted and brought to the attention of senators, they will be somewhat more careful before making them. Perhaps also the Minister's own officers-not that I am in any way suggesting that they are negligent in granting access-will bring an even more rigorous eye to the granting of access. Through those incentives-disincentives in one case and incentives in the other-there will be a better and more proper use of the Advance than seems to be the case today.

I therefore put it to the Minister that the Opposition amendments are not only designed to support the Chairman and the whole Joint Committee of Public Accounts in what the members laid down as a condition to their agreement to the amendment that the Minister has made. We are not opposing the Government's amendment made in the House of Representatives; we are saying that the amendment which is now included in the Bill before us should be complemented by the other amendment which the Joint Committee proposed as a condition for its agreement to the first amendment. I hope that the Minister will give further consideration to the position he previously stated and indicate that the Government is prepared to accept that amendment supported unanimously by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, chaired by a member of his own Party-quite rightly so; the Government being as it is today. I hope that the Minister will not resist simply for the sake of resisting but will accept that there is a genuine public good involved in this amendment proposed by the Opposition and that he will bend his not inconsiderable mind to accepting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that Dame Margaret Guilfoyle approved the guidelines in 1979. She was not Finance Minister then. It was in fact in 1981. I want to correct that. The Department of Finance is, and has been for some time, examining ways of achieving the results that the Committee seeks without the cumbersome load of paper that would be required for doing it in precisely the way that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts suggested. But as yet the Department has not been able to devise some way of fulfilling the objective, if one likes, without entailing a great deal of paper and clerical effort. But we will keep it under examination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments. The listing of items above $50,000 has been around for some considerable time. I recall before entering this Parliament that one particular department indicated, `This will be right. It is below $50,000. Some arrangements can be made'. I feel that it would be a matter of common good and proper practice if the procedures which were recommended by the Public Accounts Committee were adopted and if Senator Stone's amendments were adopted. If the chamber passes these amendments it will assist, in my view, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) to keep a tighter control on considerable amounts of money. Individual amounts below $50,000 are not considerable but in total the amounts are quite considerable.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that one of the reasons advanced for the automation of the Public Service, with all its computers and so forth, was to get rid of a lot of the paperwork. I cannot see how there would be a considerable amount of paperwork. Why would all these people need copies of the material? Why is the material simply not in a computer where eligible people can have access to it? Two copies of the material could be sent to the Parliament: one to the House of Representatives and one to the Senate to be tabled. I am not sure-and perhaps Senator Stone could enlighten me-whether the Public Accounts Committee actually recommended that the material be tabled in the Parliament or be delivered to each member of parliament. I would have thought that tabling in the Parliament would suffice. It seems to me that the only reason, other than the clerical reasons mentioned by the Minister, is the problem of excess paper. I cannot see that as a real problem, given the benefits and savings that could be obtained by the Government if these procedures were put in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the question which Senator Harradine addressed to me. I think the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) could equally have responded to it. The actual recommendation from the Public Account Committee relates to the statement which comes to us here each month. In that sense the Minister is correct in saying that it would result in some increase in the amount of paper being tabled in this place, but that does not mean to say that Senator Harradine's alternative formulation could not be turned to at some point.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Stone's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

Our general comments in this area have already been expressed in the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills which we concluded last night, and the Opposition is, therefore, prepared to move straight into committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to pick up the threads of the debate which we left last Thursday when the Senate adjourned at 10.30 p.m. We had had a quite extensive discussion on clause 2, which I certainly do not wish to go over again, the fundamental point of which was that clause 2 is a clause which removes from section 7 of the Constitution the existing fixed term for senators of six years. I simply ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to do no more at this stage than to confirm what he said on 26 May-namely, that this particular provision of the referendum Bill, clause 2, does change the current provision of the Constitution, does remove the fixed term and does, in that sense, alter what the framers of the Constitution had envisaged as the way in which the Senate would be composed and would operate as to the terms of the members of the Senate chamber. In other words, I would really like to get this debate off so that we have some continuity and have Senator Tate confirm what he had to say at page 3054 of Hansard of 26 May. Perhaps the simplest thing would be for him to look at the marked passage and read it into the record, in which case, as far as I am concerned, I would have nothing further to say on clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear that this referendum Bill does change the current provisions in the Constitution in relation to the terms of members of this chamber, in so far as, at the moment, they are elected for a fixed term. As I said on page 3054 of the Senate Hansard of 26 May:

SPEECH.PARA: In that respect this proposal alters what the framers had envisaged as the way in which the Senate would be composed and would operate as to the terms of the members of the Senate chamber.
It is a proposal to change the terms of senators to four years so that the terms of both members of this chamber and of the House of Representatives run for the same period.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. I ask the Minister a very simple question. Can he confirm that that element of the proposal, that change to the fixed terms of senators, which has the effect that he has just described, is not mentioned in the long title of the Bill? I simply want the Minister's confirmation that that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not entirely agree that that is the correct way to note the relationship of my previous answer to the long title of the Bill. The long title of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

I think anyone who has any inkling of the present situation, which, as we have agreed, is for fixed terms of six years, would understand that that long title provides for a superseding of the present position in order to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament, clearly including the Senate chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister: Does he believe that a person, the average voter, if you like-the person who will be called upon to vote on this-reading the long title of the Bill, which is what will appear on his ballot paper, and to which he has to write yes or no, has his or her attention directed to the change from a fixed term of six years to a maximum term of four years? Does the Minister suggest that the long title specifically draws to the attention of an elector the fact that we are leaving behind, abolishing, a fixed term arrangement?

—I believe that most Australians would understand, when confronted with a referendum proposal, that of course they are altering the current situation provided for under the Constitution. In so far as they are confronted with a proposal that the Constitution be altered to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament, I am quite confident that the average Australian voter would understand that thereby the present situation of fixed terms of six years is being altered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were debating this matter last week, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) acknowledged during questioning that this proposal does indeed interfere with the role of the Senate at the moment. The Minister chose to say that the proposal would alter the characteristics of the Senate. He refused to acknowledge that those characteristics gave it a power that under this legislation would certainly be done away with. What the Opposition was claiming during that debate was that the independence of the Senate from the Prime Minister of the day, the independence that this legislation proposes to do away with-resulting from the Senate having a fixed term-encourages the Prime Minister if he wants to take the Senate to an election at least to stick to that fixed term and stops him from going to elections very much too early. Indeed, it limits rather than increases the number of elections that can be held.

SPEECH.PARA: All this legislation would do-the Minister acknowledges this-is give the Prime Minister the opportunity of taking the whole of the Senate and the House of Representatives to the people as often as he chose, whenever he liked, whenever it suited him politically to do so. The Minister acknowledges all that. The Minister claims that because it is a four-year term that is proposed, even though the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has never used his full three-year term, he might be encouraged to go to an election less often. That is not what the legislation provides, and in this chamber we can look only at what the legislation provides. Indeed, the legislation provides that the Prime Minister can take the whole of the Parliament-the whole of the Senate and the House of Representatives-to the people whenever he likes.

We on this side look at the matter factually and say that this legislation is proposing to strip the Senate of its power of independence. The Minister chooses to say that it proposes to strip the Senate of its characteristics of independence. I am quite sure that people will be able to judge which is the correct term. I ask the Minister whether it is a fact that in the past, and not so very long ago, it was written into the Australian Labor Party policy that the Senate should be abolished?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very glad that Senator Walters has brought that up because, yes indeed, it was part of the Australian Labor Party platform at one stage that the Senate chamber be abolished. Very fortunately, I, amongst others, had a role at the National Conference back in 1978 or 1980, I cannot recall exactly, when that particular plank in the platform was itself abolished, if you like. The fact was that the Australian Labor Party has recognised, I believe correctly, that the Senate chamber plays an important role in our Australian democracy and that its composition, drawn as it is from the six original States plus the two Territories now, and the way in which it is composed under the electoral system provided for, really creates a chamber which plays a very important role in our democratic deliberations as elected representatives of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I think it is the case that the Senate's ability to make a stand against the House of Representatives, which is, of course, in our Westminster system controlled by the Government, increases the stature, if you like, and enhances the strength of the Senate. Under this proposal, every four years the Senate will be freshly elected by the Australian people and, having been composed at the same time as the House of Representatives, will have a strength to its claim to represent the Australian people in a way which it does not, I believe, have at the moment with the staggered and rotated fixed terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I add something to the excellent answer the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has given. Indeed, I commend him for the patient and lucid way in which he has explained this Bill over the last couple of days. Much has been made of the independence of the Senate. Clearly, it is a body that is separate and independent from the House of Representatives. One matter I would like to raise is this: what elections are all about is who shall govern, and when elections are held it is the government that goes to the people and the people who give their verdict on that government. In this chamber there is a great proportion of the government; in fact we have nine excellent Ministers who form part of it. I cannot see why it is not proper for that portion of the Government to go to the people at the same time as the rest of the Government.
—And with any luck some of them will lose.

—If we did lose government, and heaven help that does not happen, Senator Chaney would be over here forming part of the Government and it would only be proper at the end of the four years when his colleagues from the House of Representatives went to the people that he should do likewise because he would be a very eminent figure in any government formed by the coalition. Why is it fair for his Leader in the House of Representatives to go to the people but not him? Why is it fair that he can hide behind three, four or eight-year fixed terms so that his responsibility to the Government is not put to the test? Where is the fairness in that? On the other hand, if Ministers were removed from this chamber, if the Opposition were to say there should be no Ministers in this chamber, there would be a very strong argument for having separate elections and two terms. But honourable senators cannot have it both ways. Honourable senators cannot be part of a responsible government and at the same time pretend that they are not. That problem was foreseen by such people as Mr Alfred Deakin, as he then was, when the founding fathers were debating this matter. He said that it was hard to have responsible government living with, in effect, a House of review. It seems to me that that is the very question the Opposition has not addressed. Why should not a House which contains a very high proportion of Government members, both Cabinet and non-Cabinet Ministers, be put to the test at the same time as their colleagues in the House of Representatives?

SPEECH.PARA: If, as I think it should, the term of the House of Representatives is to be increased to a four-year term, in conformity with every other parliament in Australia except that of Queensland, which is the only parliament where a three-year term remains, are we going to give senators eight years in this place without having to go to the people? The proposition that the Senate have an eight-year term was never put by any founding father. Indeed, one founding father said it should have four-year terms and certainly a term no greater than six years because honourable senators should not be afraid to put themselves before the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with some reluctance because we have had a very lengthy debate on clause 2. But Senator Cooney has brought in an artful and irrelevant new argument on which I thought I should at least very briefly express a view on behalf of the Opposition. Senator Cooney fails to distinguish between the dual roles that are filled by people in both the Senate and the House of Representatives as members of the Executive and members of the legislature. We are debating a fundamental change that goes to the character of the Senate as a legislative chamber. In those circumstances Senator Cooney is importing an argument about some senators being Ministers in a way which totally ignores the fact that our fundamental concern about the changes being made in the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988 is that the Senate as a chamber, as an institution, is having some of its fundamental qualities changed. The importance of the changes being made is that they do go to the Senate's quality as a legislative chamber because they go to its independence. The reality is that there is very limited parliamentary independence from the Executive, whether it is in this national Parliament or in the State parliaments, but the high point of legislative independence in Australia is undoubtedly this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to re-canvass all of the arguments about why that is so and the role of the minority parties, et cetera. Without taking any more time of the Committee I suggest that Senator Cooney has put an artful argument but one which does not go at all to that fundamental concern about the maintenance of the Senate as a chamber which has a genuine and separate legislative function which at times it chooses to exercise even in the teeth of the normal overbearing attitude of the Executive Government. I do not make that comment in a partisan way. Governments by their nature wish to control the legislative process. If Senator Cooney is ever a Minister-I am sure all of us who regard him with goodwill would hope that he one day would have that opportunity, perhaps in the twenty-first century-I can assure him that he would find that there is a most extraordinary vanity in the bureaucracy about the legislation which is introduced by governments. The thought that elected members of parliament might interfere with the expertise that has been put before the parliament seems to cause the most extraordinary heartache. They manage to convey this heartache to their Ministers who adopt, in most cases, the most extraordinary proprietary air about every dot and comma. The legislature is treated with contempt.

That is the simple factual situation which we in the Senate have actually managed to get around a bit by way of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I remember I put up the proposal for the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and was then part of the Government which knocked it on the head. It was only a rebellious Senate that put it in place. I remember with very great pleasure that I was the first Minister in the Fraser Government, when I was representing at that time the Minister for Primary Industry in this place, to adopt amendments put forward by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Amendments were made to a series of Bills because the Parliament had pointed out that they were defective.

All of that is part of the reality that is touched by this referendum. I say to Senator Cooney, therefore, that his argument is essentially a distraction. I hesitate to use the term `red herring' because that term seems to be blessed by its usage by Senator Robert Ray. Senator Ray keeps accusing the Opposition of throwing in red herrings. In this case, it is Senator Cooney who has thrown in the red herring. His arguments go not at all to the real question of whether we will make changes which will reduce the very limited-even in the Senate-genuine legislative activity which takes place in this Parliament. I do not regard this chamber as just a rubber stamp for the bureaucracy, but that is a very unpopular view particularly in the bureaucracy and also amongst Ministers because of the process of infection. For that reason I think we should be very concerned about any change which will reduce that tiny remaining vestige of parliamentary life in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what Senator Chaney has said should be taken to heart by Senator Cooney. I have heard some talk of the Constitution in this particular referendum debate and in other debates, but I have not heard such a very strange interpretation of what the Constitution is all about as I just heard from Senator Cooney.
—Would you say it was a shallow argument?

—I think it is scraping the bottom of the barrel. That is how deep it is, rather than how shallow. Senator Cooney was trying to make a good job, as any lawyer would do, of a bad case, and Senator Chaney has responded adequately to his intervention. I want to go very briefly to a question that was raised when we were last dealing with this issue on 26 May. I refer to the comment made by Senator Tate in answer to my question about the real purposes of this measure. We are talking about the first question that is to be posed to the people dealing with maximum terms. As recorded on page 3056 of Hansard, I asked Senator Tate:

SPEECH.PARA: Am I to understand that the principal reason advanced by the Government for this measure is that it would do something to solve the problems of the Senate blocking Supply?
The Minister responded:

No, this proposal does not attempt to address that problem. In fact, that is the distinguishing characteristic between this proposal and that which was put, I think, in Senator Rae's referendum proposal and by the Australian Electoral Commission.
I imagine that that should read, `the Constitutional Commission'. Senator Tate said:
We do not attempt to address the question of Supply at all.

I want to contrast that statement by Senator Tate to this chamber-he is the Minister in charge of the Bill-with the statement of the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, on 11 May 1988 on the AM program when referring to this measure. The Attorney-General of Australia, in commenting about the first proposal, said:

I'm not optimistic about the first one. I think I'd win the other three without the support of the Opposition because they affect the rights of people. But the first one certainly comes into the usual political knock down struggle of who's going to win, and we do need bipartisan support on it.
Here is the salient point:

It would be much easier if John Howard and his Party were to face up to the fact of, what we do about the Senate's power over Supply, and also why shouldn't a Senate be answerable for its actions. That's the issue.

Here we have the Attorney-General saying one thing and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) saying exactly the opposite. What I want to know is who is misleading whom. Is Senator Tate misleading the Senate or is the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, misleading the public-or does he not know what it is all about? I agree that Senator Tate is not misleading the Senate, but I would like him to clarify for me and for this chamber the obvious discrepancy as to the Government's intention in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is a discrepancy. It is the case that the referendum proposal does not attempt to confront the question of Supply in the way, for example, that was put forward by the Constitutional Commission, which had it in mind that the Senate ought not to be able to refuse Supply for the first three years of a four-year term. Mr Lionel Bowen was certainly saying on the AM program-I did not get the quotation down completely-that, in a political sense, he would like the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, to come to grips with the question of Supply. But the Government has very consciously put aside and behind it the proposal put forward by the Constitutional Commission to deal with Supply and is confronting the political situation which Mr Bowen would have liked Mr Howard to come to grips with.

SPEECH.PARA: The political situation is that there will be no agreement in the Australian political system about whether or not the Senate ought to be able to refuse Supply to a government which retained the confidence of a majority in the House of Representatives. In that situation we are quite adamant that this proposal does not deal with Supply. Indeed, as recorded on page 2559 of House of Representatives Hansard for 18 May, the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in speaking to the Constitution alteration Bills, said:

I cannot understand this nonsense of saying we are interfering with the powers of the Senate. We are not interfering one iota with its powers. We are recognising now and for all time that those in the Senate who have no powers to initiate money Bills and no powers to amend money Bills have a power to veto money Bills and deny the very lifeline of the Government.

It is quite clear that the legislation before us does not deal with the problem of Supply being refused by this chamber. That is a very conscious difference between this Bill and that which was proposed by the Constitutional Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to have it made very clear that, as Senator Tate indicated in the Parliament last week, there is no suggestion of the Yes proposition being linked with the question of Supply. Senator Tate, as I recall it, said that there was no implication that the Yes case was somehow linked with Supply. For the purposes of the record, I think it is important to note that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is taking a different tack. He threw the Supply question into the debate even before the issue came before this Parliament. Will he do it again or does he not understand the legislation? Do we have an Attorney-General who does not understand the fundamentals of the Bill that is before us? For the purposes of the record let me quote precisely what was said on AM. The interviewer was a Peter Thompson. The interview went as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: PETER THOMPSON: Would you be optimistic that these referendums can still pass in the community in a majority of States, now that the Opposition is opposed to them.

LIONEL BOWEN: I'm not optimistic about the first one. I think I'd win the other three without the support of the Opposition because they affect the rights of the people. But the first one certainly comes into the usual political knock down struggle of who's going to win, and we do need bipartisan support on it. It would be much easier if John Howard and his Party were to face up to the fact of, what do we do about the Senate's power over Supply, and also why shouldn't a Senate be answerable for its actions. That's the issue.
PETER THOMPSON: Just a brief final one. Why did you go ahead with these bills before the second report of the Constitutional Commission?

LIONEL BOWEN: We had the report on this one. This was, as I say, a draft report back in October, which John Howard and Co. rejected, because it had the basis. There was to be no dissolutions in the first three years of a Parliament and the Senate could not reject Supply in the first three years. Now the Opposition rejected that and I've come to a compromise of trying to make it four years for both, in other words, we weren't out of kilter, and then they're still stuck with it, the Commission. But my suggestion is to have it on the basis we go to the people together, and the Senate always be answerable for its actions. Now Mr Howard doesn't want that, he wants to give Senators 8 year terms. I think the public opinion think that's far too long.

If honourable senators can make anything out of that, the Attorney-General seems to be throwing in the issue of the Senate's power to block Supply, I agree that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) and, indeed, the Attorney-General, if he knew what he was talking about-or even if he did not know what he was talking about-would be quite honest and straightforward on this aspect. I am trying to achieve a clear cut debate so that the people know what we are talking about. I seek confirmation that this issue of the power of the Senate to reject Supply should not enter the discussion of the question that is now before the Parliament.
As to the other matter on which I seek clarification, Senator Tate, as recorded on page 3059 of Hansard, made the following acknowledgment:
Given the different way in which it is actually composed-
that is, the Senate-

and given the fact that one would only need a 7 1/2 per cent quota in order to gain or secure a place in this chamber, we will have a type of representation of the Australian community every four years which would give to this chamber added weight in its deliberations on matters sent up by the other House.
