I would be grateful if the Minister could clarify for the chamber precisely what that means. I do not wish to delay the committee stage any further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the last matter, I was simply making the point-and I think Senator Harradine was in the chamber at the time and he took some pride in the fact that he never needed 7 1/2 per cent but was installed by the Tasmanian people on roughly a 15 per cent quota-that because of the way in which this chamber is elected, with the Australian Democrats and several Independents, three including Senator Robert Wood in a sense, we have a chamber which indeed reflects different strands of political conviction in the Australian community which are not represented in the type of chamber that is composed by the House of Representatives method of voting, with single member electorates. Quite clearly, just a simple glance at both chambers reveals the basis for the different type of representative quality and character which is possessed by this chamber, compared with the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: As regards the first matter, I think I can only repeat that this Government has taken a very conscious decision not to embrace the proposition put forward by the Constitutional Commission that the question of Supply be tackled by stripping the Senate of the power to defer or refuse Supply in its first three years of a four-year term. Indeed, it remains perfectly open to this chamber, after the passage of this referendum, to defer the Supply Bills or actually refuse their passage by voting against them should they be presented at any time in the future. The reason why I was not acceding to Senator Walters's pleas that I make some sort of admission that the powers of the Senate were altered by our proposal was that I had in mind very specifically that the power of the Senate to deal with Supply Bills is not in any way affected by this referendum proposal. I have said that the six-year fixed term characteristic of the chamber will change, and I do not think I can reiterate the points any more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene to say that I am not persuaded by Senator Tate's point that minority groups are able to be well represented here. That is one thing. I agree with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that we should have representation of those minority groups, but it is possible for a minority group, elected on a primary vote of just over one per cent, to have full control of the government of the day. One or two of those people in here can have the final say on every piece of legislation that goes through this place. Therefore, the Minister should face the detail of the facts that he is not making available to the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I get back to my theme. I asked the Minister earlier whether it was indeed past Australian Labor Party policy that the Senate should be abolished. The Minister said yes, that it was past Labor policy but that he had changed his mind and indeed he was one of those who had been instrumental in having the policy changed, he thought in about 1980, at one of the Labor conferences. I remember very well, and I am sure the Minister does, the comments made by Senator Gareth Evans at the time. If the Minister would like me to get the quote, I will. Senator Evans said, `It is not popular with the people of Australia to have that up front in Labor's policy, so let us get it out of our policy. But we can still work very hard underneath for the ultimate abolition of the Senate. But because it is not a popular thing to have up front in our policy, we should debate it'. When Senator Evans came into this place he said that the best way to abolish the Senate was to white-ant it from within.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say that? Surely he would not have said that!

—Of course he did, and the honourable senator knows that only too well. It underlines the fact that the true aim of the Labor Party has always been to abolish the Senate. Even though it may well have been taken out of Labor policy because, as Senator Evans said, it was unpopular with the people, those opposite could still, and indeed do, work very hard underneath for its abolition. As Senator Evans said, to enter the Senate is the best way to white-ant-from within. Senator Button in 1983, and many other Labor senators, acknowledged that the simultaneous elections referendum issue put up at that stage was also to strip the Senate of its powers. So it is no use the Minister saying here, in 1988, that that is no longer Labor Party policy as set down in its platform. We know why it is not policy in the platform; Senator Evans made it very clear at the time. So there really is little use in the Minister trying to pull the wool over our eyes at this late stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney and others have indicated that they feel the motivation of the Australian Labor Party in respect of the Senate is not all pure. Whilst I may have had some concern about motivation over many years, it has never been the bottom line for me. I instance a man drowning in a dam in a farmer's paddock. The farmer drags him out. His motivation is only that it is unsightly to have a body floating around in the dam. Of course the fact that he saves the man is important, and I am sure the man will not jump back in again. I make that point to show that we should look at the effect, the bottom line, of what we seek to do with this proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney talked about the House of review aspect of the Senate. The capacity of the Senate to be a House of review is in no way interfered with by the proposal that is before the chamber. It simply says that if at an election for the House of Representatives a government is to be judged on its policy, its past activity, its record and what it intends to do and reinstated or removed, at the same time the Senate should have to go to the people and answer for its attitude to the various aspects of policy and laws that have been passed or are intended to be passed. The people will not be told that because three years ago the Australian Democrats and the Independents won the balance of power, in the Senate with their votes, and the Opposition now finds that obnoxious, that situation cannot be changed for another three years. Those opposite believe that the people should be able to elect members of the House of Representatives to enact legislation and pay them good salaries but also pay good salaries to the people of the Senate to reject those laws that it wants passed. If they tell me that is logical and that is the way for a progressive and thinking society to go, I have to disagree. I do not disagree that the people have the right to take that attitude-that I would defend to the last-but whether it is correct or not, I would question very forcefully.

Let us look at one other aspect that has been canvassed here: the role of the Senate when it was established as a States House. The Queensland branch of the Liberal Party very clearly wants the referendum question on the principle of one vote one value to be carried. On the other hand, the Federal Liberal Party says that it does not. A number of honourable senators representing the Liberal Party would oppose the very people who elected them. They would oppose their own people in Queensland. Those States House representatives who are here to look after the interests of Queensland are to be stood over and domineered by a person such as John Stone, who, if he could do so, would increase the imbalance of electorates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. We are in the committee stage of this debate. It seems to me that the honourable senator is ranging rather wide. Indeed, he is touching on a different referendum. In deference to the Government's concern to see some progress on these matters, quite apart from anything else, I suggest that the honourable senator be reminded that we are debating the parliamentary terms legislation, not the so-called fair elections legislation, and he might, therefore, come back to the Bill.
—Order! The Committee is considering the question that clause 2 stand as printed. I ask Senator Burns to confine his remarks to relevance to that question.

—It is very difficult to do that, but I accept your decision, Mr Temporary Chairman. I close by saying that I believe, as I have said, that this proposition does not interfere in any way with the Senate as a House of review. It gives the people of Australia a real opportunity to change the government and to have the policy they want carried by both legislative chambers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to put a different point of view to Senator Burns. Of course a four-year term obstructs any decision that the Senate may make. Obviously, if a government has its legislation amended, blocked or altered in some way, it can take the Senate out at any time it chooses. Presently, if a government has its legislation knocked back or amended and does not accept the amendment, it has the option of calling a double dissolution, but first it has to re-present the Bill in the Senate within three months. If the Bill is not accepted and is rejected by the Senate on that occasion, the Prime Minister of the day can call on the Governor-General and seek a double dissolution or another election. The Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill takes away that right so that any time the Opposition, with the Independents or the Australian Democrats, obstructs legislation, the Government can call an election immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: If that situation had applied in the last three or four years, an identity card would have been presented to the Australian people as a fait accompli. Because we had the right to block the ID card legislation, during that time the momentum of objections built up to such an extent that the Government, after going to an election, was so pleased when Senator Stone found a loophole that most Labor senators had to go round sucking lemons to keep the smiles off their faces. They knew that, if the ID card proposal had gone through, they would have been dismissed. The momentum really built up during the election and that led to the demise of the ID card.

Another example is the Bill of Rights. The Government's legislation was passed in the lower House and was rejected by this chamber. It was not so much rejected; while the legislation was held up in this chamber, public opinion built up so much that the Government, for its own survival, had to withdraw it. Section 45 of the Trade Practices Act is another provision that would have escaped if the Senate had not existed. Immediately we reject or alter such legislation, under the proposal before us the Government would call an election and go straight to the people.

If the legislation before us becomes law, the other House will be put in a predominant position over the Senate. The Senate will be just the rubber stamp of the House of Representatives. Everyone can see that. It is completely misleading for the Government to seek to do that under the guise of having four-year terms. If Senator Tate can explain to the Committee how this legislation will guarantee a four-year term, I will support it. However, it does not do so. It is not stated anywhere in the legislation that a four-year term will be guaranteed. What will happen, as surely as night follows day, is that as soon as any important legislation which the Government wants to go through is amended, it will immediately call an election-whether it is one year, two years or three years into its term. We will be going to the people at the drop of a hat.

I believe that the Government is trying to emasculate the Senate. It has been said by Senator Walters from Tasmania that it has always been the intention of the Labor Government to abolish upper Houses and the Senate. That would be ruled out by the people. They want that safeguard, that brake, that insurance policy, there. The Government knows quite well that the people would not accept the abolition of the upper Houses in the States and the Senate, so it has approached the question from another angle; it has driven in from another tack. The Government has decided to abolish and emasculate the power of this Senate. It will no longer be the insurance policy on which this nation has relied for 61 years. Every time the Government is obstructed, we will go to the people. We will not have elections every two years, as we have for the last 43 years; we will be going out every 12 or 18 months. That is what we have to be terribly careful about.

I agree that Independent senators have a place in the Senate. I think that Senator Harradine has made a worthy contribution to the Senate. He rightfully deserves his position here. However, I understand that Senator Harradine achieved around 15 per cent of the vote; he received a full quota. What will we do when the quota goes down to 7.69 per cent? I note that Senator Ray is writing this down; I hope that he will address the question. Unfortunately, he indicates that he will not do so. The Senate will have representatives from the extreme left and the extreme right and every single-issue party. There will be all sorts of single-issue groups-such as a group which wants water fluoridation-thus making it impossible for this place to pass any legislation without backroom deals being done.

I do not recall very many times in this session of Parliament-I think that it would be only three or four-that the Democrats have supported the Opposition's side in a division. We could ask, without reflecting on the vote of the Senate: What sorts of deals have been done? Why did the Democrats change their position on the resource rent tax? Why do they approach things from completely different angles? Why do they support legislation when previously they supported the Opposition in opposing it? We will have to set up a little room in which the Government can negotiate with all the odds and sods and other remnants that will creep in under a quota of 7.69 per cent. Under those circumstances there will never be a time when a government will be able to have its legislation passed.

If the people of Australia support and have confidence in the Government and the Senate, they will give that Government and the Senate their imprimatur to pass legislation by giving the Government a mandate for both the lower House and the upper House by voting for Government candidates and thus allowing the Government to gain enough representation to govern. That Government would deserve to have its legislation passed. That will never occur if this Bill is passed. All sorts of people who gain only one per cent or 2 per cent of the vote are elected. There will be trade-offs and backroom deals. Committees will be set up. People will say, `If you set up a committee to investigate nuclear power in Australia, I will support some Bill or other'; `If you set up a committee to investigate organically grown food, I will support this or that Bill'. The Parliament will be run by backroom, under-the-counter deals. That is not good for Australia or for parliamentary representation. If this legislation is passed, we will not escape that situation. We have already seen it occur in this place. Therefore, I would reject this legislation on that scenario alone.

When one adds together the two scenarios, one has a real problem. One would have not only emasculated the Senate, but also cemented in place all single issue groups. We know that the Australian Democrats obtained 7 per cent of the vote throughout Australia. They are the ones who really control the Senate. I do not accept that that is in the best interests of Australia. In fact, I think it is appalling that a party that attains 7 per cent of the vote controls the passage of the Government's legislation. It is not in the best interests of this nation. I ask Senator Tate-I hope to ask Senator Robert Ray as well, while he is in the chamber-to answer this question. I know that it concerns Senator Ray, as it must concern Senator Tate, as an honest senator from Tasmania. Will they address those two problems?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly, since Senator Boswell invited me to do so. He made a few points. He said that there is no guarantee that a government's term will run for four years if this proposal is carried in the electorate. That is correct. Probably, the preference in Australian Labor Party policy and in reality is that we would have preferred fixed four-year terms. It was made very clear by the Opposition last year that that was unacceptable. One of the reasons why a fixed four-year term proposal was not introduced was in order to accommodate the Opposition. I am not here to argue that we have been totally amenable to accommodating the Opposition, but in that regard, that is why the word `fixed' was removed from the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell also talked about upper Houses as though they were absolutely wonderful. If they are so wonderful, why has his Party not reinstated one in Queensland? The upper House was abolished in 1922 or 1924.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party abolished it.
—The Labor Party abolished it.
—He is not in the upper House in the State Parliament. He is in this Parliament. That is totally irrelevant.

—Senator Lewis, it is well known that Senator Boswell is an influential member of the National Party in Queensland. I am not even being sarcastic when I say that. I wonder why that Party has not sought to re-establish the upper House. Will Senator Boswell argue that Queensland politics have been irretrievably scarred by the absence of an upper House in the last 30 years? Probably not.
—The answer to that is yes.

—Senator Chaney, with his loyalty to the coalition, says that it has. That must come as a shock to Senator Boswell. Senator Boswell has made many comments today about, if you like, the free kick to minority parties. We do not differ very much on this issue, but it conflicts with the other view opposite that this chamber must be a blocking chamber. Once there is a government majority, it is no longer a blocking chamber. If we on this side of the chamber had a majority, we would have already adjourned for the session; I admit that. If the Opposition, in government, had a majority, it would not dilly-dally by having long and tedious debates. The debates would be reasonably long, but the Government program would be determined by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a contradiction in the argument that Senator Boswell put forward today. He wants this chamber to be a blocking chamber yet he wants to do away with minority groups. No-one on this side of the chamber would disagree that it is wrong for democracy to have a minority group dictating to governments, be they coalition governments or Labor governments; but that is part of the new federal compact. It would not be a problem if the House of Representatives was the dominant House with dominant powers. Proportional representation has always been good at distributing representation. It has always been the worst possible method of distributing power. That is where the distinction lies. If the Houses were not of equal power, proportional representation would not have that dictatorial effect that Senator Boswell alluded to. Of course, it is in our hands and the hands of the Opposition to change the voting system for the Senate and cut out all the minority groups. We could go back to the old block voting system used prior to 1949. We could use a sophisticated d'Hondt system to cut out the minority parties. That is open to us, but I have not seen any willingness on either side to promote that proposal.

I will refer very briefly to a few other arguments. This issue has been raised: What happens if the Prime Minister wants to take both Houses to an election? I ask: What are honourable senators opposite afraid of? Are they afraid to go to the people for judgment? Senator Boswell would realise that at the moment many people in Queensland are pushing for voters' initiative referendums.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are arguing that you want four years so that the Prime Minister will not call an election at any time. You cannot have it both ways.

—Let me develop the argument and Senator Lewis might then respond. One of the arguments against us is, `Are you afraid to go to the people?' I ask honourable senators opposite: Are they afraid to go to the people? In regard to early elections, there is a penalty on any Prime Minister who goes to the electorate early. People ask, `Why are you calling an early election?'. The biggest victim was the Premier of South Australia in 1978.
—It was 1979.

—In 1979. Mr Corcoran called a very early election and paid the penalty. The Prime Ministers who have gone to the polls very early recently have always had an excuse. In 1977 and 1984 Mr Fraser and Mr Hawke used this excuse: `Look, we have to hold a Senate election anyway because the Houses are out of kilter after a double dissolution. Let's go early'. They had that excuse and they were able to use it. In this circumstance, those excuses disappear. I say this seriously: any Prime Minister, once given a four-year term and once having argued for a four-year term, who wants to call an early election will pay a big political price. People will say, `After all, we have given the Government four-year terms and here they are, two or 2 1/2 years down the track, wanting an early election'. It is a very untenable position and it weakens the arguments of those opposite to a large extent.

SPEECH.PARA: While we are arguing about the length of terms, only a month ago Mr Greiner was complaining about the hangover regarding the people elected in 1978 who have a say in the election of the President of the Legislative Council in 1988. He was terribly upset by that process. The conservative parties in this country must be consistent. If we were to suggest to the public that there should be eight-year terms for senators, this referendum would be dead in the water on day one. The public will not support eight-year terms. It is much more realistic that they would support a four-year term. No-one opposite argues against a four-year term for the House of Representatives. The arguments are all to do with this chamber. I would like Senator Boswell and other honourable senators opposite to argue for eight-year terms and have the public accept that they could have elected a senator in 1980 and he would be ending his term in about three months time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never had a term longer than two years and I have been here six years.
—Of course you have not. But Senator Boswell and the Opposition suggest that we have double the House of Representatives term or an eight-year term.
—This clause deals with six-year terms. It doesn't deal with eight-year terms.

—No, but in the electorate it would be treated as an eight-year term. That is very hard to argue at a Federal level. I concede that it has been a bit easier to argue for eight-year terms at a State level where people are not quite so concerned with the terms of parliament. Let me go to the final matter because I know we want to wind up this debate.
—Come Minister, you are not going to wind it up.
—No, I am not going to wind it up.
—You have just encouraged people to come into the debate.

—Senator Lewis, this time I have been trying to argue the case dispassionately. I was invited by Senator Boswell to meet some of the serious points which he has raised. Running through the argument is a view that we do not accept: that the Senate, as an institution, should be inherently conservative. I have heard that argument mounted several times in this debate. Honourable senators opposite cannot expect us to accept as a valid argument that we should have the whole system matched so that this is a naturally conservative institution. That may be their point of view but they cannot expect us to accept it. Senator Walters especially pushed this line in her previous speech. We on this side do not necessarily have to accept that. We really do think that more and more in this country governments should establish a mandate and try to carry it out. I concede that we all fall short of that. But I do not think that a mandate given eight years ago would be a sufficient one on which to judge policies these days. Some of the points made by Senator Boswell were not directly relevant to this issue but I can agree with him that we should not be doing anything to promote minority dictation in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude on this point. When the next election is called and it comes to the crunch, because of the historic division and the fear between both parties, we will again send our preferences to minority groups and allow those with 2 per cent or 3 per cent, either in a half-Senate election or in a double dissolution, to get in because we can never send preferences to each other. Even if we did, we would be afraid of the reaction of the minority parties picking one of us off and destroying us or our chances in the House of Representatives. That is a dilemma we face with minority groups. I am quite happy to see the continuation of proportional representation in upper Houses around Australia. After all, the Australian Labor Party has introduced proportional representation in South Australia, and New South Wales. It has attempted to do so in Victoria and may very well do so in Western Australia. I am not sure where it is up to in those proposals. It is all very well to come into the chamber and say that 11 years ago Senator Button said this and Senator Gareth Evans said that. I just ask honourable senators opposite to look at our record in terms of upper Houses. We have given up the fight to abolish; we have said we will reform and change them to a different type of chamber. That is why we have gone for proportional representation in four States. Currently the Labor Party policy does not have a plank for abolition of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), rather than terminating the debate on this clause, has just opened it up. That caused me some concern. So much of what he was talking about-such as eight-year terms and such things-was a complete red herring. We are dealing with clause 2 of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill. Clause 2 proposes to delete from the Constitution the paragraph which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The senators shall be chosen for a term of six years.

It has nothing to do with inserting a provision for eight or even four years. This provision in the Constitution deals with the fixed term of senators. I was interested to hear Senator Robert Ray say that the Labor Party favours fixed terms, but what it is doing here is taking away the fixed term of senators. Let me put my position clearly because I want Senator Ray to understand this: I am totally opposed to fixed terms in the House of Representatives for many reasons which I have put in this House on a previous occasion. If he likes I will give him my paper on the subject. There are many reasons, from both a parliamentary and an executive government point of view, why it is unwise and unsound to have a fixed term in the lower House. As an example, look at what is happening and has been happening in Papua New Guinea ever since the very clever Australian bureaucrats devised fixed terms for the PNG Parliament. On the other hand, our clever founding fathers-believe it or not it turns out, with hindsight, that they were clever-decided that they would not give a fixed term to the lower House but that they would give a fixed term to the upper House, the Senate. They thereby created a brake on the Prime Minister and the executive government of the day calling an election at any time they felt like it. They can still do so and if they have to they will, but the consequence of a government calling an election out of synchronisation with the Senate is that, in due course, the government will have to face a half Senate election. Because a half Senate election is treated as some sort of by-election the result is usually devastating for the government of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—I see that Senator Robert Ray agrees with me. That is a very substantial brake on the Prime Minister of the day calling an election unless he can fit it into having a half Senate election at the same time. That has been proven by history because on only four or maybe five occasions has there been a half Senate election by itself. So Prime Ministers have been aware of this brake. I am not saying that the founding fathers were able to walk on water but they gave about 10 years consideration to the constitutional problems of this country. They had before them the Constitution of the United States of America and how that had been established. They were able to select from all the wisdom of a couple of centuries of Westminster type government and they chose carefully and wisely to provide the lower House with a non-fixed term and the upper House with a fixed term. I put it to the Minister that clause 2 of this Bill takes away the fixed term of the Senate. I ask: How on earth does the Government justify putting that to the people when it claims that it supports fixed terms in general?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the recent section of this debate, I would like the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) to answer this query: If this clause were implemented, would it not undermine the whole spirit and intent of our Constitution? After all, can he deny that the Constitution was constructed to provide checks and balances against the unfettered power of the executive government? That was by design. The independence of this House was by design. That is why it was given a different electorate, a different voting system and different terms-fixed terms. The other House has non-fixed terms. Can he deny that this House is to act as a House of review, as a States House and as a House to protect the rights of the people?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray referred to the Senate as a blocking House as if it was always to be a blocking House. I happen to have been in the Senate when it was a blocking House, and it was very quickly disciplined by the people, who recognised that the Government had been elected to govern on its policies and that the Senate was acting in an obstructive way. The people exercise discipline against the Senate acting in that way. Can he deny that the election of half the Senate at each Senate election was not put there by design? It was to give us a continuing memory in the Senate so that there would be some senators who remembered the actions that took place in the previous parliament. I see all these proposals as an emasculation of the Constitution as we know it. Can the Minister deny that he is not going against the spirit and the intent of the Constitution; that he is not going against the checks and the balances that were put there by design, and that he is not acting against the independence of the Senate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The constitutional proposal that is to be put to this chamber and then to the people, I believe, retains the sort of balancing factor important in a federation, to which Senator Sheil points. It will still be the fact, after this proposal is carried by the people, should they so desire to support it in the required majorities, that 12 senators will come from Queensland, as from every other State of the Commonwealth, including my own, Tasmania. In other words, there is no proposal to change that special federal character or the way in which this chamber is composed. It is also a fact that the deliberative and legislative powers of this chamber will remain precisely the same. Should the Senate wish to reject any Bill whatsoever, it will still be entitled to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of the continuing memory of the Senate, the people can decide whether they wish Senator Sheil, Senator Lewis or Senator Tate to continue for another four-year maximum term. That is up to the people to decide. If the people in their wisdom decide to have a completely fresh set of senators, I suppose they can vote that way. As honourable senators know, it is entirely improbable that there would be such a wholesale clearing out of senators. I believe that the memory of the Senate, in that sense, will continue but with the freshness of a reconfirmation by the people every four years as the Senate is elected at the same time as the House of Representatives.

As to the other matters that have been raised, I do not think I need to traverse the ground that already has been put by Senator Robert Ray in his extended response to Senator Boswell, except to affirm absolutely that there is no issue more dead in Australian politics than the question of the abolition of the Senate. It is certainly dead in the Australian Labor Party; I think it is dead in the electorate. I use the Queensland situation only to say that, for my own part, that has been a strong motivating factor in maintaining the position I do about the Senate. I believe one of the factors which have led to the sort of government which has become arrogant in Queensland is the fact that an executive government has been able to move straight into the single chamber there without an upper House even to consider and pass its legislation in a matter of hours should it so desire. I do not believe that is healthy in a democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has answered the question at all. To say that the Senate will be completely unaffected by this measure is completely wrong because it puts the Senate at the mercy of the House of Representatives and the Prime Minister. That was specifically precluded by the Constitution. The Government is taking this measure to put this chamber at the mercy of the Prime Minister. Under the Constitution the Senate was given an independence of action so that the Prime Minister could not take it to the people unless he decided to go on an issue and call a double dissolution. So the Minister has not answered the question of whether the powers of the Senate will be completely unaffected. They will be affected by this measure. I see the independence of the Senate as one of the major triumphs of the Constitution as it exists today.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 3 (Times and places).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of clause 3, which omits the second paragraph of clause 9 of the Constitution, I ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) for a brief explanation as to what this is doing. The second paragraph of clause 9 of the Constitution states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament of a State may make laws for determining the times and places of elections of senators for the State.

The reason for the omission of this paragraph, according to the explanatory note, is that, where all Senate elections are to be held at the same time as elections for the House of Representatives, the provision is not appropriate. I ask the Minister: Is this not another example of the quite fundamental change which is being made in terms of the structure of the Senate and its relationship to other institutions? We were talking in the rather long debate on clause 2 about the relationship between the Senate and the House of Representatives. In this case we are talking about the remaining influence that the States have upon what is meant to be the States House. This fixed term proposal would mean that the States no longer have any influence at all in terms of elections for the Senate. Is that correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that clause 3 repeals the second paragraph of section 9 of the Constitution, as Senator Chaney pointed out. That section empowers State parliaments to make laws for the times and places of Senate elections. As the Bill unfolds it is quite clear that the Senate elections are to be held at the same time as elections for the House of Representatives. So the proposal simply is that the times and places for Senate elections are to be set by the Constitution itself and by laws of the Commonwealth Parliament. I think most people in the Australian community would see it as fair that the Constitution and the Commonwealth Parliament set the times and places for elections for this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clauses 5 and 6-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I originally asked that we go through the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Amendment Bill clause by clause, clauses 5 and 6 seem to me to be totally complementary. I want to make some remarks about clauses 5 and 6. Clause 5 provides in part for the insertion in the Constitution of the statement that `the terms of service of senators expire upon the expiry or dissolution of the House of Representatives'. Clause 6 extends the House of Representatives term from three years to four years. The fundamental point I wish to raise with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) on these two clauses is that in fact these provisions give the Prime Minister of the day unlimited capacity to call elections for both the Senate and the House of Representatives at any time. As to what the Prime Minister will or will not do, I remind the Minister that Senator Durack in the committee stage last Thursday asked Senator Tate to give a guarantee about the number of elections that would be held. Senator Durack said:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the Minister give a guarantee-yes or no-on behalf of the Prime Minister, of the Government of which he is a member, that if this Bill is passed fewer elections will be called by his present leader, having regard to his past record?

I can only say that Senator Tate responded by saying that he was not in the Perth magistrates court and did not have to answer yes or no. The reality is that the passage of this referendum and the insertion of these clauses into the Constitution would mean that the Prime Minister could, for example, call an election this year for both the House of Representatives and the Senate. At the moment that is not open to the Prime Minister. He has a very distinct fetter on his capacity to call an unnecessary early election by the fact that under the present constitutional arrangements there cannot be a Senate election before 1 July next year. That is why the political commentators are tipping that if things stay as they are the earliest likely election is at the end of next year. If this constitutional amendment is passed the position will be that instead of the Prime Minister having to wait until next year to call an election for the Senate and the House of Representatives he could at any time after the passage of this Bill call an election for the Senate and the House of Representatives. It may well be said that that is not the intended consequence of this Bill, but it is a possible consequence and I think the people of Australia have learnt from the Ministers of this Government the meaning of the words `unintended consequences'.

The history of government is littered with things flowing from legislation which are not what the legislators, the politicians, said would flow. I ask the Minister to confirm to the Committee that these clauses mean that, if the parliamentary terms referendum is passed, the Prime Minister could have an election for both the Senate and the House of Representatives at any time after this referendum is passed. In other words, he would not have to wait until after 1 July next year to call an election for both Houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the passage of this referendum proposal will be that the term of senators currently holding office will come to an end at the dissolution or expiry of the House of Representatives.
—I ask the Minister to be quite specific in his reply. Does that mean that the Prime Minister would have the capacity to call an election for both Houses in October, November or December this year?
—The constitutional capacity will be there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up that point that Senator Chaney has made and to which Senator Tate has responded, although I will not take up the time of the Committee too much. But it is a fundamentally important point because until the fine print of the explanatory memorandum to the Bill is read, it is not apparent-I am sure it is not apparent to the electors who are going to have to vote on this proposal in the next few months-that the consequence of the Bill will be that the terms of all senators who were elected at the last election in July 1987 will be terminated at the next election, despite the fact that the voters who voted at the general election in July 1987 thought they were electing, because this was the proposition on which the Parliament went to the people, half the senators for a six-year term. The effect of this Bill, as I understand it, is that the basis on which the last election was held for senators in July 1987 will be changed as from the date of passage of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting in passing that this proposal in the Bill is contrary to the recommendation of the Government's Constitutional Commission which said that senators should serve the equivalent of two terms of the House of Representatives. It has not been explained to date to my satisfaction by the Government why it chose to go contrary to and reject the recommendation of its own commission. But as has been said in debate on earlier clauses, and as Senator Chaney has said, a fundamental consequence of this proposal is that the Prime Minister of the day, whoever he or she may be, would no longer have any Senate restraint imposed in the calling of an early election.

Senator Lewis, in his contribution on clause 2, made the point very well that under the present system, if the government and Prime Minister of the day go to an early election for the House of Representatives, sooner or later the electoral cycle will catch up and there will have to be a half Senate election. That has been a major constraint on successive Prime Ministers over the years seeking to rush to early elections just for short term opportunistic political gain. It has been a major constraint on Prime Ministers playing fast and loose with the electoral process, even though to some extent the restraint has not been total. But it has been very significant compared with what might otherwise have been the case. So the consequence of the clause we are now debating is to change all that and remove all the constraints imposed by the Senate on the timing of elections.

Another consequence is that the Bill virtually ensures the continued existence in the Senate of splinter groups, with the destabilising effects we have seen on effective government over past years. With the whole of the Senate going to election each time the House of Representatives goes to election, a candidate has to poll only approximately 7 1/2 per cent of the vote, rather than closer to 15 per cent under the present system, to be elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a little over one per cent of the primary vote.
—As Senator Walters says, that 7 1/2 per cent is not 7 1/2 per cent of the primary vote; it is 7 1/2 per cent after all the preference votes have been distributed.
—They could hold control of the Senate.

—That is right. We have seen a situation with Senator Robert Wood-nearly Senator Robert Wood-at the last election polling less than 1 1/2 per cent of the primary vote and being elected to the Senate. Most thinking people would regard such a result as quite crazy and certainly as undemocratic. But the effect of this clause will be to entrench that system.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return very briefly to the main point; the consequence of clause 5 is that all senators will face election at the next election immediately after the passage of this Bill, if the referendum is passed. In one fell stroke the Senate restraint on the government and Prime Minister of the day calling an election at the political whim of the Prime Minister, and for short term opportunistic political gains which would not necessarily bear any resemblance to the interests of this nation, would be removed. That would fulfil the Labor Party's long-held objective, which despite the protestations that have been made during this debate certainly still exists, to weaken the position of the Senate and its ability to act as a balance to the possible excesses of executive government. That is the most significant implication and effect of all the referendum proposals before us. The consequences have not been spelt out to the public and there is no indication to date that the Government proposes to do so.

I am pleased to hear Senator Tate, in response to Senator Chaney's question, confirm that the consequences are just what we have alleged. I expect and hope that between now and the referendum, whenever it is held, that point will be brought home very clearly to the public, because what we are talking about here is the emasculation of the Senate and the ability of the elected Parliament of the people to fulfil its necessary constitutional role which is to provide checks and balances to the possible excesses and activities of executive government. What we are doing in one fell swoop is handing over our political system to the Executive at great cost and loss to the parliamentary system. That is the very antithesis of a democratic system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just elaborate a little further on what Senator Short was saying regarding the ability of senators to be elected to this place with just a little under 1 1/2 per cent of the primary vote. It would be very nice to have minority groups represented in this Senate. If we could do that as such so that minority groups could be represented and have a voice it would be very good. But the situation arises that they are not just represented in the Senate. They are able, and have in the past been able, to take full control of the Senate. If the numbers on both sides-the Labor Party side and the Liberal-National Party side-are virtually equal just one or two from a minority group who, as I say, have gained representation on just over one per cent of the primary vote have full control over every Bill, because the passage of legislation depends on whether they vote with the Government or with the Opposition. They cannot-I am quite sure the Australian people understand this-possibly deal in detail with all the legislation that comes through the Senate. It is not possible for two, three or even five people to deal with every piece of legislation that comes through the Senate. It is for that reason that sending the whole Senate to the people every time, and allowing through that mechanism the very small minorities to be represented in the Senate, is a great danger.

SPEECH.PARA: I give the Minister just a couple of examples of why it is very necessary for only half the Senate to go to the people on each occasion. Suppose that in a very large swing there is elected a government that, prior to the election, did not tell the people all its intentions. It gets in on promises which it put to the people but which it does not intend to carry out. It brings forward very radical legislation that the people of Australia had not thought that it would bring forward. If the whole Senate had gone to the election the Senate would reflect that very big swing towards that rogue government. The numbers in the Senate would mirror those of the lower House without any shadow of a doubt. They would reflect the electoral support for that rogue government. In that case there would be no stabilising influence on the actions of the government of the day.

That is the system that would apply if this proposal were passed, but under the present system, if such a government had a large swing, its numbers in the Senate would increase, but the swing would not be reflected in the total Senate because only half the Senate would have gone to the election; the other half would be the stabilising influence. The founding fathers, recognising the very great dangers of these massive swings, said that only half the Senate should go to the people at any one time. That is the basis of the great stability that we have in this country as opposed to other countries. It is imperative that that stability remain secure and that our Constitution still create the stability that was thought of so long ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make two points arising from the response which Senator Tate made to Senator Chaney. I believe that it was a very honest response from Senator Tate and I congratulate him on being an honest senator who is prepared to acknowledge-these are the words I noted-that there would be a constitutional entitlement to have an election in October or November of this year. In other words, once this measure was passed, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would be able to call an election this year-1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The person who was the Prime Minister after that election-the present Prime Minister or another one- could have another election in 1989. Admittedly he would have to face the people and explain why he was having an election in 1989 but, given some trumped up difficulty, say, the introduction of the Australia Card or some other measure which the Prime Minister of the day could introduce he could do that. An election having been held in 1989, there would be no constitutional limitation on the Prime Minister of the day having an election in 1990 if some other difficulty arose.

This could go on for as long as Prime Ministers and governments were able to get away with it. We know that politically there would be great difficulties and it may very well be that the government of the day would get rolled, but the point I make is that once this proposal was passed there would be an entitlement for the Executive Government and the Prime Minister of the day to have an election whenever they wanted. That is why we say that this proposal is dishonest.

On this proposal the people think that they are voting to extend the life of the Parliament from three years to four years. The truth of the matter is that under this proposal, although it appears on the surface that there may be an extension of the life of the Parliament from three years to four years, there could be very brief parliaments. In fact, I honestly and firmly believe that there will be many more elections, not fewer elections, once this measure is carried by the people of Australia. That is why we so strongly oppose this measure being approved by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman-
—I hope it will be a better contribution than the last.

—It will be, Senator Boswell. The last one was brilliant; this one will be ultrabrilliant. Much has been made of two issues: firstly, that it is bad to have the Senate and the House of Representatives elected at the same time; and, secondly, that the Prime Minister has the right to advise on an election at any time. The Constitution of Australia certainly has to be seen in the light of the Constitution of America, but also in the light of the unwritten constitution of the British Parliament. There is no doubt that the British Prime Minister has the constitutional right to advise the Queen as to when an election should be held, and that has been the position since the early twentieth century. Prior to that it was thought that the advice should be given on the basis of what the Cabinet decided, that the Prime Minister should take that advice to the Queen and that she should give an election on that basis. I think it was between 1913 and 1919 that an opinion was obtained that said that the Prime Minister should advise the Queen. It may well have been that that meant that he should advise the Queen in the light of what the Cabinet decided, but it has been acted upon as simply meaning that the Prime Minister himself or herself could make the decision and advise on an election.

SPEECH.PARA: When people in this chamber talk about the Prime Minister having the ability to call an election, they are simply stating the obvious; that is, that a Prime Minister in the Westminster system has that right and ability. It is not unusual; indeed, it is very much in keeping with the constitutional history to which we are heirs. Therefore, it seems to me to be drawing a red herring across the whole debate to say that it is bad because the Prime Minister can call an election. All that that says is that the Prime Minister, if he calls an election, is exercising his right to advise the Governor-General in light of constitutional history which we have inherited from England.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you say about upper Houses? It doesn't apply in Britain or Canada, does it?

—That is a good question, because it cannot apply in Canada, where the Senate is not an elected body but an appointed body. The House of Lords in England is made up of the great leading families of England which, of course, have served it so well over many generations. How many of those families are still the same as those which were around in the time of William the Conqueror, I think, is a matter of speculation. For example, Henry VIII of England headed many of the great noble families of England, as Senator Puplick would know. In any event, Canada and England are not comparisons because neither of those upper Houses is an elected body. I will turn to the question of elections. In that great case Reynolds v. Sims-it was a slightly different context from the one we are talking about here, but it is quite pertinent to what we say-Earl Warren said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe-
he is talking on behalf of the Supreme Court judges of the United States of America-

that the concept of bicameralism is rendered anachronistic and meaningless when the predominant basis of representation of the two state legislative bodies is required to be the same-population. A prime reason for bicameralism, modernly considered, is to ensure mature and deliberate consideration of, and to prevent precipitate action on, proposed legislative measures. Simply because the controlling criterion for apportioning representation is required to be the same in both houses does not mean that there will be no differences in the composition and complexion of the two bodies.

That is so. Even if these two Houses are elected at the same time, they will reflect a different constituency. That is made quite clear by the presence here of the renowned leader of the Democratic Labor Party sitting in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?
—I am sorry; the Australian Democrats. I withdraw very rapidly `Democratic Labor Party'.
—If only you had been correct.

—That is right, from the honourable senator's point of view. Clearly, the different constituencies and the different methods of electing people throw up different kinds of representatives. The great illustration of that is that the present chamber was elected at the same time as the House of Representatives was elected as was the previous one. It was in the circumstance of all members of parliament being elected at the one time that we saw those victories, as honourable senators opposite see them, in regard to the Australia Card and other legislation that has come in here. Simply, evidence indicates that the election of the two Houses at the same time does not make the Senate a rubber stamp. In fact, the evidence proves quite the contrary. Both the Bill of Rights and the Australia Card are evidence that two Houses elected at the same time can produce a difference in what they do.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the amendment circulated in my name:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 1, Title, leave out all words after ``Constitution'', insert ``to increase the terms of members of the House of Representatives from a maximum of 3 years to a maximum of 4 years, to reduce the terms of Senators from a fixed 6 years to a maximum of 4 years, to require simultaneous elections for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament, and to abolish the system whereby half the Senators retire every three years''.

I have only a brief chance to introduce this but it is a very critical amendment as far as the Opposition is concerned. It proposes to substitute for the present long title of the Bill the long title which I have just read out. The significance of that is that it is the long title of the Act passed through this Parliament which is put before the people of Australia in the referendum proposal. Therefore, this proposed amendment goes to precisely what question would be put to the people of Australia in that referendum. I will address the Committee at length later on that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

—I think what I said is that it is probably silly, but a lot of things we do here are probably silly. The Senate does some probably silly things; everybody does. No policies are perfect. I do not have to explain that view at any great length, and I do not propose to. It is not a matter which relates to my ministerial responsibility.
