—What I do at the National Conference of the Australian Labor Party is essentially my business and not the business of the Senate.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to corporate plan No. 10 of the Australian National Railways Commission. Has the Minister noted Australian National's strategy to upgrade and standardise the Adelaide to Melbourne rail corridor and its tactics to justify special funding for that rail corridor? What barriers currently exist to the standardisation of the Adelaide to Melbourne railway and what is the apparent position of the Victorian railways on this important national question?
—I am not sure whether I have a brief on this particular question. I will check it out and give Senator Maguire an answer before the end of Question Time.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Further to Senator Chaney's question, I ask: Is it a fact that the uranium paper prepared at the Minister's direction recommends Australia should allow additional exports to meet growing market demand and that preference should be given to new operators who are prepared to work towards adding maximum value to the ore? Does it further recommend that research into uranium enrichment should be allowed to proceed and, if successful, the Government should allow the export of enriched uranium and fabricated fuel rods? Does the Minister agree with those recommendations?
—The paper to which Senator Parer refers does not recommend any of those things.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask whether the Minister is correctly quoted in yesterday's Age when in the context of the uranium debate he is reported as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: If we are going to send any mineral out of Australia we might as well add as much value as possible.

If so, what action will the Minister take either within Cabinet and Caucus or within the wider forums of the Australian Labor Party, such as next week's National Conference, to apply that criterion to the uranium industry? Does the Minister agree that the longer Australia delays uranium enrichment the harder it will be to get into markets as overseas plants will become even more entrenched?

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I agree with the first part of Senator Parer's supplementary question; that is to say, I share the view that as far as possible value should be added to Australia's minerals by further processing in order that this country might obtain the considerable benefit of that. Whether it is appropriate in respect of any particular industry depends on what technology is available in terms of that process. For example, while the Northern Territory Government has suggested some figures on uranium enrichment involving enormous investment I think those figures must be predicated on the assumption of conventional enrichment technology.
—Laser technology?
—No, conventional enrichment technology. If there is available technology at the right price and so on, I certainly would favour that development.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister noted advice of the Soviet Union's unqualified ratification of protocols 2 and 3 to the Treaty of Rarotonga? What are the implications of this ratification and what indications are there of other nuclear weapons states following the example set by the People's Republic of China and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics?

—The Australian Government has welcomed the advice received on 20 May of the Soviet Union's unqualified ratification of protocols 2 and 3 to the Treaty of Rarotonga. That ratification took effect on 21 April 1988 when the Soviet Union's instrument of ratification was lodged with the treaty's depository, the Director of the South Pacific Bureau for Economic Cooperation. The Soviet Union declared on ratification its intention of fully complying with its obligations under protocols 2 and 3 and did not condition its ratification by the statement it made at the time of signature. This takes account of views expressed by Australia and other South Pacific Forum countries. By ratifying the protocols without qualification the Soviet Union has accepted binding undertakings not to use or threaten to use any nuclear explosive device against parties to the treaty and not to test any nuclear explosive device anywhere within the South Pacific nuclear free zone.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of the growing evidence of harm to the aquatic environment from anti-fouling paints containing organic tin compounds, particularly tributyl tin or TBT? Is the Minister aware of the restrictions which many countries have placed on the use of TBT? What steps is the Minister taking to ensure that TBT use is controlled in Australia before significant and long-term damage is done to aquatic life forms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of evidence of harm to the aquatic environment from TBT, contained in anti-fouling paints. These paints are widely used on ships, pleasure craft and the like--
—Things that float in the water.

—That is correct; that sort of thing. They are used to prevent aquatic organisms encrusting them and causing damage. We can have no barnacles. It is reportedly more effective than other anti-fouling agents so it is considered to be important. However the amount of TBT in some new paints and the use of these paints have grown considerably in recent times. I have been informed that restrictions have been placed on the use of TBT in paints in France and the United Kingdom. I have also been informed that Federal controls are proposed in the United States and that some of the American States have themselves instituted controls. There has been some scientific work on the question in Australia already. There was, I think, a workshop in Lismore in February and a substantial study has just been completed by the New South Wales State Pollution Control Commission. My Department has now taken an active interest in the question. I am pleased that the recent agreement on the use of these paints is shortly to restrict their use, through State pesticide regulations, to formulations providing for the slow release of TBT into the water. Whether or not this is the complete answer will be determined by the monitoring of the problem areas where there are obviously, as Senator Puplick would say, large numbers of things that float in the water. That will be undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: So it is not simply a matter of banning TBT paints; there is evidence that the available alternatives can also present some environmental problems. This is a problem that we will have to monitor carefully over the next 12 months. I am not sure that the cure will be better than the disease, but we will monitor the situation to see what effects the cure has. If Senator Coulter were to ask the question again early in the new year, we might have a better and more complete answer for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am a little surprised at the Minister's reply in relation to slow release paints. The Minister should know that the function of anti-fouling paints is precisely to release toxic substances slowly into water. If they released those substances quickly, they would not be very effective as anti-fouling paints. I ask again whether the Minister will move further to restrict the use of TBT, which has been shown to be a lot more toxic than the conventional paints.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I made myself clear in what I said the first time, but I said that I was pleased that by State regulation we would be looking at those formulations with the slow release formulas of which Senator Coulter has spoken. I agree with him. That is obviously the area of concern and that is what we are getting agreement on for State regulations. So we are on the same tack. I hope the honourable senator is not surprised by the answer to his supplementary question. It must be that my original answer was inadequate. If that is the case, I apologise.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I draw his attention to reports in the media about the failure of three prominent builders in New South Wales. These bankruptcies have led to 275 families having unbuilt or partly built homes. Will the Commonwealth encourage State governments, and legislate itself in areas of its jurisdiction, first to limit the deposit required by a builder to a maximum figure as suggested by the Master Builders Association of New South Wales, and, secondly, to look more closely at the equity of builders at the time of licence application or renewals to prevent such occurrences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I make the point that traditionally the regulation of the building--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask whether this matter is not one which lies within the State jurisdiction, outside the jurisdiction of the Minister. Therefore, I query whether the question is in order.
—On the point of order, Mr President: if Senator Chaney were somewhat patient, I could link the State response to a Federal response and we would all be satisfied.

—Mr President, I do not wish to obstruct a proper question. I simply raise the point that there appears to be no Commonwealth involvement in this matter. If the Minister can tell us where his portfolio impinges on this matter, the question may well be in order; but I raise the point of order. I do not think the Minister has given us any information which would entitle the question to be ruled in order.
—I will allow Senator Bolkus to answer the question.

—Thank you, Mr President. The first point I was going to make before Senator Chaney rose was that traditionally this sort of problem relating to the building industry, particularly the whole question of licensing, comes within the responsibility of State and Territory governments. To take that one step further, for some time all members of the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers, or SCOCAM, have had this item on their agenda. Ministers have been concerned to ensure that there is adequate protection for consumers in an area such as this, where there are many pitfalls in domestic home building. SCOCAM has supported the establishment and development of a standard form contract for domestic home building and extensions. The Ministers have had it under consideration for some time. One of the aspects of SCOCAM's considerations in this area has been the whole question of deposits. SCOCAM Ministers have recognised that deposits are a very important element of any standardised approach in this area by State and Federal Ministers.

ANSWER.PARA: The next meeting of SCOCAM will be held in mid-July in Melbourne. I will be approaching my State colleagues with a view to seeing whether we can develop, one step further, a system of a uniform response to problems caused by building bankruptcies but noting at the same time that while the Federal Government will be involved to the extent of trying to obtain uniformity and protection, we do not anticipate that we will be taking any further action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Resources confirm that the entire production from the Koongarra uranium deposit in the Northern Territory, the development of which has been stopped by Labor's silly three-mine uranium policy, has been sold to Japan and Canada and that the 32 million pounds of uranium oxide contracted for sale will produce about $2 billion over the next 10 years? Is it further a fact that these sales have been negotiated at levels above the current floor price and that the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, was very high in praise of the agreement between Denison Australia and the traditional Aboriginal owners? What will be the cost to Australia in terms of lost jobs and lost investment if this project remains stalled by Labor policy? What will be the direct loss to Commonwealth and Northern Territory Government revenues? Finally, what will Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory lose if the Labor conference next week refuses to change the existing policy?

—There were several parts to that question, the first asking me to confirm the existence of contracts between Koongarra and other overseas purchasing agencies, the names of which I think the honourable senator gave. I cannot confirm that. I have not seen a contract, but since this matter falls within the responsibility of the portfolio Minister, Mr John Kerin, and is not my direct portfolio responsibility, I will put that question on notice and get back to Senator Tambling.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am somewhat surprised that a Minister for Resources in this place would seek to sidetrack an issue of this nature to another Minister. It seems that Ministers at the table today are very reluctant to enter into any discussion with regard to uranium. My supplementary question is as follows: Has the Minister had discussions with the executives of Denison and Koongarra? Have they made him aware of the issues raised in my initial question, and is it a fact that some $250m will not flow to Aboriginal people if the Koongarra project does not proceed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that when the supplementary question is asked we find out the answers that the honourable senator wanted to elicit to the primary question. I wonder whether that is regarded as an abuse of Question Time. The arguments that the honourable senator has put seem to be the answers that he is asking me to give him. It begs this question from me: If he knew the answer in the first place, why did he ask the question? In terms of what was, frankly, his gratuitous observation, he may well be wishing to pursue a political point, but he may well also be ignorant. On the assumption that the latter and not the former is the case, he is not aware of the division of responsibilities between me and the portfolio Minister, Mr Kerin. If the honourable senator was aware of the division of responsibilities between us both he would know, as he is actually obliged to find out I would suggest, that Mr Kerin has the responsibility for coal and nuclear matters in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked whether I had met with executives from Denison. Over the last few weeks, in fact ever since I took over this portfolio, I have met representatives of a number of companies, some of whom were uranium miners, some of whom aspired to be uranium miners, and some of whom wanted to open new mines. I do not actually recall meeting with people from Denison. It might be that I did.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators opposite will allow me to finish the answer, I do not actually recall meeting with them. I do know that they were seeking to meet me and I do know that I have no objection to meeting them and in fact would like to meet them. On that basis, I cannot confirm any information that the honourable senator wishes to confirm with me. If he really wants an answer to the question, perhaps he should wait another week.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.
—He is finding the answer.

—Is the Minister aware of an article in last week's Australian Financial Review which claims that the Government's new anti-dumping legislation could contain a loophole that would allow importers to avoid anti-dumping rulings simply by changing source countries? Could the Minister comment on that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer has already pointed out that I had the answer out before the question was finished. That is a stunningly acute observation for Senator Archer and I congratulate him. That is perfectly true; that is called expedition. That is what we call it in this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I am well aware of the article in question. It was drawn to my attention on several occasions. The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act already provides facility for the retroactive application of dumping duties consistent with our treaty obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade anti-dumping code in circumstances where it can be shown that the importer knew or should have known that the imports, including resources imports, were at dumped prices and that material injury to an Australian industry would result. Secondly, where a dumping notice exists in relation to imports from one country, the resourcing of those imports does not really provide an opportunity to circumvent the effectiveness of the anti-dumping code. As dumping duties would already apply to these goods exported from one or more sources, the authorities would be in possession of current and detailed information on the industry, the injury caused to it by those imports and the price level at which the injury was caused.

In those circumstances it would be relatively easy for the authorities to establish whether a new source of imports at a particular price level could contribute to that injury. This would leave to be established only the matter as to whether the goods were at dumped prices and the Australian industry would have to provide sufficient evidence of this to enable the Australian Customs Service to require the exporter to provide information on domestic prices and costs. The provisions of the anti-dumping code could be imposed on imports to Australia in the period prior to the date of a finding of dumping.

In summary, this has always been an endemic problem in dumping complaints, but I think the arrangements in the proposed legislation are sufficiently flexible to cope with the situation which the honourable senator described in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Has the Minister noted the attack on the traditional Aboriginal owners of the Koongarra uranium deposit by the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Hogg, who suggested that, in campaigning for the Government to change its policy and allow development of the Koongarra uranium mine, these people are being manipulated? Will the Minister agree that such a slur is appropriately described as `undiluted racism of the worst kind'?

—I would not adopt that sort of description of statements that may have been made. I have heard some reports along those lines, but I certainly would not wish to attach that particular description to second-hand reports that I may have come across quite accidentally. I do believe it is important that Aboriginal people in their communities be given the dignity which is their due, and indeed the Government's proposals in relation to the self-determination and self-management of Aboriginal communities are designed to foster and recognise that very desirable objective.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I regret that the Minister does not have the courage, as his colleague Senator Collins did yesterday, publicly to denounce Mr Hogg and dissociate the Government from his deplorable comments. I ask: Will the Minister at least endorse the right of the Aboriginal people concerned to organise a campaign and to engage professional help in support of a case they believe will benefit their community, which if successful would certainly also benefit the whole Australian community, and that they should be able to do so free of accusations from whatever quarter, including the Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, of manipulation or that they are parties to what Mr Hogg calls a very cynical exercise?

—I believe any group of Australians ought to be able to organise themselves in order to lobby, whether it be in the political arena or in relation to something to do with their particular material and financial well-being. In so far as this particular group of Aboriginals wishes to embark on that course, I believe it is entirely proper, but whether I think it is proper or not, it is obviously part of that self-management and self-determination which I believe Aboriginal communities are quite rightly asserting.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister seen a handbill on which Ansett Airlines of Australia advertises a `new direct service from Canberra to the Gold Coast'? Does this so-called direct service in fact call at Williamstown and Brisbane before arriving at Coolangatta Airport on the Gold Coast? Would the Minister remind Ansett that it should not distribute misleading advertising to entice the public to use its services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in fact seen the handbill advertising the direct service from Canberra to the Gold Coast and, like Senator Colston, most senators probably would respond quite warmly to the prospect of direct flights to their home base. There is also one direct service from Canberra to Brisbane mentioned in another part of the Ansett advertisement package. I suppose also like Senator Colston that, despite the early enthusiasm of seeing these sorts of things, when one discovers that it takes four hours to get from Canberra to Coolangatta one wonders about the directness of the flight.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the matter has been brought to my attention by Senator Colston I have had the opportunity to have a close look at it. I gather that the practice that Ansett follows here, describing this as a direct service, is regarded by Ansett as being in accordance with industry practice. However, I think there may be an aspect of consumers being misled by the approach taken by the advertisement. Of course misleading advertising comes within the ambit of the Trade Practices Act, particularly section 52 thereof. As Senator Colston has asked me to get in touch with Ansett I will do so with a view to seeing whether we can have the advertisement changed. A more beneficial result would be to have a more direct service from Canberra to Brisbane. In the first instance I will be taking up this matter with the Trade Practices Commission to ascertain whether we can have this particular misleading advertisement rectified.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Can the Minister confirm that all environmental conditions for the development of the Koongarra uranium project have been met? Can the Minister also confirm, as reported in today's Melbourne Age newspaper, that he told Senator Bob Collins last night that he agreed 100 per cent with the senator's speech in reply to the attack by Mr Bob Hogg on the Aboriginal traditional owners of the Koongarra project, that he told Senator Collins it was a great speech, that he agreed with it 100 per cent and that he would be quite happy to go on the public record? If so, will he now formally do what Senator Tate would not do-dissociate himself and the Government from Mr Hogg's derogatory comments about the reasons why the people of that area are pushing for a change to the Government's uranium policy, comments which his colleague Senator Collins rightly described in his speech last night as `undiluted racism of the worst kind'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —As to whether or not Koongarra has been cleared of all environmental problems in respect of a mining operation, I do not know. I doubt very much whether, as yet, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has done enough studies to say that conclusively. However--
—You had better check that.

—Slow down; my general view has been that I believe that uranium mining could be carried out safely at Koongarra, as it has been at Ranger where damage to the environment has been minimal. This is because a very strict regime was set up at Ranger which was monitored by the Office of the Supervising Scientist and, I believe, monitored successfully. However, that is not really the point at issue in Senator Puplick's question, I was asked whether or not I would dissociate myself and the Government from Mr Hogg's comments. I would never presume to dissociate the Government from anything. I do not speak for the Government; I am but a humble Minister. I do not know that my personal view on anything would dissociate the Government from it. However, given that I was prepared to make a doorstop comment this morning I will repeat the comment here: I said this morning that I would have thought that Mr Hogg's comments were more appropriate to Bruce Ruxton than they were to the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party. I stand by that.

—Did the Minister representing the Treasurer see an article on the front page of Sunday's Sun-Herald which claimed that because the fringe benefits tax (FBT) rate has been retained at 49c, when compared with the new corporate tax rate of 39c, employees will lose valuable fringe benefits? Why has the Government not lowered the fringe benefits tax rate to 39c in the dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article and I regret to say that it is completely wrong. The purpose of the fringe benefits tax (FBT) is to ensure that when an employer pays an employee in kind rather than money, the remuneration is subject to an appropriate rate of tax. So FBT is directed at the remuneration of employees. Therefore, it is clearly the personal tax rates scale that is pertinent and not the rate of company tax. For convenience, the rate that has been struck for FBT is the maximum personal rate, less only the Medicare levy, the reason being that almost all those who receive significant fringe benefits associated with employment are in the income tranche that attracts the maximum marginal rate. Leaving it at a single rate helps to keep it administratively simple.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very complicated to explain why the article is wrong. Fringe benefits, to a quite minor degree, become more attractive at the time that the maximum personal tax rate is higher than the corporate tax rate. That makes fringe benefits marginally more attractive, but not a great deal more attractive, to an employer and, possibly, an employee, if they decide to split the difference between them. Even if the article were true, the option of cashing out fringe benefits is always available, and indeed that is an option which I have always favoured and which the Government has not been opposed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. It concerns the Minister's address to the Sturt Australian Labor Party Federal Electorate Council (FEC) in Adelaide on Sunday. In particular I refer to his comments that, as a result of the tariff cuts announced last week, and taking into account the treatment of the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) and passenger motor vehicle (PMV) industries, `Shirts and blouses will be reduced in price by 48 per cent', `a car such as a Mazda 323 would be 13 per cent cheaper' and `footwear should be reduced in price by 10 per cent'. How does the Minister account for the saving on a new Mazda of over $3,000, and how does he justify expecting massive falls in prices in the TCF industry, given that no major tariff reductions were announced to the passenger motor vehicle and textiles, clothing and footwear industries last week? Has the Minister been advised by Senator Button of further tariff cuts which are in the pipeline but as yet unannounced? If not, will the Minister withdraw his comments, given the criticism in the last 24 hours from the Australian Retailers Association (ARA), which predicted that, on the contrary, the price of many clothing and footwear items would increase by 12 to 15 per cent by the end of 1989, from the Confederation of Australian Industry and from the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Industry Council of Australia? Finally, will the Trade Practices Commission be investigating the Minister's own shonky attempts to sell last week's tariff changes to the general public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate and government in this country would be better served if Senator Lewis were to read the speech and quote from it accurately. In the interests of doing so, I will quote from the speech I made on Sunday to the Sturt FEC:

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the Government and the trade union movement can work together to ensure that labour market adjustments flowing from tariff cuts phased in over four years will be manageable.
I went on to say:

It is also important to note here that the textile, clothing and footwear sector, the steel industry and the motor vehicle manufacturers, all of which operate under existing plans, are not subject to the same kind of rapid change.

It is quite clear that what I was referring to was not immediate cuts in these areas, but cuts over the announced period of reductions in tariffs. That point came out of the speech. It is obviously a speech that Opposition senators have not read.

TALK.START.PARA: —You really are a fraud.
—On a point of order, Mr President, I ask that Senator Walters withdraw that remark.
—Order! I heard the interjection--
—I withdraw.
—I ask Senator Walters to withdraw.
—I have already done so, Mr President.
—I call Senator Bolkus.

—In the interests of my relationship with Senator Walters, I am glad that I did not hear her interjection. I went on to say-I raise this to inform Senator Lewis even further-that the decreases were based on domestic price increases as well. I said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . if domestically produced goods are reduced in price by amounts corresponding to the effect these measures should have on imported goods, the purchasing power of households should increase significantly.
Another contingency I mentioned, among others, was:
These falls do, of course, depend on the effects of tariff reductions being passed through entirely to retail prices.

There is no getting away from the fact that the Government's purpose in making these changes is twofold: obviously the most important aspect of it is to make Australian industry more competitive and, secondly, we want to do so in a planned, comprehensive way. Industry cannot have it both ways. It cannot, on the one hand, have decreased prices and strive for competition and, on the other, claim to keep its prices at the same real value as they were before tariffs were cut. The thrust of my statement on Sunday was that I would instruct the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) to monitor prices in the affected areas as a priority project. It is an ongoing project because, as will be clearly understood by those who read the speech, tariff reductions are, in the main, being phased in over a period-some over four years and, for TCF, seven years.

Senator Lewis referred to the ARA statement. The ARA talked about one step in the overall change. What industry should be talking about and addressing its mind to is the cumulative effect of the tariff changes, not just what the next step along the track should be. The ARA's allegations were based on the early stages of the plan. If one looks at the plan in its entirety, one sees that the notional figures are subject to the following contingencies which I mentioned accurately in my speech: time lags, the movements in production inputs, inflationary movements, and so on. The basic point that I made in my speech on Sunday is that prices should be reduced by the end of the periods in which the tariffs are reduced.

The Government's primary concern is that we are committed to ensuring that the maximum possible benefits flow from tariff reductions to consumers. I said on Sunday, in my capacity as Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices, that I am particularly interested in these measures as they should have significant benefits for consumers, especially low income earners. Senator Lewis mentioned the ARA. I do not think that he mentioned the Confederation of Australian Industry. Its Press statement was hardly worth responding to. It shows the Australian community that some sections of Australian industry-and I stress the word `some'-are afraid of the challenges involved in this sort of reassessment. The announcement that I made on Sunday, very specifically, was that the PSA would be charged with the responsibility of monitoring this flow-through to consumers. This is not a new form of government regulation. It is basically a case of the Government once again acting in the interests of consumers. I contend that the Opposition does not spend much time in doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, I ask the Minister to table the papers from which he quoted. I refer, secondly, to reported statements by the Minister-for example, that for low income families, it is calculated that these proposed price cuts and savings would be equal to a pre-tax wage increase of 3 per cent and for high income families the equivalent of a wage rise of 2 per cent. Is that what the Minister says will happen at the end of a period of about five years rather than what will happen in the immediate future?

—The answer to the first part of the question is no. The answer to the second part of the question is that the figures contained in my speech-I will gladly give Senator Lewis a copy of the speech-are based on the contingencies mentioned in the speech over the period of introduction of the plans and the reduction in tariffs, as announced by the Government.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. What is the basis upon which the Minister can decline to table a document from which he has quoted?
—A point of pomposity, not a point of order.

—I am always prepared to be lectured by the expert on the subject. The Minister can hardly claim that the document is a confidential document, since it is the text of a public address. He has had three pages or so of typed material in front of him from which he has read the answer to the question. He cannot say that it is a confidential document, since the parts that he has quoted in his answer form part of a publicly available document. Under those circumstances I believe that he should be required to table the material from which he has read.

—Standing order 363 really applies to a motion that documents be tabled. The convention is that the Minister can either table a document from which he has quoted or he can say that they are his own notes or part of his own speech and therefore not table them. Senator Bolkus chose not to table them.

—My question is directed to Senator Walsh, in his capacity as both the Minister for Finance and the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen an article in the Sunday Telegraph which referred to calls by business groups for a consumption tax? Is it true that a consumption tax will be necessary to finance a significant round of reductions in personal income tax rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article in the Sunday Telegraph. The Sydney Sunday papers must have excelled themselves last week. The same assertion was also made, somewhat more surprisingly, by an official or executive from the Arthur Young company, a firm of accountants, in a broadcast by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), at least in Brisbane, on Friday morning. The officer from Arthur Young said that a consumption tax was implicit in the May statement because it was not possible to finance income tax cuts without a consumption tax. Of course, this Government will not finance tax cuts by printing money, which the Opposition did when it was in government and which it would do if it ever returned to government. The reason why tax cuts can be afforded is that we have had two years of negative real growth.
—You have a lot of bracket creep.

—I am coming to that, Senator. We will have another two years of negative real growth. Even if one abstracts from assets sales, over that four-year period there will be zero real growth in Commonwealth outlays. If, during that same period, gross domestic product (GDP) grows at 3 per cent per year-on present indications that would seem to be, if anything, a conservative assumption-and if there are zero real outlays growth and zero inflation, Commonwealth revenue will increase by between $1.5 billion and $1.8 billion a year. It would do so for this reason: it is possible to quibble about as much as the last $10 billion, but upwards of $60 billion of Commonwealth revenue will grow proportionately to GDP. Personal income taxes, most sales taxes, excises-excluding the crude oil excise-can be expected to yield revenue or increase revenue proportional to the growth in gross domestic product.

ANSWER.PARA: It follows, if one takes a figure of $50 billion as the lower estimate or $60 billion as the higher estimate, with GDP growth of 3 per cent, that taxation revenue would grow by $1 1/2 billion to $1.8 billion per year. It has nothing to do with fiscal drag. It would accrue entirely because of growth in the economy. When one looks at the other side of the equation, the outlays side of the equation, and sees that outlays are being held at zero real growth over a four-year period, it becomes obvious that $6 billion to $7 billion is available over a four-year period for reductions in taxation, reductions in the Budget deficit in the early stages or additions to the Budget surplus in the later stages of that process. The effect of this is still coming through, to some extent. The base broadening measures which this Government first embarked upon nearly three years ago are increasing the income tax base as well as the increase in revenue attributable to economic growth.

So the tax cuts can be afforded for those reasons. I will be as honest as Senator Stone was last Thursday when we appeared on an ABC program together. Over and above that factor, of course, what is commonly known as fiscal drag is increasing revenue further. That will also be available.

TALK.START.PARA: —So if you cut your own spending you can really cut taxes.

—If Senator Stone's Party was a bit more specific about where spending should be cut, I might have a bit more respect for it. Indeed, if the Opposition was at all specific about where expenditure should be cut, I would have some respect for it which I do not have now. All I am aware of are the various promises that Senator Stone and his colleagues have made, not to reduce expenditure but to increase it. For example, let me refer to a list which is by no means exhaustive. The abolition of the assets test would cost between $300m and $500m, and the figure would grow over time. The construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway would cost $700m. Mr White has said that the Opposition, in government, would have an aircraft carrier. That would cost $2 billion to $3 billion. He also said that it would have half a dozen nuclear submarines. That would cost another few billion dollars. Senator Stone's Party colleague the honourable member for Gilmore said that the petroleum product freight subsidy scheme should be resurrected. That would cost another $160m.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is clearly debating the question. He has moved beyond his normal, well-modulated and calm presentation to his raving mode, which usually means that he is debating the question.
—Have you finished, Senator Walsh?

—Not quite, Mr President. Senator Chaney probably had a valid point of order for once. I was provoked by Senator Stone into giving a few details of the humbug and irresponsibility of the Opposition. The plain fact is that the tax cuts that have been forecast by the Treasurer can be delivered without pushing the Budget back into massive deficits-as Mr Howard used to do when he was Treasurer-increasing the intensity of personal taxation or introducing a broad-based consumption tax.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is it a fact that the present tax on superannuation lump sum payments of 15 per cent and 30 per cent applies only to that portion of the lump sum accumulated after 30 June 1983, while that portion accumulated before that date is taxed at only 5 per cent? Is it also a fact that under the new provisions announced in the May economic statement, the proposed income tax on superannuation fund earnings will apply to the earnings of the total fund and not just that portion of the fund accumulated after 30 June 1983? If this is the case, does the Minister agree that this change in taxation is therefore not just a change in timing of tax receipts, as claimed by the Treasurer, but also effectively an increase in tax, thereby reducing the final benefits available to superannuants? To ensure that the final benefits obtained by superannuants will not be less under the new scheme than under the old, will the Government change its announced policy to ensure that only the income of that portion of the fund accumulated from contributions after 30 June 1983 is subject to the new tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Towards the end of that diatribe I was asked whether the changes constitute an increase in taxation on superannuation. The answer is no. I was asked whether the Government would change the policy and the answer to that is also no. I will deal firstly with what Senator Chapman said in the early part of his question, that accumulations post-1983 only are subject to the 15 per cent and 30 per cent lump sum taxation. That is not quite correct. For taxation purposes, the period before and after 1983 over which the contributions are invested is notionally taken as the fraction to which the higher lump sum tax will apply, which is not the same thing as the accumulation of the benefits at any given point of time. In other words, the tax treatment of the lump sum is more concessional than had it been applied to the straight accumulation in a fund from May or June of 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the changes in the lump sum tax proposed are in fact mildly concessional. The cut-in point-previously $55,000 taxed at 16 1/4 per cent, because the Medicare levy was applied to it as well-has been reduced to $60,000. The rate of tax both before and after the $60,000 threshold has been reduced. The effect of those changes is likewise mildly concessionary. The revenue which would ultimately have been yielded by the tax on lump sums at the end of the investment has been not entirely but almost entirely replaced by the effect of the decision to tax the contributions of employers into funds in the beginning. The major point of Senator Chapman's question was of course the taxation of earnings within the fund. I am surprised that he did not follow the example set by his Liberal Party colleague in the House of Representatives, Mr Chapman, whom I saw on television on Sunday night--
Honourable senators-Connolly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am sorry about that. They are all so inconsequential it is difficult to remember who is who. I expect that he waved page 45 of the Treasury document around to show that there was a line which said existing superannuation benefit $88,120 and proposed superannuation benefit $86,358-a difference of about $1,800 or 2 per cent-which, according to Mr Connolly, would have made superannuation absolutely unattractive and would have been the end of the superannuation industry. Even if that were true, which it was not-I will come to that in a moment-it was a ridiculous conclusion to reach and the sort of conclusion I would expect Mr Connolly and all the other undistinguished members of the Opposition to reach. Of course it is not true because if the document is read properly it can be seen that that table is based on the assumption that there will be no change in the existing distribution of investments by superannuation funds.

ANSWER.PARA: In the past a massive distortion through the tax system affected the behaviour of managers of superannuation funds. The massive distortion was that if they received income as interest or rent it was tax free; if they received income as dividends from equity investments tax was paid by the company in which the profits were earned and tax, until quite recently, could have been paid by the recipients of the dividends when there was a distribution. That unequal playing field was a massive distortion which affected the behaviour of rational fund investors. So of course they tended to invest their money so that it would yield income in the form of rent or interest instead of profits from business enterprises, from equity holdings. That massive distortion has now been removed. I suppose it is difficult for Opposition members to understand this, but as a result of the removal of that gross distortion on the behaviour of fund managers, rational fund managers will change their investment policies.

I heard Mr Willett, the Chairman of what is said to be-as far as I know it is true-the largest superannuation fund in Australia, the Commonwealth Government's employees fund, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT), on Monday morning saying that previously SFIT did not take into account after tax yields, nor did superannuation fund managers in general. Now they will have to take into account after tax yields. When super funds get a proper mix of equity investments, including investments in companies which pay franked dividends-tax on fund earnings will be exempt from the 15 per cent tax-the funds will come back to the sort of position they are in now as far as their tax liabilities are concerned, but the massive distortion on their investment policies will no longer be there. They will make their decisions about investments and where to put their funds in accordance with normal and rational assessments of what is and what is not a good investment-not something which is a tax haven compared with something which is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. From what the Minister has said I take it that unless superannuation funds invest all of their funds in companies that provide dividend imputation, the import of my question is true, that the taxation paid by superannuation funds will be higher under this changed arrangement than it would have been under the old arrangement. Therefore, the benefits to superannuants in the long run will be lower.
—It would appear that Senator Chapman is deaf as well.
—You just don't understand it.

—Tell us about the free boozy lunch, Tony-that is your specialty. Tell us about how many tens of thousands of jobs you said would be lost in restaurants if the free boozy lunch was cut out. Senator Chapman asked whether I said that unless they put all their investments into equity investments that yield franked dividends they would have to pay tax. No, I did not say that at all. I said that they could avoid paying the tax by having a proper mix of equity and other investments without having their decision about that mix of investments distorted by the previously unequal taxation system within which those investments were made.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May Senator Powell asked me a question relating to the number of women pilots employed by Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. I undertook to provide her with an answer which I now seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Australian Airlines employs one female pilot. It should be noted however, that there has only been one pilot intake program conducted by Australian since 1981. All pilots whether male or female are governed by the same employment conditions, there is no specific policy pertaining to women. Generally women are now much more identifiable in the airline's workforce, particularly in the middle and senior management areas. Australian has also increased the number of women in the trade and technical areas.

Qantas Airlines currently employs six women pilots and has one in training. Qantas does not have a specific policy relating to women pilots, but does have an Equal Employment Opportunity policy and will assist women to compete on an equal basis where possible. Qantas is further examining ways of encouraging more applications from women pilots.

Ansett Airlines employs four women pilots, one of which has recently become a Captain. Ansett has an Affirmative Action Program and actively encourages applications from women for all positions in the company. However, Ansett has not advertised for pilots for some time due to the large number of direct applications for pilot positions.
I am satisfied with the progress to date within the airlines on the employment of women in the whole range of positions available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday in Question Time Senator Walters asked me about the operation of a tax file number in relation to the Department of Social Security. I now have the following information from the Minister for Social Security:

ANSWER.PARA: TAXATION FILE NUMBER AND SOCIAL SECURITY

The Treasurer announced in the recent Economic Statement that the Taxation Office had been given the go ahead to develop a system for making greater use of tax file numbers in its normal administration.
He emphasised that at no time will people be required to produce a tax file number as a form of personal identification.
There has been an impression created by some media articles that the taxation file number will be a pre-requisite for eligibility for social security assistance. That is not correct.

Unemployment, sickness and special benefits and job search allowance payments made by the Department of Social Security are taxable. These payments are regarded as salary or wages for taxation purposes.
Consequently, the Department of Social Security is required to deduct tax from these fortnightly payments the same as employers.

When clients apply for these payments they are asked to fill in an Income Tax Instalment Declaration Form. In most cases clients indicate that they are entitled to claim the taxation general exemption. Because of the amount of their fortnightly social security payment and their entitlement to tax rebates, no tax is deducted each fortnight.
If clients do not fill in an Income Tax Instalment Declaration Form, the Department is required to tax each payment at 29 cents in the dollar.

At present there are 548,000 persons receiving payments who have filled in an Income Tax Instalment Declaration Form. Of these, 30,500 are having tax instalments deducted from their fortnightly payments and 517,600 are not because of the general tax exemption which applies.

There are also 29,100 persons receiving fortnightly unemployment, sickness and special benefit and job search allowance payments who have not filled in an Income Tax Instalment Declaration Form. Tax is being deducted from those payments at the rate of 29 cents in the dollar.
The taxation deductions are forwarded to the Australian Taxation Office on a monthly basis.
At the end of each financial year the payments made to each person are shown on a group certificate or statement of earnings which is given to the client for inclusion in their income tax return.

The taxation file number proposal, announced by the Treasurer, means that the Department of Social Security will have to include the client's taxation file number on his or her group certificate or statement of earnings. As I have said, this certificate or statement is already provided by the Department to the client. The proposal means one further piece of information will be added.

Consequently the Department of Social Security will need to ask clients for their taxation file number when they apply for assistance. If they do not give it the social security payment will be made, provided of course, that the person is eligible. However, the Department will be required to deduct tax from the payment at the highest marginal rate.
This is exactly the same administrative arrangement between the Department of Social Security and the Australian Tax Office as currently applies, which I have already detailed.

The system begins on 1 November 1988. From that date each new applicant for the social security payments in question will be asked to write his or her taxation file number on the Income Tax Instalment Declaration Form filled out as part of the claim process.

I emphasise that the proposed system is for taxation, not social security, purposes. The important point is that unemployment, sickness and special benefits and job search allowance payments are treated as earnings and cannot be dealt with differently from other payments of this nature as far as taxation aspects are concerned.
I also repeat for benefit of my colleagues that the proposed system will not be used to assess eligibility for social security payments.

At the end of her question last week Senator Walters asked me to table the notes from which I answered a question last week. I have had further requests to do so and I promised that I would do so today. I now table the page from my brief.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Jenkins asked me a question relating to an article from the West Australian of 23 May with the heading `Judge Sets Iranians free'. I responded to part 6 of the honourable senator's question yesterday and undertook to get answers to the other parts. As the response is rather lengthy, I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the response in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-

1. Mr Justice Lee directed the Department to answer a court interrogatory as to what information the Minister or the Department has received regarding the whereabouts and safety of an Iranian who was refused entry into Australia on 4 October 1985. No answer to the interrogatory has been furnished as yet pending enquiries of the Department's overseas offices. I am informed that an examination of the Department's files in Australia concluded that no information was received in relation to the whereabouts and safety of that man since November 1985, other than an allegation by a solicitor contained in an affidavit filed in the very matter now before Mr Justice Lee to the effect that unconfirmed information received by Amnesty International and passed on to her that the man was thereafter persecuted and may have been executed in about 1987. The solicitor added that ``Amnesty is still seeking confirmation of that execution''.

2. An Iranian man, aged 27, arrived in Australia on 4 October 1985 on a Cathay Pacific flight without passport or visa from Hong Kong. He sought refuge in Australia. He disclosed that he posted his passport in Hong Kong to an address in Australia. He arranged for a solicitor to meet the airline.

The man, a professional person belonging to the ruling ethnic and religious group in Iran, based his claim for refuge on an alleged clandestine religious conversion to christianity two years previously.
The man was refused entry into Australia under section 36A of the Migration Act and the airline was required to remove him back to Hong Kong.

The view was taken then that the man was the responsibility of the flag of the carrier and hence was under the protection of the United Kingdom, who was and is a signatory of the convention relating to the status of refugees. Moreover, the first port of destination of the carrier was Hong Kong, which was and is a British territory with facilities for the reception of refugees awaiting resettlement, where the man could press his claim for resettlement as a refugee.
The then acting Minister (Mr Brown) and later, the then Minister (Mr Hurford) confirmed the action taken.
The decisions in that case were the subject of litigation in the federal court, before a single judge and before the full court.

In the outcome, under consent orders made by the Federal Court the minister was required to consider, whilst the man was in Hong Kong, the man's claim for resettlement in Australia as a refugee and the man was also required to seek the protection of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and also to hand over to the Australian authorities his passport.

It was established that the man had applied twice in Iran for a visitor's visa to Australia in late 1984 and early 1985. On both occasions, the applications were rejected. The man then departed Iran on 23 August 1985 for India with an Iranian passport and a valid Indian tourist visa. That visa was later extended to allow him to remain in India until 12 November 1985.

In Bombay, he again applied unsuccessfully for an Australian visitor's visa. He claimed on that occasion that he wished to visit friends in Australia prior to undertaking studies in the Federal Republic of Germany. His passport disclosed a visa to that country issued in Tehran which expired on 29 June 1985.

At no stage, up until so ordered by the court, did the man seek the protection of UNHCR, nor approach an Australian overseas post for resettlement as a refugee, although he had ample opportunity to do either or both before seeking entry into Australia at the airport.

By posting his passport to an address in Sydney ahead of his departure from Hong Kong to Sydney, the man denied the Australian authorities at the airport the opportunity to examine his identity and circumstances, and rendered difficult his deportation if his claims were to be dismissed following his expected entry into Australia. It is common knowledge, that it is difficult to effect the deportation of a person with no travel documentation.
The man's claim of religious conversion was never satisfactorily established.

On 15 October 1985, the then Minister (Mr Hurford) considered the man's application for refugee resettlement in Australia in the light of a detailed submission following interviews with the man in Hong Kong. The then Minister decided to reject the application on credibility and on refugee and immigration policy grounds.
The Minister's decision and supporting document were communicated to the man's solicitors on the same day.
That decision was not challenged, and indeed the original application for review of the decisions relating to refusal of entry was withdrawn by the man's solicitors a week later.

It is understood that the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees did not extend protection to the man under the mandate of that office. Following that decision it appears that the Hong Kong authorities expelled the man back to India, and India in turn returned the man to Iran in November 1985.
3, 4 and 5 The Department and I have no knowledge as to what treatment the man received upon or since his return to Iran from India in 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the debate being adjourned for lunch, I had moved an amendment which seeks to substitute a new long title to the Bill. It is unusual for the Senate to spend much time on the title of a Bill. Usually it does not matter. But the significance of the title of this Bill and of all the Bills which institute constitutional amendments is that what the people of Australia get put before them when they receive a ballot paper is a question which is based upon the long title of the Bill. So people walking into the ballot box, if this Bill remains in its present form and is passed by the Parliament, will be asked whether they approve of:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

It is a very simple proposition which relates to four-year maximum terms and a proposition which may, on the face of it to many Australians, appear attractive. The concern of the Opposition is that that is a thoroughly dishonest question to be posing to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —That concern is not only the Opposition's; it is that of Morgan gallup polls, me--

—I was going on to that. I have some support from Senator Harradine, who is not from the Opposition; he is an independent senator from Tasmania. The concern which we have expressed is reflected by many other observers. As Senator Harradine has said, the Director of the Morgan (Roy) Research Centre Pty Ltd, Mr Gary Morgan, who is probably responsible for asking questions of as many Australians as anybody else in our history, and whose whole profession is involved in phrasing questions so that the opinions of people can be determined, has described these questions as biased to try to obtain a yes response from the voter. Mr Morgan said that any public opinion polling company which asked questions as blatantly biased as the Government proposes, would completely lose its credibility. We raised that matter in the second reading debate and it is a very central concern of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be a very interesting test of the Australian Democrats, because the amendment that we have put forward is not a biased amendment. It picks up some of the elements of substance, all of which have been conceded by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) as being part of the constitutional change which is proposed. Our simple proposition is that the Australian people are entitled to a question on which to vote which will be far more explanatory of the constitutional changes that are being sought by this Government. It is not just Mr Gary Morgan; there have been a whole series of people who have talked about this. I will not quote Ralph Hunt, who put out an excellent Press release, because he is a member of the Opposition. But let me refer again to what Paddy McGuinness had to say. I think all people would regard him as a respected observer on the social, political and economic scene. People might not always agree with him but no-one, I think, has ever accused him of being a political partisan and in some way the property--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is certainly very conservative.

—That comment could come only from Senator Zakharov's corner-or part of the political spectrum because, in many respects, Mr McGuinness has stood up for all sorts of ideals, including the ideal of racial equality. That is one matter which comes to mind. He really applies his mind to society and rights in a very honest and fair way. What does he say? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government is being very dishonest in its approach to the proposed referendum on constitutional amendments.

This is what Mr McGuinness-not some Liberal, not some person who is committed to the Australian Labor Party, the National Party or the Liberal Party-says the question should be. He says it should be phrased in the following term:
Do you agree to weakening the power and status of the Senate?

That is Mr McGuinness's view of the true political import of this constitutional amendment. We are not seeking to word this proposal in a way which is politically biased. We are saying that the people of Australia are entitled to be told frankly what is contained in this Bill. We are suggesting that a proper description of the Bill is that it is a Bill:
to increase the terms of members of the House of Representatives from a maximum of 3 to a maximum of 4 years-
that clearly is the import of the Bill-
to reduce the terms of Senators from a fixed 6 years to a maximum of 4 years-

the point is specifically drawn to the attention of the electors that we are going from a fixed term for the Senate to a maximum term of four years for the Senate; so the point that is nowhere mentioned in the present question is made explicit-
to require simultaneous elections for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament, and to abolish the system whereby half the Senators retire every three years.

We say that they are the essential, mechanical changes which are being made by this proposal. We have not sought to include in our amendment what we believe to be the political or power impact. We have not included argument or emotive words. We have been coldly descriptive in the amendment we are putting forward. I do not know whether the Australian Democrats intend to participate in this debate; they have not to this stage participated in the committee stage debate, but I note that two of them are now in the chamber. I put the very simple question: Do the Democrats agree that the elements of change which are reflected in our amendment are elements which are in the Bill, changes of substance which are to be effected by this constitutional proposal? If the answer to that question is yes, they must in fairness support this proposal because to do otherwise is to risk a fraud upon the people of Australia. That is really what we are looking at-the possibility that a great number of people will simply misunderstand the question that is being put to them because, as Mr McGuinness has said, the questions have not been put in an honest way.

We believe that the Government has set out to mislead in this description and, therefore, that it has set out in a quite fraudulent way to promote this constitutional amendment. I remind the Senate that this has been a quite lengthy committee debate, designed, on the part of the Opposition, simply to draw out the essential and quite major changes which this Bill is making beyond the change of the term, changes which go to the whole structure and framework of the Senate. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that debate and to the fact that Senator Tate, as he had to, conceded the elements of change that we asserted. I will quote a couple of particulars from Senator Tate's speech in the debate last Thursday. In the debate on the early part of the Bill he said:
This provision of the referendum Bill would change the current provision in the Constitution and would change the situation whereby senators have a fixed term . . .

I interpolate: The question, as it is being posed to the Australian people by the Government, does not make that very central point explicit. It may be that it is a necessary implication from the present title; it simply is not made explicit. Senator Tate goes on to say:

. . . a fixed term which they serve unless affected by a double dissolution. In that respect this proposal alters what the framers had envisaged as the way in which the Senate would be composed and would operate as to the terms of the members of the Senate chamber.

I simply say to Senator Tate and to the Australian Democrats-of whose support on this matter I am not sure, but which I hope we will get if they have honesty of purpose with respect to these constitutional proposals-that what has been said by Senator Tate in the committee debate about the effect of this Bill is not reflected in the question which currently is to be posed to the people. Senator Tate said a little later in that debate:

The proposition that fixed terms are a distinguishing characteristic of this chamber as provided for at the moment under the constitutional provisions, particularly obviously, under section 7 of the Constitution, is absolutely correct.

So Senator Tate, in the debate, conceded that fixed terms are a distinguishing characteristic of this chamber. The committee debate was fascinating. We had several unexpected and I suspect unwelcome and certainly distracting interventions by Labor people, including Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Home Affairs. Let us look at Senator Ray's spirited defence of the need for fixed terms. He said the Labor Party wants fixed terms and the only reason it is not going for fixed terms is that we did not want fixed terms. Senator Ray keeps contributing to the debate and accusing other people of illogicality and inconsistency. I just say that if the Labor Party policy is for fixed terms, why is it that this solitary element of fixed terms in the Australian Constitution-which the Minister in the debate has conceded does constitute some fetter upon the capacity of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to just pull the Parliament out at any time and to have elections whenever the Prime Minister likes-is being struck down by the Government? I think the answer is quite clear: It is being done to meet the political objectives of the government of the day. It is not being done in a conscientious attempt to improve the Constitution.

We referred in the debate to an opinion given by Mr Ewart Smith, who rocketed to fame because of his putting the finger on a fundamental deficiency, a defect, in the Australia Card debate. Mr Smith in his opinion, which as he stressed was not one which was given on the basis of being paid to give advice to the Opposition, was quoted as stating:

He was particularly opposed to the four-year term proposal because it would give senators four years, thus enabling a prime minister to call an election for the Senate as well as the House of Representatives for no good cause. The Senate's power would be reduced if the rotation principle under which half the Senate retires at a time was abandoned.

I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that in our amendment we have not included those matters which might be regarded as matters of political argument. We have not sought to include in the title, in the question, an allegation that this is about reducing the power of the Senate. We have not included our opinion that this can lead to more elections rather than fewer elections. In other words, we have not emulated the government in its approach to phrasing this question. We have not sought to replace one dishonest question with another. We have not said that because the Government is trying to slant its question in favour of its proposal we should produce an amendment which would slant the question in favour of the Opposition. We are saying that all we want in the long title of the legislation is something which fairly and squarely tells the people of Australia what they are voting about. They can draw their own conclusions and listen to arguments about whether that is good or bad, whether there should be more or fewer elections, whether it strengthens or reduces the power of the Senate. These are matters of political judgment, political opinion, and they are matters which we do not seek to pose in this question because we accept that whichever way one did that would lead to some bias.

The present question being posed by the Government is clearly a question which has been asked to try to produce the answer the Government wants. That is highly undesirable; it is wrong. It is a fraud upon the electorate, and this amendment is really a test of the Australian Democrats' bona fides with respect to this debate. All we seek is an honest description so that people will know what they are voting on. I believe that unless there is a commitment to having this referendum carried, whether it is understood or not, then this amendment will be given universal support. Certainly it has the very strong support of the Opposition parties. We believe it is essential if we are to have an honest referendum campaign. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this amendment. I do it reluctantly because I do not think that it includes a particular question that should be posed. It may be that the particular question I would include does go over the border a little and into argumentative areas. I think Senator Chaney has been a little too clinical in opposing the drafting of the question. Nevertheless, I commend him for that. Senator Chaney's description of this measure is far more truthful than the long title that has been put forward by the Government. I would have added a question as to whether the people desired to enable the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to call a double dissolution election at his pleasure. That is really what this Bill is all about. Nevertheless, I concede that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) on behalf of the Opposition has attempted to get some truthfulness into this measure. As he said, the long title of the Bill will be the actual question that is asked of the electorate. I believe it is most essential, if we are going to keep the Government and the Parliament honest on a major question such as this, that we should ensure that the question is not untruthful, misleading or deceptive, as indeed it is if it goes before the people as it is contained in the long title of the Bill. Therefore I support the amendment of the Leader of the Opposition and I hope that others will do so as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Chaney. In doing so I want to refer generally to the debate which has taken place on the Bill earlier in the committee stage. The long title of the Bill which we are seeking to amend states simply:

SPEECH.PARA: An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

In one sense that is literally correct, but it suffers from a major deficiency in that it does not tell the whole truth, it tells only some of the truth. Of course, it has been a very well recognised principle in the law that to be telling half truths is to be telling untruths, falsehoods.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party thinks it is clever.

—The Labor Party thinks it is clever, as Senator Crichton-Browne has said; it thinks this is smart, very clever. This is an extremely serious proposition that the Government is putting forward deliberately to mislead the people. Why does the Government not tell the whole truth? The reason it does not want to tell the whole truth is that the people may not so readily answer yes, which the Government wants, if the whole truth is told. If it just tells the people that this is to have four-year parliaments the average person would say, `Oh, that means four-year parliaments; yes, we think that this is a good idea'. There is clearly a strong view in the community in favour of four-year parliaments, although I do not think we should by any means assume, nor should the Government, that that will be the majority view of the people of Australia. Nevertheless, let us assume that that is a majority view at the moment. Certainly the Government is not doing even itself much service by trying to pull the wool over the eyes of the people. They know that the Government is relying on the goodwill of a large number of people who favour four-year parliaments. The Government is trying to pull the wool over the eyes of those people by bringing in under the coat tails of this amendment proposals which are clearly designed to weaken, if not ultimately destroy, the Senate. If that were spelled out clearly, and the amendment Senator Chaney has moved does that, then people would be less likely to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three quite separate questions. The first question is whether the maximum term of the House of Representatives should be extended from three years to four years. As I say, that is one question to which large numbers of people in Australia will say yes. The second and separate question is whether or not the fixed term of the Senate should be destroyed. The third question is whether the Senate should have exactly the same four-year term as the House of Representatives. Really there are three questions all rolled into one in this proposal. I think that it is quite dishonest for the Government not to explain the full ambit of this in the question that it will put to the people. Also I think it is deplorable for the Government, although perhaps not dishonest, to be asking three questions rolled into one. It should be asking the people in separate questions whether they are in favour of this or that. The Government could, if it thinks there is a connection between the questions, make certain answers contingent on others. In fact, that was part of a referendum proposal a few years ago when Senator Evans was the Attorney-General-not that I thought much of that proposal either, but at least it was giving people a proper choice. In this case, the Government has not.

In the course of this debate there have been a great many statements made by honourable senators opposite-indeed, by front bench members of the Government. I cannot quite remember, but I think Senator Robert Ray and certainly Senator Tate have been arguing strongly in this debate that this proposal does not weaken the power of the Senate. How Senator Tate, Senator Ray or other honourable senators can rationalise the idea that by destroying a fixed term of six years and making that term entirely at the whim of the Prime Minister of the day will not in any way affect the powers of the Senate is beyond my belief and understanding.

The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) does not seem to have much knowledge of constitutional law because, of course, the increase in the power of the Prime Minister has resulted from the development of his power to call an election whenever he is in trouble. Sometimes that trouble is with his own supporters, not necessarily with the Opposition. However, the development of that absolute power as a convention of our Constitution means that the Prime Minister can go along to the Governor-General with some reasons-they may be specious reasons, but they are not really examined very much; maybe they ought to be- and ask for an election. The convention really means that a Prime Minister with a majority in the House of Representatives can go along and ask for an election to be called whenever he likes. The saying is that the Prime Minister always carries an election in his pocket. That is now a well recognised convention of the Constitution; whether it is right or wrong, that is a fact.

There have been a couple of impediments to Prime Ministers calling an election of even the House of Representatives. One of these is in regard to the fixed terms for Senators. As Prime Minister Menzies found when he had an early election in 1963 he got elections for the House of Representatives out of kilter with those for the Senate. In that situation one has to have half Senate elections or more early elections to bring the two Houses back together. Therefore, that is a consideration that Prime Ministers have had to bear in mind. To some extent, it has restrained the enthusiasm of Prime Ministers for just going off and having early elections whenever they saw fit. Of course, the other restraint on Prime Ministers in calling early elections is that if they wanted to include the whole of the Senate that could be done only in the case of a deadlock between the two Houses in order to bring into operation the double dissolution provisions. Indeed, also in invoking the double dissolution provisions Prime Ministers have had to bear in mind that this also causes the two Houses to get out of phase and leads to the problem of juggling Senate and House of Representatives elections with half Senate elections subsequent to double dissolutions.

There have been very clear restraints, even on Prime Ministers' powers over the House of Representatives, arising from the structure of the Senate.
