However, in the proposal before the chamber we now have the answer to all the dreams of all Prime Ministers, past, present and future because in future they will not have to manufacture double dissolutions; they will not have to worry about half Senate elections any more. They will simply go along to Yarralumla and say, `I want an election' and the whole of the Senate will be dissolved at the same time as the House of Representatives. Senator Harradine pointed out in the debate that perhaps we ought even to have said that this proposal will relieve Prime Ministers of the need to have double dissolutions in the future, and the certain amount of trouble that sometimes causes them. Prime Ministers cannot always get grounds for a double dissolution just when they happen to want one.

In this proposal we have a remarkable increase in the powers of the Prime Minister. The Government has proposed a quite massive reduction in the status of the Senate. Clearly, the Senate's power must only be weakened, if not destroyed, by a proposal of this kind. To say that this does not in fact take away the power of the Senate over money Bills, to reject legislation or whatever, again is literally true. However, it does not express the total result of the Government's proposals. Neither Senator Tate nor any of his colleagues need take my authority for what I am saying because the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), happily sitting at the table at the moment--

TALK.START.PARA: —Most unhappily sitting at the table.

—Oh, Senator Button is not happy. I am not surprised that Senator Button is not happy. If Senator Button has been listening to all those honourable senators sitting behind him, particularly to his colleague the Minister for Justice, he would not be happy with the rubbish they have been serving up to the people of Australia in this debate. I will now get to Senator Button. Senator Button took part in a debate which I remember very well because I happened to be the Minister at the table at the time. As a Minister in the Fraser Government I had introduced a proposal--
—Was this in 1887?

—It was in 1977. It was a very mild proposal compared to this one. I just wanted to have simultaneous elections. The people did not agree with that and I, unlike members of this Government, abide by the decision of the electorate expressed on no fewer than three occasions. In 1974, 1977 and 1984 the people of Australia said no to this idea of having, as it was then, half the Senate go to election with the House of Representatives. But this proposal goes much further than that because it provides that the whole of the Senate will have to go to election every time there is an election for the House of Representatives. Senator Button supported the Bill that I introduced into the Senate.
—I was only a boy at the time. It was a long time ago.

—No, Senator Button was not just a boy. He had been in the Senate three years then because it was in 1977. Senator Button had become quite an experienced senator by then, I am afraid. Senator Button said in that debate:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the real importance and significance of this proposal from our point of view in the Opposition-
at that time the Labor Party was in Opposition-
is that it does what many of its critics say it will do-
I ask Senator Tate to attend to this-

It limits the significance and influence of the Senate . . . we do have a very strong view that the powers of the Senate should be delimited at every opportunity. These are the basic reasons why we will be supporting the legislation. In saying that we are being consistent with everything we have said before.

Of course, Senator Button was also prescient of what his colleague Senator Gareth Evans later said when he came into this place. In fact, Senator Evans was the Attorney-General for a while, a not very successful Attorney-General of the Labor Government. About the time Senator Evans was elected to the Senate-I think it was on 2 July 1978 and he had just taken his seat in the Senate-he was interviewed by the Canberra Times. We may think he is very expansive with his words these days but in those days he was not only more expansive but also probably even more truthful than he is today. He said, as reported in the Canberra Times on 2 July 1978:
The way to abolish the Senate, or at least to muzzle it, is to white ant it from within.
That is precisely, Senator Tate, what this proposal does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Chaney's amendment moved on behalf of the Opposition, not so much because the force and logic of his argument needs my support but more to give the Australian Democrats time to have a think about this. I see they have run out of the chamber at the moment. They are probably down in their little bunker doing some deal with the Government, as is their wont. When I saw the titles of these referendum Bills that are to be put before the people I thought the Government should have been had up before the Trade Practices Commission for misleading advertising, because that is exactly what it has tried to do. The argument has been put time and again during this debate that the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the four-year term Bill, is a massive alteration to the powers of the Senate and goes against what the founding fathers intended for this country. They were trying to dissolve the power of government, to make it so that no one person could ever gain control of the reins of government in this country. Yet we have here a gigantic step to put power in the hands of the Prime Minister. If it is not obvious for everyone to see now it certainly will be at the end of the campaign. People will say no to these referendum proposals. I assure the Government that it will be a massive campaign because I see this Bill as striking a blow against the freedom of the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Nearly all Prime Ministers, not just Labor Prime Ministers, have tried by various means in the past to limit the powers of the Senate. We have had for example, the appointment of Ministers in the Senate; the appointment of the Leader of the Government in the Senate by the Prime Minister; the use of referenda; the use of banging Bills through the Parliament if the Government had the numbers and testing them in the High Court; and the use of the treaty power. There have been lots of means, all designed to try to undermine the power of the Senate. This particular measure for the Senate to have terms equal with those of the House of Representatives is perhaps the biggest axe blow at the feet of the Senate that it could have.

I am very pleased that Senator Harradine is supporting the amendment. I take his point that it really should go further. Senator Chaney has been most circumspect in framing the terms of the amendment so that it cannot possibly offend the Government on political grounds. It certainly clarifies the position so that the people will know exactly what they are voting for, and I am sure if they do know what they are voting for they will vote against the proposals. That is one of the main reasons why I oppose the title of the Bill. It is obviously intended to mislead the people. The Government should be ashamed of itself for indulging in misleading advertising. That is exactly what it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to support Senator Chaney's amendment to the title of the question that will be put to the Australian people because it certainly does not explain to the people just what the Government is doing. Senator Chaney's amendment proposes that the Senate fixed term be reduced from a six-year period to a maximum of four years, requires a simultaneous election for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament and abolishes the system whereby half the Senate retires every three years. Senator Durack has just quoted Senator Button who on a previous occasion acknowledged at least that the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988 would strip the Senate of its powers if it compelled the Senate to go to an election along with the House of Representatives whenever the Prime Minister wanted. Yet, we have heard Senator Tate say that it does not strip the Senate of its powers; it just changes the characteristics of the Senate. That is obviously not true. Senator Button was being fairly forthright and honest. Senator Evans, at a later stage, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The way to abolish the Senate, or at least to muzzle it, is to white ant it from within.

They at least were being honest. I will quote a little further because Senator Evans in 1983 said more than that in relation to a simultaneous elections, a proposal not quite as bad as what we are looking at today. He said:
These proposals are relatively modest compared with some of the changes we may want to be making in the future.

So now it is very clear. Senator Evans warned the Australian community that simultaneous elections were only one step towards demolishing the Senate. This is one of those proposals that Senator Evans was referring to when he made the statement he did because this proposal goes a lot further than simultaneous elections. It says that the whole of the Senate shall be taken to a election every time the Prime Minister of the day wishes to take the House of Representatives. There is no point in Senator Tate using pretty words like `it changes the characteristic'. Both his leader and his previous Attorney-General, Senator Evans, have told the people, `Yes, it does strip the Senate of its powers'. Senator Evans said that simultaneous elections were nothing compared to what Labor had in store for the Australian people later. We are only now realising what he meant by that statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of sawing sawdust I want to support the amendment Senator Chaney has proposed. I regret that the Australian Democrats have not accepted this offer to respond favourably to a very reasonable amendment but rather have fled from the chamber. I would have thought that if there was one thing that a government ought to be scrupulously honest about, it is questions it is putting to the public by way of referendum. If there is one thing we should be able to rely on governments to do it is to ask people a question which is relevant to the answer. I can think of nothing more blatantly dishonest for a government to do than to so structure a question as to absolutely mislead those who will be required to compulsorily answer it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have here a question to be put to the people, concerning a Bill to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. What it does not say is in part corrected and rectified by Senator Chaney's amendment. His proposal is to increase the terms of members of the House of Representatives from a maximum of three years to a maximum of four years, to reduce the terms of senators from a fixed six years to a maximum of four years, to require simultaneous elections for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament and to abolish the system whereby half the senators retire every three years.

Senator Chaney could have gone further and still been correct. He could have referred to fixed terms, of which there is no mention in his amendment. He could have asked the very simple question that Paddy McGuinness proposed: Would the people of Australia support a Senate with reduced powers? Would they support the reduction of the powers of the Senate by way of a constitutional amendment? Of course, the answer is no. I find it a sad indictment, but an honest reflection, of this Government that it is so prepared to mislead the Australian people. It reminds me starkly of the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, trying to slip through this Parliament a Bill which appropriated $2m for the Yes case and no money for the No case. Fortunately, we were able to move an amendment to that Bill to prevent that.

The Government's proposal makes no reference in any form to the present section 7 of the Constitution, which refers to the Senate having fixed six-year terms-no less and no more. The question in no way relates to section 28 of the Constitution, which refers to the terms of the House of Representatives. It says:
Every House of Representatives shall continue for three years from the first meeting of the House, and no longer, but may be sooner dissolved by the Governor-General.

The difference, the comparison, is stark, as was the intention of the founding fathers in so drafting those two sections. The intention was obvious. It was intended that the Senate be a States House and that it remain remote, removed and untouched--

TALK.START.PARA: —Independent.

—Independent, untrammelled by the machinations, convulsions, political intrigue and political manoeuvring that might take place in the House of Representatives. It was intended that, if events took place in the House of Representatives which caused it to have an election, the Senate would stand removed from it. This proposal, although one would never know it from reading it, is intended to remove that capacity and to attach the Senate, like a weak relative, a mere grey shadow, to the House of Representatives, compelled in its functions and its future by events of the House of Representatives, inextricably tied to the fate not only of the government but of the House of Representatives and quite unable to stand alone and removed. It is now to be simply an instrument of the Prime Minister and its duration, its term, will rest exclusively in his hands. When he decides, for his own political expediency or for the future of his Government, to have an election, the Senate will now find itself required to go to an election also, for reasons quite unrelated to its own conduct and its own activities but simply to give the Prime Minister a chance to have an early election and to have his Government returned.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no doubt that this question, when put to the people, simply on the basis of its breathtaking audacity, its dishonesty, will be defeated. I have no doubt that, as Senator Sheil said, at the end of the day, if members of the public do not understand all the arguments of the type outlined by Senator Durack, they will understand one thing-that the question is a fraud. If they understand nothing else they will know that it is a bodgie question, a dud question, a fraud question, and on that basis alone I have no doubt that it will be defeated. I am quite certain that, given that the campaign for the No case is simply no more than presenting the facts, the question will be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too support the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney. Today we are addressing the most fundamental principles that the Australian people rely on-the Constitution of Australia. It is the rock that this nation is built on. It is our democracy encompassed in a very small book of 30 or 40 pages and it should be handled like eggs, with the most extreme care. Yet we have this Government coming in here with a cavalier attitude, proposing a short Bill of only one page which is immense in its dishonesty. The people of Australia deserve to know the meaning of the question that is to be put to them in the referendum in September. They deserve to know, when they answer that question in the affirmative or the negative, what that response will mean. The question as drafted in the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill clearly does not convey the meaning of the responses that will be required.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from various speakers on this side of the chamber and Senator Harradine that this Bill is clearly in default. It will take away the insurance policy that the people of this nation have relied on since the founding fathers proposed the Constitution in 1901. It will emasculate the Senate but we are not told this in the question proposed in the Bill. The title of the Bill is clearly in error and no-one on the Government side can launch an argument to support the proposed question.

Senator Chaney's amendment is clear and concise, and it tells the people exactly what will happen if they support the Yes case or if they vote no. Surely the Government and the Australian Democrats, who are noticeable by their absence from this debate, can support a question that will allow the people to know what they are voting for. I do not know where the Democrats are at the moment. I hope that they come into this chamber to support Senator Chaney's amendment. Otherwise they will be forever condemned as the running dogs of the Australian Labor Party. They will be forever condemned as the fourth faction of the Australian Labor Party that never had the guts, the fortitude or the courage to stand up in this Parliament for what is honest and decent. I do not know where they are at the moment, but I hope that they come back here and can hold their heads up in this place and say, `We support a question that is honest, and when people answer yes or no to that question they will know what they are answering yes or no to'. Of course, if they do not come back the question put to the people will be one that is dishonest. I believe that the people will respond to that dishonesty by voting no, as they did in 1974, 1977 and 1984.

The Democrats may be considering the fact that, if this proposal by the Government or, I suppose, Senator Chaney's amendment is passed, they will be locked into this place forever and will have to get only 3 or 4 per cent of the vote in their respective States. That will be the decision they are making now as they are locked in a huddle downstairs-whether they can offend the Government, which has put this Bill up, and, if they do offend it, what the repercussions will be for the Democrats. These thoughts will be going through their minds at the moment. I say to them as they are making their decision: there is more to politics than expediency. There is honesty and integrity. I hope that the Democrats will not be found lacking in those qualities and that they will support Senator Chaney's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to reinforce the speeches made by my colleagues in the Opposition and to support the amendment that has been moved to the title of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988 by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. This is a matter of honesty and of soundness in what is being put to the people of Australia. We are saying, and no-one can deny, that there is a lack of honesty and soundness in the description as drafted by the Government that will be put to the people in the referenda later this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give a simple analogy. If a government were proposing to cut taxes and at the same time to cut its spending on various government programs, it could conduct a poll of the people of Australia to see whether there was general agreement for this balancing act of government decision that was being proposed. If it wanted to maximise an outcome for lower taxes and to dress up the proposal to get the assent of the people, it would just put the question, `Are you in favour of lower taxes?' One can predict that, if that was all that was known, the people of Australia, any community of Australia, would answer overwhelmingly, `Yes, we are in favour of lower taxes'. However, if the proposal was put in alternative terms-`Do you want cuts in government programs such as age pensions, veterans' entitlements, unemployment benefits, road development, schools and hospitals?'-any group of Australians that were polled would probably say, `No, we do not want the cuts'.

In this example I am putting forward there would be a balance of lower taxes and lower spending but, depending upon which part of that package was put by way of the question in the poll, we would get completely different outcomes. If there were to be such a proposal and if it were to be credible and worth the paper it was written on, the Government would need to proceed in a bipartisan and balanced way and to say `Do you want cuts in government spending programs to the extent that they enable corresponding cuts in taxes?'. That might not be quite as simple to put to the people, but it certainly would be more honest. The people would sit down and say, `Ah, there is the word ``corresponding'' there. If we have cuts in programs it will enable cuts in taxes; if we have the cuts in taxes it will require cuts in spending'. There would be a variety of responses and it would be hard to predict whether the answer would be yes or no.

Depending upon the way in which the question is put, we can predict that the answer will be yes or no or somewhere in between. Clearly in the case that is before us in the chamber, we have the Government choosing a biased title and a biased question with regard to the first proposal for change to the Constitution. The Government's proposal has these words in the title:
An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

At first blush that looks pretty straightforward and could be summarised as a proposal to establish a four-year Parliament. There is general approval out in the community for four-year parliaments. Without reference to the details, those words are calculated by the Government to maximise a `Yes' outcome. However, if we put an alternative question at the other end of the spectrum-`An Act to alter the Constitution to abolish real power in the Senate'-I would predict that the people of Australia would say no to that question, because there is a widespread view that the Senate is important as a House of review, as a protection for the smaller States and indeed as a protection for the processes of parliament being sound. People would not want to see the abolition of the powers of the Senate, whether it is in relation to the identity card, which the Senate stopped but which raced through the House of Representatives, or the Bill of Rights, which similarly was approved with the iron majority of the Government in that place but was stopped when it came to the closer scrutiny and the detailed argument in the Senate.

What the Leader of the Opposition has put forward as a more honest, more sound and more appropriate title is not at one extreme of description, as is the Government's proposal, or at the other extreme-the one I have just put forward for the sake of the argument. Rather, it is directly descriptive, directly honest and directly sound. It is in four parts and it states that the title should be `An Act to alter the Constitution' to do four things:

to increase the terms of members of the House of Representatives from a maximum of 3 years to a maximum of 4 years, to reduce the terms of Senators from a fixed 6 years to a maximum of 4 years, to require simultaneous elections for both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament, and to abolish the system whereby half the Senators retire every three years.

Nobody in these several days of debate on this matter in the chamber has argued that those four matters are not accurate or factual. Is there anyone who would now want to say that those four matters are not accurate or factual? I do not hear any protest or anyone that would want to say, here in the chamber, that these words as proposed by Senator Chaney on behalf of the Opposition are other than factual and accurate. So I can only say that, when the people of Australia are looking at a matter that proposes to change the Constitution, they are aware that the Constitution can be so changed only if there is before the Houses of the Parliament a Bill such as we have here today and we debate it carefully and resolve upon an appropriate form of words that maximise what is sound. Then the outcome of that debate appears at the polling booth at a referendum and the people say yes or no to it. I put it to Senator Tate that we have a great responsibility in terms of our consideration of the Bill to ensure that the title by which the measure will be summarised and described is accurate and sound. If it is not accurate and sound, we are letting down the people of Australia.

When the people of Australia vote on this matter, they will not have the option of saying, `Yes, but' or `No, if'. They will be able to say only `yes' or `no'. It is paramount that the description of the measure that is put to them to which they are to say `yes' or `no' is put honestly and soundly. Because the Government's title is not meeting those criteria, it should be amended. I can only urge, in concert with my colleagues, that the Opposition's amendment be accepted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rebuts the idea that, in describing the Bill in the way it has by its long title, it has set out to mislead the Australian people. I believe that the description, `A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament' is short and simple, but it is adequate to the task of describing the various elements in the Bill. What we are putting in that long title is the essence of a proposal to be placed before the Australian people by way of referendum. It is quite clear that, in providing for a four-year maximum term for members of both Houses, one is increasing the term of members of the House of Representatives from the next election onwards, and that the fixed six-year term of senators, as presently provided, will be altered. The long title, in being expressed in the way it is, will convey the essence of the proposal to the elector and will be sufficient to alert that person to the basic nature of what is proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no slant or subterfuge involved in the way the matter is expressed. I believe that, by the time the referendum proposals are put, the people will recognise the adequacy of what is put in that simple formula. I believe that the long title should be supported. I could go through all of the contributions to the second reading and committee stages of the Bill, but they have already been recapitulated. I will simply say that the long title adequately describes what is being put in this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has moved an amendment regarding the long title of the Bill. This is important because, as many people have said, the long title of the Bill represents the question which people will be asked to assert or refuse. It is interesting to compare the title suggested by Senator Chaney in his amendment, on behalf of the Opposition with that suggested by the Government. They illustrate two different philosophies of what the long title should be about with regard to a Bill on constitutional change. Senator Chaney's title enumerates the changes, which I think is a reasonable approach. The Government's enumerates the result, which is also reasonable. Quite frankly, I think that at the end of the day it is very difficult, certainly in terms of the discussions we have had on this matter, to choose between one philosophy and the other. Both have something to recommend them. One would hope that the items which are included in both will be the substantive items debated in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: One would also hope-I think that I am treading on shaky ground here-that the Yes and the No case would rehearse the substantive arguments. I realise that I am treading on very slippery ground there. I say that because if anybody wants the enlightened task of going back and rereading the Yes and No cases for many of the constitutional proposals in the last 10 years, he cannot but be struck by the lack of information conveyed to the elector and the extraordinary propositions that were put both for and against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyway, how many read them?

—Senator Harradine asks, `How many read them?'. We had a very interesting debate here, I think in 1983, about whether or not the Government should be able to spend money elsewhere. I think that it was indicated quite clearly in that debate that all honourable senators were of a mind that that ought to continue, that at least there was a chance that at some stage information might be conveyed to the elector. I suppose it is up to those who comprise the committees that write the Yes and the No case to do their best to present factual information to the elector upon which he is able to make a decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Some extraordinary statements have been made in this debate so far, particularly those attacking the Australian Democrats. I do not propose to answer them. Most are contemptible and have no bearing on this issue. I suppose it is part of the cut and thrust of political life in this country that people feel that abusing one another goes for intelligent debate. I would have thought that in addressing one's mind to this issue, one would have to end up choosing which philosophy one wishes to adopt in couching the final question that goes to the people. We have decided, for a couple of reasons, that that part of Senator Chaney's amendment which talks about a fixed term and the part at the end which talks about abolishing the system whereby half the senators retire every three years, which is the formal context that governs the Senate and the Senate's elections, do not reflect the practical context of Senate elections.

The Government's proposal, which actually talks about a maximum term rather than simply a four-year term-the proposal is not for a four-year term; it is for a maximum of four years-is an accurate description of the outcome. That is the basis on which people will be asked to say, `Yes, I want that' or `No, I don't want it'. I do not want to couch the Opposition's proposition in the terminology that it was another cynical attempt to manipulate the electorate. I hope that in the debate on the rest of the Bills we will address ourselves to those issues in a more rational and reasonable way. We accept the philosophy of the Government's terminology in terms of trying to put the outcomes in the long title rather than putting the changes in the long title. On that basis, as well as the other basis of the two items reflecting the practical context as well as the theoretical context, or the constitutional context, we support the retention of the long title to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak further, having heard Senator Macklin put down a position for the Australian Democrats, and to express my very great disappointment at the attitude he has taken. He has made a statement which is quite inaccurate about the approach the Government has adopted on this question. Senator Macklin said that the Government, in determining the title of this Bill and in laying down what question, therefore, will be put to the Australian people, has enumerated the result of the changes. That is not true. The Government has enumerated a result of the changes. It has enumerated one of the changes and it has carefully concealed the other changes that will flow.

SPEECH.PARA: In an attempt to be absolutely fair in this matter, the Opposition has looked at what we see as the real changes of substance which are effected. We have left out of the question what we believe to be the results, which are matters for argument. Is one of the results, for example, fewer or more elections? One of the results about which we certainly know is that if this amendment is carried it will make it easier for the Australian Democrats to retain their representation in this place. That is not the result; it is a result of this referendum. I raise that matter because the Australian Democrats commenced their political being under the leadership of an ex-colleague of mine, Don Chipp. Don Chipp said that his objective in coming here was `to keep the bastards honest'. By `the bastards' he meant us politicians-not Liberal politicians in particular or Labor politicians or independents. He wanted to keep government, and politicians generally, honest.

I suggest to Senator Macklin that he think further about the argument he has put. I believe he is under a particular obligation to do so because, with respect to this amendment, a very heavy element of self-interest is involved. I do not accuse Senator Macklin of speaking from self-interest. I simply remind him that when one's interest is involved, that is the time when one has to examine most carefully one's thought processes and motivation. I simply say that there is a particularly heavy onus on the Australian Democrats, in supporting a change to the Constitution which is of direct and clear benefit to the Australian Democrats, to be doubly concerned to make sure that the argument they put forward is solid, logical and correct and that they are doing the right thing by the people of Australia.

I say without a moment's doubt that Senator Macklin is not correct when he says that the Government has given us a short title, a long title and, therefore, a question which enumerates the result of these changes. It enumerates one of the results. It does not enumerate that a result of these changes is that one of the things which has been described by Senator Tate as a distinguishing characteristic of this chamber is to disappear. I will quote what the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who is in charge of this Bill, has said, because I wish to avoid any suggestion that I am trying to use words in a manipulative or partisan way. I adopt these words used by Senator Tate:
The proposition that fixed terms are a distinguishing characteristic of this chamber . . . is absolutely correct.

That is what Senator Tate said in the course of the debate. One of the results of this constitutional change, therefore, is to remove one of the distinguishing characteristics of this chamber. We do not say that the title should include reference to the fact that the abolition of that distinguishing character is to increase Executive control over the Senate, to make the safeguard of the Senate therefore less real. We do not say that one of the results is to enable the Australian Democrats always to have access to a lower quota and therefore to improve their chance of election. We do not raise all of those political results which we genuinely believe will flow from it. What we have done-and I ask Senator Macklin to consider this again-is to set out what are the key changes.

We can all argue about what results will flow, because I think honest men can differ. Honest men can differ from year to year. Senator Tate, whom we all regard as an honest man, thought in 1983 or 1984 that an eight-year term was a good idea. He now thinks that it is not a good idea. Views on these matters will change over time and in different circumstances and, perhaps, when the majority of one's party changes its mind. We have all been through that experience in a political party. We are not always able to argue the case that we personally believe in. We argue the case that a majority of the party, after proper argument, has determined. An absolute requirement on Senator Tate and all members of the Labor Party is that the view that they put forward must be that of Caucus. We understand that. I do not suggest any lack of morality or otherwise on it. It is a bit confusing for the public at times, but the system operates under those rules.

The critical point is that we are looking at the honesty of the question which is being put to the Australian people. I do not believe that it is possible for Senator Macklin to assert with accuracy that the question as posed by the Government gives the result of the changes. It gives one of the results of the changes. The things which matter are the important other results-results which go to the sort of constitutional structure we have and to the capacity of the Australian people to resist wrong actions by government.

There has been a lot of reference in this debate to the identity card and to the Bill of Rights. They are quite important reminders of the fact that the Senate, in a quite subtle way, stands for the people of Australia in a way that no other body in politics can. It is worth remembering that the really fascinating point about the ID card was that the majority in the Senate, which included the Australian Democrats, the Liberal and National parties and Senator Harradine, took a decision to oppose the identity card when 70 per cent of the people of Australia agreed with the card and disagreed with us. We defeated it twice. We had an election, we lost the election, and by the time the Bill came back before us the proportions had reversed; 70 per cent of the Australian people were then against the card and agreed with us.

The peculiar thing was that we in this Senate were prepared to take what was then a very unpopular stance, vindicated by the subsequent change of mind of the Australian people as they came to understand what the card meant, as they listened to the arguments put by the parliamentary committee, saw the report put down by my colleague Senator Puplick, which I thought was an excellent exposition of the difficulties with the card, and so on. That is what we are talking about. We are not talking about some airy-fairy thing which means nothing. We are not talking about our own terms. In truth, very few of us get to serve a full term. We know that. What we are talking about, essentially, is this question of whether some limitations are placed on the power of government to override the legislature. It all sounds so theoretical and self-serving. That is why one must refer to those examples which show that the Senate, in the end, stands for the informed will of the people. That is what is under threat.

I think it is quite wrong of the Australian Democrats to take refuge in the argument we have just heard from Senator Macklin. It was a very disappointing response from him. I ask him very seriously to reconsider it. Senator Harradine thought that we had been deficient. He thought that we would give the Australian people a better picture if we also told them that the Bill was to enable the Prime Minister to call a double dissolution election at his pleasure. Strictly, that is accurate, on the word of the Minister. The Minister told us both last Thursday and today that the Prime Minister effectively has the power to call an election at any time. My response is to say that one can argue that some emotional words are used, that it goes beyond flat description. I am bending over backwards to be absolutely flat and fair and to leave the argument to argument rather than to what is contained in the title of the Bill and the question on the ballot paper.

The Australian Democrats must expect to be judged in this matter on the obvious facts. They have to be judged on the fact that their own self-interest must lead them to support this constitutional change because they need only half as many votes to get elected to this place, if we have a permanent double dissolution situation, as they need in a half Senate election. That is why they should be doubly careful in this case. They should be bending over backwards, as I have been bending over backwards, to be fair to the Australian electorate. If they maintain the argument which Senator Macklin has adopted this afternoon, I accuse them of not being prepared to protect the Australian electorate and to ensure that an honest question is put to it. I accuse them if not of dishonesty then of allowing their whole judgment and approach to be clouded by self-interest. I do not believe that this is in any way consistent with the basis on which the Party was founded by the ex-senator, Don Chipp. It is a very sad drop in the standards of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support fully what Senator Chaney said, particularly about self-interest and honesty for each one of us in this chamber. I rise because Senator Macklin has not risen. I make the same plea as Senator Chaney has made to him and to the Australian Democrats, to reconsider the position that they have just put to us through Senator Macklin's speech. In his quiet speech, which weighed up the various merits of the Government's title and the Opposition's, he called for a rational approach. He came to a conclusion which the rest of us in the Senate see as being obviously on the side of the self-interest of the Democrats. Yet he did not make any explicit reference to his own self-interest. The Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, often speaks on these matters. I am not concerned if the Democrats rise to say that it is in their self-interest to have words left as they are, as proposed by the Government, because in that way more people would be more inclined to see this proposal as less dangerous to the rights of Australian citizens and to the stability of the Senate and the working of parliament; therefore, it is more likely to get a yes outcome and advantage the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing wrong with a member of this Parliament honestly saying: `I am voting this way because it is in the interests of my Party to do so'. But if a soft speech is made which calls for rational debate and which then neglects any analysis of self-interest, surely there is a question about credibility. Surely the questions will be asked with all the directness that the founder of the Democrats put, of so-called `keeping the bastards honest'. Is it not the case, Mr Chairman, that Senator Macklin, like you and I, is a short-term senator? He will be facing an election at the next due half Senate election in 1990. If he were to face that election, without any change to the Constitution in the meantime, he would need to accumulate a quota of 15 per cent of the votes in Queensland. However, it is very problematic whether he or any other Democrat will get such a quota at the next due half Senate election. So he would be facing defeat and no longer remaining as a senator for Queensland. However, if this Bill is passed and put to the people in a few months time in September and if it gains the assent of the majority of Australians and the majority of States, the circumstances will be very different. Senator Macklin in particular will need to accumulate approximately only 7 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —So will you.

—So will any senator, to be re-elected to this place. Therefore, his task of gaining election will be twice as easy. That is particularly important for the Australian Democrats and for any minority party, Independent senator or emerging candidate. Unlike parties which have long had a substantial following in Australia such as the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party, they will find it much more difficult to get a 15 per cent quota than to get a 7 per cent quota. When that stares us in the face and when it is in the self-interest of the Democrats not only to support this Bill and advocate its support by the people of Australia in the referendum but also to support a title to that question which is likely to maximise that vote, we should rightly ask: What is the self-interest and the hidden agenda of the Democrats in this matter?

SPEECH.PARA: I am not berating Senator Macklin for his calm and apparently rational speech. I am not even berating him for standing here and saying that it is in his self-interest and therefore he is doing it. But I am putting to him the challenge of the founder of his Party, to keep all politicians honest. Let us keep ourselves credible by at least referring to the self-interest that we have, not just dress it up in a learned, academic and considering speech. I join with all Senator Chaney has said and again put it to the Democrats that they reconsider this view and support the more accurate and more descriptive title that the Opposition has moved as an amendment in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The points made by Senator Chaney and Senator Teague a moment ago I think are based on a supposition that ignores-it is probably quite reasonable to do so-the second reading speeches, since they were made so long ago. On the second reading speech, I made a simple point, particularly with regard to this item, and that was that we will be supporting the item in this chamber to go to the people. We have always supported items. Indeed, I remember that we supported one of the former Senator Peter Rae of the Liberal Party in relation to which I expressed the view that if it were to go to the people we would campaign against it because we did not believe that it would be an advantage to have the Constitution changed in the way it proposed. In the debate here last week I made a claim-I do not wish to go over that again because I think the Chair would probably call me to order-with regard to citizens' initiative and the ability of more questions going to the people. As it so happens, I indicated no position on behalf of the Party with regard to this item in the campaign. That was quite deliberate. I informed the House that my Party would be campaigning for the second, third and fourth questions vigorously and that at the moment, we would not be campaigning, in terms of the Party's position, for or against the first item. I gave a number of reasons for this in my speech in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague also went on to make other points which are probably of a little more hypothetical nature about whether I might succeed in Queensland if I stood at the next election. I was originally elected to this place as one out of five. Senator Teague suggested that I would not be re-elected. I am confident of my position. Although some honourable senators may not think it is a very good commendation, there has been a small monograph done by Malcolm Mackerras on the possible outcome of the next election which says that I will get elected in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —You start to worry when Mackerras says you are right. You're gone.

—I thought that Senator Boswell would make those very unkind and uncharitable comments about Malcolm Mackerras's predictions. That is why I premised my remarks in the way I did. I am quite happy to fight the next election under either the current Constitution or the new one and I will win as I have in the last four elections that I have fought.
—But you don't deny that the change actually advantages you?

—I have never denied that. We have quite openly said that the change will strengthen the Senate because it will ensure that the Australian Democrats will hold the balance of power here. That will mean that neither the Government nor the Opposition will control this chamber. We believe that will enable this chamber to operate, as it has since 1981, as a House of review. We think that is beneficial for the country and for the Parliament. I made no bones about that in the speech I made in the second reading debate on this legislation when I had an hour to expand those particular points. I stand by those comments. I do not believe that it is the structural nature of this chamber that makes it a genuine House of review; it is the numbers in this chamber that make it a House of review. There may be some dispute about that, but that is the position I hold and I am quite happy to debate that proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously this particular proposition would be in our interests. However, our Party's policy is-and we intend to continue to campaign strongly on this matter-for a fixed term Parliament. This is not such a proposal, hence public support for this proposal would be contrary to our belief that ultimately we need a fixed term Parliament. I express regret that such a proposal was not put. We were the only people in this place to vote for that proposition last time around. I think it was 1983 when we finally got a vote on this exercise when the Government withdrew its own Bill on that matter that it introduced soon after it was elected. Ultimately, we will go down that track in this country. It is the type of thing that the people of this country want. However, that matter is not before us at this time. People should have the right to cast a judgment on this proposition and that is why we will support the proposition going to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have given an undertaking not to campaign on question No. 1 when the referenda are put.
—Order! The matter before the Chair is the title of this Bill.

—I am addressing the title. I am very aware of it because it is material to all that has been said in the last several speeches. The title in the form that is proposed by the Government is not to be changed, with the support of the Democrats, because they have indicated a preference for the description in terms of one of the results of this matter being passed. Their policy on the term of the Senate, enunciated by Senator Macklin, is for a fixed term. This is contrary to that policy. Also, Democrat policy is to maximise the ability of the people themselves to decide. The Democrats have indicated that they will not campaign on this question. That means that there will be no how-to-vote cards distributed by the Democrats in the referendum campaign that will ensue.

—I would like very briefly to comment on Senator Macklin's suggestion that there are two philosophies of thought-I perhaps would have used the term `two schools' of thought. I do not know whether there are schools of thought-perhaps that point has just come up in the last day or two or the last hour or two-as to how the question is to be put to the people. Senator Macklin says that one school of thought is that the question that is to be put to the people should refer to the results of what will occur if the referendum is adopted and the Constitution is altered. The other school of thought, he says, is one which puts to the people the alterations that will take place to the Constitution. We have two questions: one is the outcome, as the honourable senator said, and one is the alteration. What does the Constitution say about that? There is only one question to be put to the people and that surely is: What is the alteration to the Constitution to be? It should not be: What will be the outcome or outcomes? It should be: What are the changes to section 128?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry for moving in before my colleague Senator Macklin who was also rising to speak, but I wanted him to have an opportunity to think about the matter I wish to raise. Senator Macklin, who was speaking on behalf of the Australian Democrats a few minutes ago, said that he would not answer abuse. I have no quarrel with a senator who says that he will not answer abuse, but I am a little sorry that he chose not to answer one of the points of substance that I put to him. I hope he would not suggest that my remarks were in any way abusive of his position, although I challenge the correctness of it. The fundamental point which Senator Macklin made in explaining his Party's position was to say that the Government has chosen to enumerate the result. The point I made in response to him was that the Government has chosen not to do that at all. The Government has chosen to enumerate a result.

SPEECH.PARA: I note Senator Harradine's contribution to the debate with which I respectfully agree. I think the obligation on the Government, is to put before the people in the long title what changes are, in fact, being made to the Constitution. But Senator Macklin did not address at all the proposition that I put to him, that there are a series of results which flow from this particular change. One of the results, as I reminded him in my earlier comment, was that one of the distinguishing characteristics of this chamber is to be changed. I would appreciate it if Senator Macklin would think further on that point because I think there is a great risk that we are witnessing a bit of sophistry here-sophistry, I am sure, is a term well known to Senator Macklin-and I invite him to consider the point of substance that was put to him and to respond to it.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Title be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Ordered that the third reading of the Bill be an Order of the Day for a later hour of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my notice of intention given earlier today, I now withdraw Business of the Senate Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for the disallowance of the public rental housing assistance program.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, to be considered in conjunction with that Committee's reference on the feasibility of a national identification scheme:

(a) the taxation file numbering scheme announced by the Treasurer in the May Economic Statement, and, in particular, whether the scheme is likely to improve the efficiency of the taxation system and to eliminate fraud and abuses in the taxation and social security systems; and
(b) the possibility of that scheme developing into a de facto national identification card system with unacceptable impositions being made upon privacy and civil liberties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Throughout the course of the last debate there were constant references to quotations which I am alleged to have made back in 1978 on the nature of the Senate. I have forborne from participating in the debate in the certain knowledge that it would generate a further cycle of unproductive comment, but let me just read for the record what was actually said. The first was in the Canberra Times of 2 July 1978, in which an article written by me appeared under a title-not of my own writing, but of the sub-editor's-which is the quote that has been used so often today: `The way to abolish the Senate, or at least muzzle it, is to white-ant it from within'. I make it clear for the record that I said no such thing and wrote no such thing. The closest thing to it which appears in the article is a sentence in the following terms-and remember the time at which it was written and the context of the Australian Labor Party policy that existed at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: If one believes, as I do, along with all good Labor men and women true, that the Senate ought to be abolished, or at the very least deprived of its capacity to destroy properly elected governments, there is surely no better forum in which to promote these insidious heresies than the institution itself.
That is a very different proposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly the same thing; just a fancy way.

—It is more than a fancy way, Senator Chaney; it is a very different concept, which I hope the honourable senator would have the honesty and decency at least to acknowledge. It is not a matter of insidious white-anting; it is the open use of a forum for political debate, and that is something that is entirely reasonable and it is a cause which I have adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that I wish to make is about my maiden speech, which has been constantly the subject on about 25 different occasions throughout the course of the last debate, in which again sentiments of that kind were attributed to me. In fact, there was no point during that speech, although I said a number of other things about the Senate, when I could have been taken to be urging its abolition. What I did say was to the contrary, because I was indicating that I thought the Senate had a constructive role to play. I will repeat, if I may, the relevant passage. I stated:

I take this opportunity to place on record my unshakable determination-along with that of my Labor Party colleagues-to ensure that the constitutional outrages of 1974 and 1975 are never again repeated. If this House does have a useful role to play in the legislative process, it does not lie in menacing or threatening a properly elected government with the power of life or death based on some spurious conception of the Senate's position as a defender of States' rights or federalism or the more recently fashionable notion that it is a last resort defender of the national interest against the Huns and Visigoths of the lower House. Rather it lies in the careful and effective scrutiny, analysis, testing and review of the legislative and executive initiatives of the government of the day, and occasionally in the initiation of reforming legislative proposals of its own. There are ample precedents in recent years for constructive and helpful work of this kind. I look forward to participating in it and wish only that the Senate would get on with it.

That is the end of that quotation. That is the substance of what I said about the role of the Senate on that occasion. I repeat the sentiment on this occasion that I wish the Senate would get on with the task of doing something constructive, but I think it is important and legitimate to place that on the record. May I express the hope that there are no further grotesque misrepresentations during the referendum campaign of the kind that we have heard so often during this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not want to debate the matters that have just been raised by way of personal explanation by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). I think we ought to get on with the careful analysis, testing and scrutiny of the legislation that is before us. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the personal explanation.
Because I wish to go back to doing the task that the Minister has outlined as ours, namely, the careful analysis, testing and scrutiny of legislation, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 is an extremely short Bill the purpose of which is to alter the Constitution to enable the recognition of local government. What is proposed to be added to the Constitution is a new section 119a which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

What I seek from the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in the committee stage of debate on this Bill is some explanation of the meaning of this proposal. I mention that because although, of course, there are provisions in the Standing Orders which state that we are not entitled to ask a Minister for a legal opinion during Question Time, I assume that we are not restricted from doing so in this debate. I think that there are significant differences of view as to just what the words in the clause mean. I suspect that the true position is that none of us really knows what the words mean in a final constitutional sense because who knows what the High Court of Australia will make of it? I say that without wishing to be disrespectful of the High Court. Indeed, no disrespect is intended. The reality is that constitutional provisions notoriously are interpreted in widely different ways.

In the debate on the next Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988, which picks up matters such as trial by jury and freedom of religion and so on, I suspect that honourable senators will refer to the quite divergent views of High Court judges on what the meanings of those provisions are. For example, I was struck by the fact that Mr Justice Murphy and Mr Justice Deane proposed a view of the trial by jury provision which was fundamentally different from the view of the majority of judges. That is relevant to this debate only as a reminder to us, that what is said in the Constitution can be interpreted in widely different ways. I must confess to some difficulty in respect of what the Government is putting forward here.

On the face of it, I suggest to the Minister that the constitutional amendment is in fact adding nothing other than an oral reference to local government. It is adding nothing to the present situation, and nothing in the way of guarantees. What the words specifically say is that:
Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government . . .

I think it would be common ground within the Committee that there is a system of local government within each State, but that there is not a suggestion in the clause that there should be anything new or different. Perhaps before I go on to quote further from that clause I should say that there is, of course, a significant difference between what is contained in this clause and what has been recommended in respect of the inclusion of local government in the Constitution. For example, there was a recommendation that there should be a reference to the `establishment and continuance of local government', whereas the Government has chosen to insert the expression `a system of local government'. This suggests that what is being required is merely some system, not the preservation of any particular local government body. Indeed, from the explanatory memorandum that would appear to be what the Government is seeking to achieve.

Clause 119a goes on to refer to, `local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State'. This is in accordance with the status quo but perhaps it means that there has to be local government throughout the State. The requirement of elected local bodies is one that is well known in all States. Clause 119a further states, `empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State'. Those words, as I say, appear to add very little or indeed nothing to the status quo, unless it could be argued that the requirement that local government bodies be elected in accordance with the laws of the State means that we cannot have a local government body which is not elected. On the face of it, that is an implication one might seek to draw from those words because when we think about it we say, `Hang on, there are local government bodies which are not elected bodies, but are appointed bodies'. For example, I think the City of Sydney has enjoyed an appointed administration for some time. Early this afternoon I heard in conversation reference to certain Victorian municipalities that were being administered on a short term basis and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Melbourne.

—My colleague Senator Walters has referred to Melbourne. Therefore, it seems to me that one's antennae start to move about and one asks, `What is really meant here?' I find it very hard to connect what is written in the Bill with what is contained in the explanatory memorandum. I am fascinated because it seems to me that what the Government is saying is, `We believe the High Court will take a certain view of these words'. However, it seems to me that the meaning is not apparent on the face of the words at all. I ask the Minister as part of my comments on the committee stage of the Bill whether he is suggesting that the High Court is bound in any way by the explanatory notes. It would be my understanding that it is not, any more than the High Court is bound by or is to be guided or assisted by the debate in this chamber on this particular measure. The amendment to the, I think, Acts Interpretation Act which enables the courts to refer to Hansard does not as I understand it apply to constitutional amendments. Therefore, we have a situation where what has been said in this place and, as I understand it, what has been said in the explanatory notes are not of themselves, or should not be, of assistance to the High Court, although none of us in our ignorance knows what is of assistance to judges. However, as I understand it, in a formal legal sense-I seek the Minister's clarification on this-what is written in the explanatory notes and what is said in the debate, whether it is in the Minister's second reading speech or in this committee stage of the debate are not matters which can be adverted to in legal argument and taken as a guide for the Court. What is said in the explanatory note is:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. The Constitutional obligation will be to establish and continue a system of local government.

The words `establish', `continue' and `system' are underlined. I think that the systems have all been established so I do not know what the Government means by that. There is a system established in every State. The word `continue' is underlined. Paragraph 3 of the explanatory memorandum states:
Nor is it intended to preclude laws providing for the dismissal of a local council in appropriate circumstances, subject to a new local government body being elected within a reasonable period.

What is the basis of that statement? The suggestion in the explanatory memorandum is that in some way this amendment will place some new obligation upon the administering authority, namely, the government of the particular State, if it dismisses a local council because it thinks the council is a bunch of either incompetents or crooks, to allow it, after what is called in the explanatory memorandum `a reasonable period' to re-establish democratically elected local government. I am genuinely puzzled because that seems to be no more than a guess at what this might be held to mean and quite frankly it is not the meaning I would attribute to it. If the Government has in mind appointing me to the High Court I should warn it that in my view there is no obligation on the face of these words for the Government to do anything with respect to any particular area of a State. I am fortified in that view because paragraph 4 of the explanatory memorandum says that the section:
is not intended to oblige a State to establish local government bodies throughout the whole of the State.

I do not think the Minister can have it both ways. I really do not think that the Minister can say in paragraph 4 of the explanatory memorandum that what he has proposed to write into the Constitution about local government does not oblige a State government to have local government in substantial areas. I presume the Minister is trying to cover the situation that used to apply in South Australia, where some of the remoter areas were not covered by local government. I am assisted by the nodding of the Temporary Chairman, Senator Teague, who is from the State of South Australia.

The Government is apparently saying that there is no obligation under this section to establish and continue local government throughout the State. Yet, it is suggesting that when a State exercising its lawful functions terminates an elected local authority for the sorts of reasons I have outlined-because of administrative incompetence, dishonesty or whatever-there is some new constitutional obligation to have a new local government body elected within a reasonable period. I am sorry if there are some words in this which have totally escaped my attention, but the gravamen of my point in this committee debate is simply that once again the Government has been either careless or not straight. It has either carelessly made this mistake, produced these inconsistent propositions, or is in fact trying to say to local government, `Look, these words mean what we think you want them to mean'.

In other words, this is a particularly shoddy piece of work. I hope it is not the Minister's work. In the Minister's defence, I would be grateful if he could actually identify who is responsible for it. I hope it was not the Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, because as I understand it he actually made quite a good living in legal practice for a while and I do not think the person who wrote this explanatory memorandum would. Perhaps he could tell us what it means. How does he make compatible what is in paragraph 3 and 4 with what I see in the explanatory memorandum? I see those points as totally incompatible. How in the world does the Minister spell out either conclusion in the words that he is proposing to insert into the Constitution?

I will close my comments on this matter by simply saying to the Minister that the more one looks at this the more the political nature of the exercise being undertaken is apparent. I do not pretend that in the short term it is not an effective political operation, because a lot of people in local government have worked very hard over a very long period because they have liked the idea of constitutional recognition. I acknowledge that. Just as with the identity card, once starts a bit behind the eight ball. In this case the Government, as usual, has been clever but I suspect too clever by half. The Minister has given, on the face of it, an unsustainable explanation or explanations of what the Government is doing. On the other hand, I issue a warning, and I would be happy to have the Minister's comment on it, that the Minister cannot predict, Mr Bowen cannot predict and certainly Mr Hawke, whose knowledge of the law is infinitesimal, cannot predict what the High Court will make of all of this.

I am struck by the fact that Deane and Murphy, who spoke of a particular constitutional provision, said that it had to mean something. We may well find the High Court at some stage puzzling over this, saying that this has to mean something. I doubt that it will have much time to ponder it in any long-term sense because I note that an old graduate of the Western Australian law school, Mr George Winterton, had a few things to say about this. He suggested that the moment a local authority is dismissed by a State government it will rush off to the High Court for a declarational order to restrain the State. This is an intensely practical matter I have raised with the Minister. I commend to the Minister's attention the view of Mr George Winterton that we should leave local government alone in this context and that the referendum proposals should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support very strongly the comments that Senator Chaney just made. I will not go over the same points that he raised, other than to start my remarks by reading again the actual clause that is being proposed for insertion into the Constitution and which is the essence of this Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government.
The Government is proposing to insert into the Constitution a new section which reads as follows:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

It seems that that clause raises more questions than it answers. Certainly it does not appear to go anywhere towards meeting the needs and requests of local government itself set out in the submissions that the Australian Council of Local Government Associations made in 1986 and 1987 to the Australian Constitutional Commission. In oral evidence given to the Constitutional Commission last year, the Council advocated:

the inclusion in the Federal Constitution of a separate Chapter concerned with Local Government, which would provide for its existence, its exercise of certain powers, and protection of a council from dismissal except for just cause.

It also proposed a redistribution of powers between the three levels of government. So that was what the Australian Council of Local Government Associations put to the Constitutional Commission last year. It had also put earlier submissions to that Commission seeking a stronger recognition of local government in the Constitution.

It is worth noting, as I said, that the wording of the proposed amendment to the Constitution does not touch substantively the needs or the wishes of local government. For example, the word `Commonwealth' is not even mentioned in the clause. It provides for no recognition of local government by the Commonwealth Government. There is no reference to revenue sharing arrangements, which of course are the very essence of what local government has been looking for in terms of legalised and constitutional recognition. It all gets back in the end to revenue sharing and funding. There is no reference at all to the ability of local government to deal directly with the Federal government, there is no guarantee against wrongful dismissal of a local council, there is no guarantee against forced amalgamations of local governments, and there is no substantive recognition of any of the other matters of which local government is seeking recognition. Indeed, there is not even in the clause a definition of local government itself. The constitutional lawyers, as has been said before and will certainly be said again-Senator Chaney made this point-will have a field day with this proposal if it is passed.

The concept, the potential definition of local government, is very wide indeed. For example, would it encompass the regional Aboriginal councils that are to be set up under the new arrangements in that area, if they come to pass? The thing that worries me most, or worries me equally with those other concerns, is that this clause, through its very wording, seems to me to entrench local government even more firmly as a creature of the States, a shadow from which it has been struggling to emerge for years. Every aspect of the wording of this proposal gives the role to the States. It says:

Each State shall provide for the establishment . . . of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

If ever local government wanted to have its subservient role vis-a-vis State governments recognised in full, the wording it has been lumbered with in this constitutional amendment proposal certainly does that. It is worth pointing out also that the Powers Advisory Committee, an advisory committee to the Constitutional Commission, recommended that local government should not be accorded recognition in the Constitution, and it gave various reasons for that. I shall repeat just some of them. The first states:
There is some uncertainty as to how the High Court would interpret a provision in the form proposed by the Constitutional convention in Brisbane.
That was back in 1985, and I will not go into all the details of that. As to the second reason:
Support for the proposals came almost exclusively from Local Government and appeared mainly to be based on a perceived need to increase the status of Local Government.

That is not a reason, in my view, for necessarily opposing the proposal but it is an argument, if local government is to be recognised, for it to be done in a meaningful way and not in a way which has been described, I think quite rightly, as tokenism. Another reason given by the Powers Advisory Committee states:
The implications of a new Chapter on Local Government has not been canvassed in sufficient depth.
The Committee also claimed:
Any entrenchment of the existence of Local Government should take place in State Constitutions under which it exists.

In the last decade, four of the six States have recognised local government in their State Constitutions. Victoria did it in 1979, as did Western Australia; South Australia did so in 1980, and New South Wales in 1986. So local government is recognised constitutionally in four of the six States. Tasmania and Queensland are the only States not to have accepted the invitation to the States to recognise local government in their Constitutions, as suggested by the Constitutional Convention in 1976.

It is obvious that the Liberal and National parties are copping a lot of criticism from local government for their attitude to this proposal, but I believe that at the end of the day it will be the policies of the respective parties that form the basis for the judgment by local government on the will to recognise local government and to do for it what local government needs to have done. If that is the case, it will be very interesting to compare the records of the two major parties in this area. It was a Liberal-National government-the Fraser Government-that first gave local government a fixed funding arrangement through personal income tax sharing back in the 1970s. It was the same Fraser Government that provided for local government representation on the States grants commissions and which provided for distribution of the personal income tax share. It was the Fraser Government, and Mr Ralph Hunt while Minister for Transport in that Government, that introduced the bicentennial road funding levy of 2c a litre to provide more road funds for local government. It was the Fraser Government that set up a forum for local government in the form of the Advisory Council for Inter-governmental Relations and gave local government an equal and recognised share as the legitimate and very important third tier of government.

They are the types of measures and the record that the Liberal and National parties can point to in their attitudes towards local government. They have been very positive, very tangible and real benefits accorded to local government when compared with Labor's record on local government. In 1986 it disbanded the only forum that was available to local government in the form of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations; it has pegged back the 2 per cent personal income tax sharing formula to a less favourable formula, with conditions to its payment related to population, to the detriment of need; it has reduced road funding in real terms over the Hawke Government's period in office by more than 25 per cent in real terms; and it has flawed the amendment to the constitutional proposal now before honourable senators, for example, by specifically excluding Australian territories.

The referendum question that is to be put, looked at in essence, contains nothing of substance, nothing of benefit to local government. Indeed, on quite reasonable interpretations of that amendment one could say that, far from advancing the cause of local government, the proposition contained in the Bill before us sets back the cause of local government. It does not give local government any of the beneficial recognition it needs. It entrenches local government constitutionally as a creature of the States.
