Those are issues that local government itself has fought strenuously against.

I would put it to the Minister in the chamber, the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), that if the Government is serious about according due, proper and meaningful recognition to local government, surely it could not have come up with the amendment that it has proposed. I ask the Minister, when he is responding to these comments from this side of the House, if he could explain to me and to the chamber the advantages that he sees and that the Government sees in this proposal so far as local government is concerned, because any reading of the proposal makes it very difficult to see those advantages. As I said, I think it is something which is going to prove highly counterproductive to the cause of local government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a short contribution to this committee stage debate on this legislation, particularly as this debate unfolds, on a couple of arguments which are being put by the Opposition, which I believe need to be addressed and on which I think it is important to make clear the position of the Australian Democrats. I first focus on a couple of comments made thus far in the debate, one by Senator Chaney in his conclusion, that we should leave local government alone, and another by Senator Short, that there is nothing of benefit to local government in this Constitutional Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988. I believe those comments, amongst others, indicate clearly, as I said in my contribution during the second reading stage, a certain arrogance on behalf of politicians of one sphere and level of government with regard to those in another sphere. I say that only because we are here dealing with a Bill which is designed to change the Constitution of this country, to include in that Constitution for the first time the third tier of government in this country, local government.

SPEECH.PARA: If one speaks to people who are involved in that tier, as opposed to people in this chamber engaged in this debate, one gets a totally different argument. I think it is important that in this Committee debate that voice is heard. I do not believe that we, as Federal politicians elected by the people, should presume to speak in the sort of way that the Opposition is presuming to speak for those people elected at a different tier of government, even though we may be paid for what we do and even though we may have to turn up at our properly constituted meetings perhaps more often than they do. I do not think, nor do the rest of the Australian Democrats, that gives us any particular right to speak on behalf of our colleagues at the local government level. I think it is important in this debate that they are represented so that their voice can be heard.

One of the issues raised in this debate is that this is mere tokenism. Senator Short referred to the fact that this does not really do very much for local government. If I may present the voice of those people who are in local government, the Municipal Association of Victoria had something to say about that argument put by the Opposition in this debate, when in a Press release which it issued in the past week or so, in response to claims of tokenism, it said:

Some Liberals have told us privately that they support the notion of constitutional recognition for local government but they think people will be confused if they advocate a `no' vote for some questions and a `yes' vote for others.
Now that's real tokenism. And it's an insult to the collective intelligence of local communities.
A bit of respect for the rights of local communities is not too much to expect and I would urge the Opposition to change its stance on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. What Senator Powell is saying is not correct and is indeed an insult to our Party. I do not think Senator Powell should read media comments and take them as gospel. What she has just said is not true.
—Order! That is not a point of order. Senator Walters may speak in the debate if she wishes.

—For the benefit of the chamber I will clarify what I was reading from. It is not a media comment but a document written by the Municipal Association of Victoria. I do not know whether it appeared in the media, but I certainly believe, since it appears on its letterhead, and it was sent to me directly by the Association, it does express its viewpoint. If it is an insult to anybody, I am sure that needs to be taken up with the body concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pick up another couple of points which have already been made and which I am sure members of the National Party of Australia will refer to when speaking in the committee debate. One is that this move to change the Constitution is centralising power in the hands of the Federal Government. That was certainly the claim made by Mr Cobb in the other place and by Mr Sinclair, the Leader of the National Party. Yet I noted just a few minutes ago in this debate that Senator Short said the reverse, that this will entrench more power in the States. I would suggest that we are already seeing a debate for the No case, if you like, by the Opposition which is at the very least somewhat confused. I think it will be fascinating to see it unfold.

Going back to the claim that there is nothing of benefit in this for local government, I think it is important to point out what local government itself says is of benefit on this Bill. We cannot put all of the comments on the record right now, but certainly local government does not agree that recognition will centralise power. On the contrary, it believes that it will strengthen the system of decentralised community based government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your views rather than theirs? That is just pandering to interest groups.

—I welcome the question about our view. I made it clear in the debate at the second reading stage that the Democrats' view is very strongly supportive of what local government wants. We have listened to local government and we are not ashamed to stand here today and have its voice heard in this committee stage. In fact, our view accords with the local government position. We have never at any stage of this debate said that this Bill is perfect, that this move is the ultimate move. But at the same time we believe that the Constitution of this country is a growing, developing document and should be. Therefore this kind of change, as long as it advances the cause and is supported, is worth pursuing.

SPEECH.PARA: The local government people believe that the very act of recognition, which is pursued by this Bill and by the subsequent referendum, will mean that State and Federal bureaucrats and politicians will be more ready to consult with local government, and that is a very important issue. For those and all the other reasons which have already been stated by me on behalf of the Democrats in this debate, we very strongly support this legislation and the subsequent referendum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the next speaker I would like to draw the Committee's attention to the way this debate is developing. This is not a debate on whether we wish to have this particular Bill, as that has already been determined at the second reading stage. What the Committee is supposed to be devoting its attention to is the working of the clauses of the Bill. The general philosophical principles and desirability of the Bill were determined at the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address the technical aspects of the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, because I think it is very significant that the Constitutional Commission recommended a form of words which have not been adopted by the Government. It talked about local government bodies. There have been a vast array of suggestions as to an appropriate form of recognition advanced by various interest groups on behalf of local government. The one that the Government has finally hit upon is not one that has been the subject of those recommendations, but is merely a form of words lifted from the State Constitutions. That is very significant because, in reality, that is where the matter should reside. Currently, four States provide for a system of local government. Hopefully, two others will join them in the not too distant future.
—Tasmania will join them.
—Good; we are almost there.
—And Phillip Island.
—Queensland.

—Phillip Island and Queensland are on the way. We have almost reached the stage where we can safely say that all the State governments provide for appropriate recognition of local government. That is the place for it to be granted, because it is only at that point that there is a capacity to make local adjustments and to decide whether local government is needed in certain areas, whether a dismissal needs to be followed by a period of appointment, followed by a form of re-election, and whether levels of funding should differ over the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that if we go for a form of words such as those in the referendum proposal, we achieve precisely the opposite. That point was made by Sir John Moore's distribution of powers committee, the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations and Dr Cheryl Saunders. They made the point that, once we provide for a recognition of local government, we inevitably encourage the High Court of Australia to provide an expansive interpretation-in other words, an interpretative vacuum into which the High Court would inevitably move. We would then find a national prescription being laid down by the High Court-not with any malintent, but simply because a form of words needs clarification. Of course, many local government bodies would seek just that. We would end up with a national prescription that would be quite inappropriate to reflect the variations that should and do apply across the nation.

The local government movement does itself a gross disservice by settling, if it does, for the form of words that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has proposed in the most cynical way. I note that in his speech yesterday to a local government congress he talked about a new and exciting era of local government flowing from what he described as significant constitutional change. That is hogwash. On one view, one can argue that that is a form of tokenism. I think that there is some substance to that in the sense that that is all that the Government intended. However, the matter which we must address much more seriously is the likely interpretation that will be placed on those words and the likely consequence that will flow.

One cannot do better than to refer to a document which my colleague Shirley Walters circulated recently which points out that there are a number of ways in which local government will be disadvantaged by the proposal. It could well result in the lowest common denominator being imposed across the nation, which would not be in the best interests of local government. There would be no protection against dismissal. That is made clear by the wording in the explanatory memorandum, which recognises the right of a State to determine, having regard to the nature of a particular region and other relevant circumstances, that it would not be appropriate for a region to be administered by a local government body. That is not simply talking about areas that do not have local government currently. It would be just as appropriate to areas that currently have it.

Again, I think that local government is deluded if it believes that this measure provides some form of safeguards. Indeed, only this afternoon, in talking to a prominent activist in the local government field, it was suggested to me that this recognition would provide an entree for local government to achieve attendance at meetings of the Australian Loan Council and State grants commissions. I do not think that that would follow. Indeed, the person I spoke to conceded that that was more a hope than any interpretation that one might place on the words. Again, I think it shows how one can be easily deluded.

At the same time that the Government is offering what it no doubt sees as harmless words, it is reducing the amount of money available to local government, cutting back on road funding and hoping that local government will remain quiescent because it is being offered something. That something is, I think, a very poisoned chalice because it could well emerge that local government will rue the day if such an amendment came into force and where then the subject of interpretation by the High Court. It certainly would not protect against amalgamations. One has only to recall the furious political activity that ensued in Victoria when the Cain Government was stupid enough to attempt to force amalgamations down the throats of a number of shires and municipalities. There would be no protection at all under this general expression, nor indeed would there be protection in a number of other areas. That is where I think the real vice lies.

It is clear that the Government would like to pretend that it is offering very significant protections, but the reality is that it is offering virtually nothing but uncertainty, which I think will be to the cost of local government. To the extent that it will make it harder to appoint administrators in the wake of incompetent or dishonest local government administrations, it will do the whole conduct of local government a disservice. Yet it has been suggested that, because there is provision for a system, somehow limits would be imposed that would require only a reasonable period to elapse between the dismissal of a council and the election of a replacement. I do not accept that for one moment. The Melbourne City Council was sacked and remained sacked I think for about 18 months. In another instance, the Sydney City Council had its services dispensed with for quite some time. Sunshine and Keilor councils similarly had their services terminated.

There is no doubt that flexibility is very necessary. It would be fatuous to suggest simply that, having sacked one group of elected councillors, we must immediately elect another. Quite often what is needed is a breathing space in which the problems can be sorted out and in which others who might not be tainted by past irregularities can be encouraged to come forward. This would therefore, allow a much healthier form of local democracy to emerge. Yet local government seems to be deluded into thinking that, by having this constitutional referendum proposal carried, it would somehow be afforded protection of that sort. To the extent that it did, I think it would be unhelpful and, to the extent that it does not, it does not alter the status quo.

One can say, again, that the form of words would give rise to very serious concerns. As Senator Short outlined not so long ago, we have a very proud record in this regard. One has only to go through the history of the late 1970s and early 1980s to see all that we did for local government. All those things had a common thread to them-that is, they provided security of office and underpinned the very important work that is undertaken by local government. The last thing that anyone on this side of the chamber would want to do is diminish the role of local government. Yet the Government is pretending that, by proposing this form of words, it will be able to distract attention from its own lack of financial and other commitment to local government. That is a short-sighted tragedy.

It is clear that we have a record of which we should be proud. The Prime Minister and others who would run around with canards such as, `The Opposition's position is one of expediency; it has simply chosen to vote no because it is convenient in some unexplained manner' is in total ignorance of the facts, which are that this decision was taken by the Liberal and National parties on the basis of principle and after a careful consideration of the issues involved, bearing in mind the consequences for the system of government which would thereby emerge, the consequences that would be placed on both Federal and State governments and the very real needs of local government.

In my judgment, it is not sufficient to accede to something simply because someone asks for it. It seemed to be the thrust of Senator Powell's contribution that, because local government wanted it, it had to be a good thing. The Government of this country would be in chaos if we responded to interest groups simply by caving in to their requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an interest group; this is a legitimate tier of government.

—That is absolutely so. We do not for one moment seek to denigrate its importance or role. But we have an obligation, as members of this chamber, to analyse the referendum proposal in a way that does not seem to have been undertaken by the Australian Democrats.
—What about local government? They analysed it.

—I am not sure that that is so. I understand that many people's minds were well and truly made up before the referendum question was announced. Many people who wrote to us-and no doubt to Senator Powell and others-made it perfectly clear that, whatever form of words emerged, they would be enthusiastically in favour of the proposal. I think that that sort of myopia does a grave disservice to the role that we should carry out as legislators. A small example, I suppose, is the Metropolitan Municipal Association, which wrote to me, amongst others. It said that it would strongly support the proposal which might emerge. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: According to recent press reports, Constitutional Recognition . . . may be the subject of a referendum . . .
This Association strongly supports this proposal . . .
It was in favour of the proposal before it knew what it stated. It continued:
amongst other considerations, it would allow Local Government to participate more fully in the design, delivery and co-ordination of public policies and programmes.
The present system of `symbolic recognition' is considered most inadequate . . .

One cannot have it both ways. The Association wants meaningful involvement in the processes of government. That is precisely what we would offer. We believe that local government's needs are met, not by empty rhetoric but by being given sufficient funds to carry out its obligations, by assistance and involvement in the various decision-making processes and not by empty phrases casually thrown around by a cynical Prime Minister.

If we address the actual terms of the proposal, we see that it contains words that have not been proposed anywhere else; that open up a whole series of problems that will ultimately require interpretation by the High Court; that will do no great service to local government; and that will not in any way be compatible with the structure of the Constitution as it is presently formed. What local government needs, deserves and must have is a comprehensive regime of protections provided at State level by those governments which are best placed to make regular adjustments to meet those real needs. Hopefully, that will occur in the not too distant future. The progress of local government will not be assisted in any way by the constitutional referendum proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a short contribution to the committee stage of the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988. In doing so, I think I can say that we all recognise and appreciate the work of local government. We have always said that there are three tiers of government: the Federal tier-the Commonwealth; State government; and local government. I believe that local government is close to people and their problems. I also feel that those in local government are not terribly well paid for the work that they do. They provide a real service to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I, like many other people, have received letters from various councils complaining bitterly that the Opposition has decided to oppose this referendum question on local government. The Randwick Council was one council that wrote to me. I presume that it wrote to every senator and Federal member about the same matter. The President of the Local Government Association, Councillor Peter Kyle, said the same thing.

What is being proposed is the insertion of a new section 119a in the Constitution to the effect that each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer and make by-laws for their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State. No mention is made in that of any move by the Commonwealth to recognise local government, except, of course, in the referendum question. We should remember that point.

I believe that all State governments support local government. Already, four State governments have recognised local government in their constitutions. I understand from Senator Walters and Senator Boswell that the Tasmanian and Queensland governments are working towards that end. I do not think that this proposal that we are examining tonight is of any benefit to local government. We must be very careful to ensure that it is not the start of a move to centralise power in Canberra. Of course, during the time of Mr Whitlam's Government there was great talk about the abolition of the States. I would not like to think that this legislation represented the beginning of that process.

TALK.START.PARA: —This might be a start in that direction.

—It might be a start in that direction. My concern is that the proposed amendment could be open to an unduly wide interpretation. It has been very broadly defined. Recent decisions of the High Court dealing with external affairs powers do nothing to allay any fears that we might have in this regard. I wrote to Randwick Council that actions speak louder than words. Our record on this side of the chamber is very good. Senator Short gave a very good exposition of what had been done by our parties when we were in government to assist local government in a very practical way. Local government ought to recognise that that is what we have done. We have been very anxious to help local government in a practical way.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a Liberal-National Party government that first gave local government a fixed funding arrangement through personal income tax sharing. Local governments want to know how much money they will get from tax sharing. It saddens me that the amount given to local government under this arrangement has fallen from 2 per cent, when our parties were in government, to 1.66 per cent. I do not believe that this Government has provided local government with very much, a part from words. I think about the road funding crisis. Not enough money is made available to local government for roads. Every senator would have had many letters from councils in this regard.

As I said earlier, I appreciate local governments. I believe that State governments appreciate them, too. We must be careful that this Bill does not herald the reintroduction of regionalism that was so favoured by Mr Whitlam. Funding arrangements could force amalgamations. Local government should think about some of these matters. If we are to recognise local government, as Senator Short said, we want to do so in a meaningful way. I have contributed to this debate to say that actions speak louder than words. The proposal contained in this Bill says things about local governments but will not do anything for them. I do not think that there is any real need for the Bill, and we will vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like Senator Bjelke-Petersen, will be brief. I support the question that the Minister has already been asked: Why did the Government change the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission? The $6m Constitutional Commission recommended that a certain form of words be contained in the proposal. The Government changed it to `a system of local government'. It used the word `State' twice. Senator Short in his speech implied why that was done, as did Senator Chaney. The reason, of course, is that this enshrinement of local government in the Federal Constitution will only make the power of the States stronger. It will enshrine their rights to hire and fire at will. If we are to believe the explanatory memorandum that accompanies the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, they would not only be able to hire and fire at will, but would also be able to act in accordance with paragraph 4 of the explanatory memorandum, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Section 119a is not intended to oblige a State to establish local government bodies throughout the whole of the State. A State would be free to determine that, having regard to the nature of a particular region and other relevant circumstances, it would not be appropriate for the region to be administered by a local government body.

I listened with interest to what Senator Powell had to say. I took exception to her comment that we on this side of the chamber were presuming to speak on behalf of local government but were not qualified to do so. I inform Senator Powell that, to my knowledge, there are between 30 and 40 former members of local government involved in this side of politics. I was in local government until March of this year. In my 12 years in local government I spent four years as warden. In fact, my senior secretary is a member of a local government council. So if anybody is entitled to talk on local government it is those on this side of the chamber.

Thanks to my very sympathetic Whip I spent a couple of hours at the local government conference this morning to get a feel of what is going on. Unfortunately, local government believes-this was put to me-that Federal constitutional recognition is a start. As a former member of local government and one who is very sympathetic to local government, as far as I am concerned it is not a start, it is a finish of local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They've had their recognition.

—It has its recognition and that is the finish of it. We have a conjuring trick from the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saying how good they are to local government. I have seen Prime Minister Hawke working in Tasmania. He came down and addressed some of our local government members at a cricket ground that I was involved with. He made a lot of promises and said how much he loved local government and that it has always been sweet to his heart. He said a few bleating words to our warden and then waltzed off. The Minister for Justice was also there on that day. A couple of weeks later we received a letter to say that unfortunately the Prime Minister could not help with further funds for the oval. So much for the soft spot in his heart for local government!

SPEECH.PARA: Local government has believed for years with a great amount of feeling that it should be recognised. The situation has become so bad that I think local government almost feels as if it is a quest for the Holy Grail. I would liken it to someone waiting for a bus: after waiting all day all of a sudden a bus comes along and the person grabs it-the first one. Local government is hopping on Senator Reynolds's bus but unfortunately it is heading down the wrong road. When local government gets down the road far enough and wakes up and sees what is going on it will find--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are really insulting local government.

—I am not insulting it. When the thinking people in local government come to set their budgets in June and July and have to front their ratepayers with 10, 15 and 20 per cent increases in rates, what will they say? Will they say, `It is not our fault. We have got constitutional recognition'? What is really happening is that while this Government is waving its magic wand and making believe that it really believes in local government, it is ripping the money off it hand over fist. Every grants commission around Australia, apart from one, has pointed out that local government has received reduced funds. We have seen the great reductions in road funds. The other day Senator Reynolds said, `Next year we are not going to reduce road funds to local government. We're taking special notice of that. We are going to give them the same moneys they had last year. But we are going to reduce the money for the States'. People should not to be so stupid as to think that it will not be passed on. I have been in local government long enough to know that everything ends up at local government. That is where the buck stops if we have a buck. That is the way it goes.
—You were going to be brief.

—I will be. I have just one other query for the Minister. No-one has commented on this point yet. We are to presume that the measures set out in explanatory memoranda will come into being because of the Acts Interpretation Act, but I would like to ask the Minister whether this would apply to the Constitution and not to Acts of Parliament. It has been put to me that the Acts Interpretation Act applies only to Acts of Parliament and not to the Constitution. If that is the case, and it is seen in that way, the wording of the Bill will stand alone. What happens if it does stand alone? We would have this meaningless system of local government elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer and to make by-laws for its respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State. That is what we will have, that is what local government will have and that will be the end of it. The High Court of Australia and everybody else will be hamstrung because the explanatory memoranda will not count for anything. I would like the Minister to assure me that the High Court will not see it in that way and that the Acts Interpretation Act will be able to be used along with the Bill in question. If it is not, the legislation really does sell out local government entirely. With these words I will allow my colleague from Tasmania to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman--
—He is an odd looking Tasmanian.

—I am certainly not a senator for Tasmania but I always support the Tasmanian Liberals because they speak sense in this Parliament. I have no problem in associating myself with their remarks. What we are debating tonight poses this question to all of us here: What is a system of local government? Senator Chaney, an eminent barrister, posed that question. There is another senator here who is a prominent solicitor. A number of such people do not have the slightest idea what the wording means. So how will the people out there who will vote on this proposal understand the question? With a great deal of difficulty. If the barristers and solicitors in this Parliament cannot understand what a system of local government means and how it will be interpreted by the High Court of Australia, it will be very difficult for the average person in the street to make an objective judgment on that.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that local government has always been a product of State governments. If we vote for this Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill I am not entirely convinced that we will not be handing over the power of the local governments in the Federal system of government. I have recently been to the western areas of Queensland and have spoken to a number of local shire councils. I had no difficulty whatsoever in convincing the chairpersons of the shires that they are on a very dangerous course. I have acceptance of my argument. I have asked them: `If local government is recognised by the Federal Government what course will be taken and what will happen if the Federal Government wants to amalgamate smaller shires as a system of local government?'. Local government will have no power to object; it will have no State government to come to its aid. The divisions could possibly be equal in Queensland local government. There are a number of smaller shire councils which have large town divisions but smaller country divisions. I tell them that the Labor Government wants one vote one value for the State and Federal systems of government. It will probably try to form local government divisions into equal voting proportions so there will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —They will do it by funding.

—It will do it somehow but there will possibly be a thousand votes in a town and three or four hundred votes out in the country divisions. The present system will go. I am also concerned because in Queensland we have 31 Aboriginal and island councils that have local government status. The High Court could well give an interpretation that the Aboriginal communities, if they are recognised under the Australian Constitution as a system of government, are the responsibility of the Federal Government. After what Mr Hand has done to the Aboriginal and Islander communities they will run a mile from any further involvement in the Federal system of government. Mr Hand has just sacked eight people from the Board of the Aboriginal Development Commission because they would not do what he required them to do. They are not enamoured of Mr Hand to such an extent that they will be further involved in the federal system of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Who would have thought that two little words under section 51 of the Constitution could have usurped the power of all local and State governments in the World Heritage area? I warn all local governments in Queensland, which are always worried about the centralisation of power in Canberra and about the erosion of State rights, that they could be heading down exactly that track aiding and abetting the Federal Government. It is possible that any words that are added to the Constitution will lend themselves to interpretation by the High Court. We have seen this in regard to the World Heritage area under the external powers treaty. This Government has taken over the power of 12 to 15 local governments in the tropical wetlands of north Queensland as well as taking over the power of the Queensland elected State government. All these things can happen and have happened. They have happened before because of an interpretation by the High Court. Who knows what the High Court of Australia will be made up of in another 10 or 15 years?

I suppose this Bill will go through with the help of the Australian Democrats, who have lost all credibility tonight. They should hang their heads in shame. They have proved that they are the running dogs of the Labor Party. They had the opportunity tonight to put a good, honest, open question to the people of Australia, but they made a deal with the Government to cement themselves in this place on about 3 per cent of the vote. I have absolutely no respect now for the Democrats. I did have some respect when their former leader was in this House. He tried to keep them on the straight and narrow. But they have demeaned themselves and are now just an attachment to the Labor Party. People who are considering supporting the Democrats would be far better off supporting the Labor Party. At least they would know what it is doing.

Two or three years ago Senator Vigor, of the Australian Democrats, proposed a system of proportional representation for the local government of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). That proposal was rejected by the Government and it failed. Now a deal has been done between the Government and the Democrats. The Government will support a system of proportional representation for the ACT. Why will the Government support it? It will support the proposal because it will probably give the Democrats a voice in local government in the ACT. Why has the Government suddenly changed its direction since this proposal was made 12 or 18 months ago? It is becoming common in this place for deals to be made between the Democrats and the Government. It is a waste of a vote to vote for the Democrats. That vote would be better placed supporting the Labor Party. At least we know where it stands. It is issuing the legislation; the Democrats are joining the Government. I ask honourable senators on this side of the chamber: How many times have the Democrats voted with the Opposition in this session of Parliament? It is probably only three of four times in the last six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once.

—Senator Panizza says that the Democrats have supported the Opposition on one occasion in the last six or eight sitting weeks. That is how the Democrats are supposed to be keeping us honest. There has been one deal after another. The Democrats have lost all credibility tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat: I warn local government shires that they are getting into something that they do not understand. They are getting into bed with a Federal government that wants to restrict them, that wants one vote one value, and that will cause the divisions to have equal strength, which will absolutely wreck local government in rural Queensland. They are leaving themselves wide open for a High Court challenge on an interpretation that could lead to amalgamations, regionalisations and everything that Queensland and every other local government in Australia want to avoid at any price.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The extraordinary thing about the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, which is before us, is its slenderness. What it says, apart from the short title, is that it proposes to insert a new section in the Constitution. The proposed new section reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government . . .

With the exception of two States, that is already in being. Only Queensland and Tasmania do not have such a system. Tasmania, I gather, is in the course of introducing one. So that proposal does nothing for four of the States. It goes on:
with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

That is the full ambit of what is proposed to be inserted in the Constitution at the forthcoming referendum on this matter. One is led to ask: Is that all? In view of the high expectations which have been aroused in local government circles by all the Government's false promises and posturing on this matter, one is bound to say that this Bill is a fraud. It is true that all four of the referendum Bills before the Parliament are, to a greater or lesser degree, frauds, but this is the most palpable fraud that I, at any rate, have seen for a very long time. I sit here every day looking at the Government side of the chamber, so I have some experience in seeing the processes of fraud.

Local governments, of course, have not fully appreciated yet the hoax which the Federal Government is in the process of perpetrating upon them. They are running around the country expressing gratitude, love and admiration for the Australian Labor Party for recognising them. It is true that they are being recognised and they are being given the back of the Government's hand in the process. I can only say that if the local government spokesman gets satisfaction out of that, I am glad on their account, but, I have to say, it indicates a considerable lack of comprehension on their part as to what is actually being done for them. As several speakers have already indicated-I, therefore, will not elaborate on the same point again-this puts the whole area of local government into the hands of the High Court of Australia, into the hands of legal interpretation by non-elected persons.
I have some other comments to make on the Bill. I support entirely what Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Boswell said.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner suspension I was in the process of commenting very briefly on what appear to be a couple of the major misconceptions which the Government appears to have been successful in generating in the minds of some of our local authority representatives throughout Australia in the aftermath of its decision to introduce the Bill we are currently discussing. I will mention a couple of those misconceptions. One was voiced only the other day by the lord mayor of one of our largest local authorities, a person for whom I have the utmost respect but who quite clearly simply had not read the Bill or anything else associated with the Bill. That lord mayor voiced the opinion that once this referendum was passed, as the person in question trusted it would be, it would be impossible thereafter for State governments to dismiss any local authority or behave in a similar way.

SPEECH.PARA: I have since had occasion to point out to the person concerned that that is a total misconception. Not only is it a misconception of a general kind in so far as the Bill does nothing to hobble or in any way inhibit the powers of State governments in that regard, but the second reading speech on this Bill in the House of Representatives by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen)-and, indeed, the speech of the Minister in this place-points out:
The provision is not intended to prevent State governments from providing for the amalgamation of local government councils or for their dismissal on grounds of incompetence or malpractice.
It goes on:
It is expected, however, that the States will need to make provision for the election of new councils within a reasonable time after any such dismissal.

That is the case today, so there is no change there. I cite that simply as an example of the kind of misconception that apparently is quite prevalent among our local authority representatives as to what this Bill means. The truth is that the Bill means nothing at all other than that it `recognises' the existence of local governments within the Commonwealth Constitution-much good may it do them. It will not do them any good at all; that is the point.

As Senator Alston, who I think spoke very well on this Bill late this afternoon, pointed out, at a meeting of local authority representatives he had been to today in this city, a number of people had expressed the quite mistaken understanding that if this referendum should be passed it would in some undefined way give local government access to major financial forums such as the Premiers Conference or Loan Council meetings, at which they could hope to influence the amounts of moneys to be provided either by way of grants or borrowing authorities to local authorities throughout the country. That is totally untrue. The Bill will affect that position in no way.

The Commonwealth Government, if it wished, today could invite representatives of local authorities to attend in some observer capacity either the Premiers Conference or-perhaps somewhat less clearly, but nevertheless it would be within its power-Local Council meetings as observers. But this Government does not choose to, previous governments of different complexions did not choose to, and I suspect that in future governments similarly will not choose to because they will take the view that these meetings are for discussions between the Commonwealth Government and State governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first and second tiers.

—The first and second tiers, as Senator Crichton-Browne quite rightly observes. Whether that be appropriate or inappropriate is not the point of these remarks. The point of these remarks is simply to point out-I hope to put this to rest at least in the mind of anybody who may be listening-that this Bill will do nothing whatsoever to open the doors of those sanctums to local authority representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are in fact speaking just briefly about financial concerns of local authorities and whether this referendum will do anything to ease those concerns, let me just very quickly make a point which I think was made by one or two earlier speakers, namely, that this Government has shown its total hypocrisy. On the one hand it is weeping crocodile tears about the need to recognise local authorities with the Bill which we are presently debating. On the other hand, in last Wednesday night's economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the Government announced a cut of $20m in the funds to be provided in 1988-89 by the Commonwealth Government to local authorities. In addition, in the same economic statement, the Treasurer announced that the Government would, next financial year, cut the funds the Commonwealth provides for road funding in the States by $50m.

In its usual weasel word manner, the Australian Labor Party has sought to protect itself against the charge that this will also mean a cut in road funding for local authorities by saying that it will preserve unchanged the funding for local authorities within the total of such funding to be provided in 1988-89 and that therefore this is not a cut in local authority road funding. That is, of course, a deceitful argument because while technically that will be the effect of what the Government has decided, in practice what will undoubtedly happen-it is as plain as the nose on the face of anybody who has ever had experience in these matters-is that the State governments will then cut the amounts of funds which they make available to local authorities for roads, not because they have any particular desire to hurt local authorities, but because they will be $50m worse off, and they will take some of that $50m out of the hide of local authorities as well as out of our own hides. On both counts, this Government has shown its total hypocrisy in its attitude or its asserted concern for the position and problems of local authorities. What it has done is actually to show by its actions-that is to say, by its revenue reducing actions-what it thinks of them while, at the same time, uttering a lot of fine words about recognising them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 which seeks to add a new section 119a to the Constitution which refers to local government. My colleagues have already advanced very good reasons for the position which my Party is taking and which the coalition parties are taking. I do not wish to rehearse those arguments. My intervention will be mercifully brief. My concern for local government really relates to the people who devote their time and their efforts to serving with local government and, particularly, to some of the women in Australia who have chosen to become active in politics, starting through local government service.

SPEECH.PARA: After the recent Liberal Party Federal Council meeting, we had the Second National Liberal Women's Conference on the Monday following the Federal Council. At that conference two papers were presented, one by the Hon. Rosemary Varty, MLC, entitled Women and Politics-`A State Perspective', and the other by Councillor Wendy Spry, the mayor of Prahran in Melbourne, entitled Women and Politics-A Local Government Perspective. In those two papers these two elected representatives set down some of the problems which women face in serving at local and State level the citizens of their municipalities and of their States. They are significant contributions to the debate. I seek leave of the Senate to table the documents in order to make them available to all honourable senators.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I discuss the alleged benefits the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988 will provide to local government perhaps I might for a moment examine whether local government has a place at all in the Australian Constitution. As we examine that proposition perhaps we need to remind ourselves as senators of the object of the Federal Constitution in the first place. The Constitution is a document drafted and created by the representatives of the various original States. Its intention was to give unto the Federal Parliament the power to make laws which may properly be described as relevant to matters of an interstate nature or an international nature, or at least certainly having those characteristics.

SPEECH.PARA: The Constitution purposely excluded matters which were exclusively of an intrastate nature-matters which can and are best managed at a State level. Of course, that meant all matters which could be dealt with without effect to those outside the borders of each State or matters which would not impinge upon those of other States. Those matters are found within State legislation and they are found within the State constitutions. Of course, that separation of powers did not flow from some arbitrary or capricious decision of our founding fathers but, of course, from a fundamental reality that the laws affecting individuals are fairest in their design and in their application when they are created and are administered as close to the people they affect as is realistically practical. Of course, the natural gravitation of power through its devolution to those upon whom it touches is, of course, democracy in its finest form and in its pristine state. Australia is one of those few democracies in which we have laws made for the good government of the people who are removed 3,000 miles at least in the one land mass from the source of that power. The very size of Australia is the cause of our system of federation.

As I say, the Constitution provides quite specific enumerated powers to the Commonwealth. Of course, the balance of all other powers is provided to the States. There are 128 clauses in the Constitution which by and large set out in precise terms those powers which were intended to be given unto the Commonwealth from those colonial States at the time of Federation. Under that criterion alone, local government ought not to have a place in our Federal Constitution. It ought quite properly to be found in State constitutions. Of course, in the case of Western Australia it is. Its Constitution deliberately provides:

52. (1) The Legislature shall maintain a system of local governing bodies elected and constituted in such manner as the Legislature may from time to time provide. (2) Each elected local governing body shall have such powers as the Legislature may from time to time provide being such powers as the Legislature considers necessary for the better government of the area in respect of which the body is constituted.

There is a further section 53 that gives some added meat to those first two proposals. Mr Temporary Chairman, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the history of local government in Western Australia. This is a brief resume to be found in the 1985 Constitutional Convention debate on local government by Standing Committee A.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many pages is it?
—It is very brief; it is not a page, but a paragraph or so.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(2) HISTORICAL DEVELOPMENT

2.1 Prior to the 1840's the English Colonial government had tried to institute Local Government systems based on the English pattern. These very early attempts at local government in the colony were generally unsuccessful-the reasons being many and varied. The nature of the people and the conditions in the colony contributed to their lack of success as did the imposition of rates on unwilling citizens; a scarcity of members of the leisured class with time to spare on local matters; a sparsely populated and isolated countryside; a lack of local and social unity of common interests and the often imposition of schemes which were, in retrospect, too ambitious.

2.2 As communities became more settled, the people gradually recognized the need for a system of Local Government and began to agitate for its implementation. For example, in 1838, the colony of Western Australia legislated to establish town trusts in response to the determination by rural settlers to control and upgrade roads. In 1841, the residents or Melbourne were clamouring for more services than could be provided by public companies and thus in 1842, the municipality of Melbourne was incorporated. By approximately the 1850's municipal councils had been established in all the States' major cities.

2.3 The 1850's saw the growth of inland towns servicing a large rural sector and the consequential development of comprehensive municipal systems. In the colonies of Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia these systems were generally permissive. As responsible government was not established in Victoria until 1856, South Australia until 1857 and Western Australia until 1890, it is clear that the extension of a Local Government system and establishment of local government bodies did not await the advent of responsible government, and proceeded largely independent of the political developments at the colonial level.

2.4 Van Dieman's Land, New South Wales and Queensland achieved comprehensive permission municipal systems after the establishment of responsible government. Van Dieman's Land achieved an extensive comprehensive permissive local government system by the implementation of the Rural Municipalities Act of 1858. The voluntary system of incorporation in New South Wales and Queensland resulted in very few municipal incorporations. It appears that services to a community in an unincorporated area were provided by self-help groups, government special purpose boards, and advisory non-statutory road trusts and committees. Thus, in these communities, local Parliamentarians were heavily relied upon to organize the funding of services and facilities. This system was not entirely satisfactory and by the 1870's there were moves for the creation of comprehensive mandatory municipal systems.

2.5 Mandatory systems had been imposed by legislation in all States by the early 1900's. In the States of Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia the transition from a permissive to a mandatory system was of less significance than in the other three States, as systems of Local Government had already been well-established (with the exception of more arid and sparsely populated areas) in these States.

2.6 In the last 80 years Local Government systems have continued to develop and adapt to the needs of the communities within each State. The Sub-Committee notes that there are differences in the municipal systems of each State and that differences are also apparent between municipal bodies within each State. The Sub-Committee considers that these differences are indicative of the adaptability and flexibility of Local Government throughout Australia today.

2.7 In 1945, at the Local Government Summer Schools the problems facing local government at that time were examined, and the Sub-Committee notes with considerable interest the fact that at one of these Summer Schools, Professor F. A. Bland advocated two alternative suggestions for a Local Government Charter. (See The Shire and Municipal Record, 1945 at p. 246). This Charter is now of historical interest only, having been drafted in a different time and to solve different problems. However the Sub-Committee considers that, as a general principle, the recognition of Local Government as a full partner with State and Federal Governments in the work of public administration was of importance from as long ago as 1945, when consideration was being given to formal recognition of Local Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That history clearly demonstrates that local government in Australia has, of course, responded to the needs and requirements of individual communities in individual geographical areas within the various States. In the case of Western Australia, the first proposals for local government were made when the colonial powers introduced legislation in 1838 for the purpose of setting up town trusts as a result of calls by the locals to have some influence, some say and some power over local roads. This is why they were originally called road boards in Western Australia. I do not know what they were called on the eastern seaboard. I think it was in either 1842 or 1848 that the colony of Victoria was next to set up a local government system. Local government evolved in a very successful and logical way, as one can imagine, as a result of its relationship with State governments. I again quote what Standing Committee A said about the evolutionary system:

SPEECH.PARA: Traditionally, Local Government has provided limited community services. Today, the services of Local Government to its community are many and varied, with each local authority developing services according to the needs of its communities. This evolution in the services provided has often been initiated from within the community, and Local Government has proved itself to be adaptable by adjusting to these community needs and expectations. This has been subject of course, to the availability of finances. Furthermore, the State governments have often delegated functions and duties to Local Government. Local Government has generally co-operated with the State Government and is often the best system in which certain services can be established, maintained and developed.

That is, of course, why it is called local government. Clearly this system of integration of local geographic concerns, when people had common interests and certain matters had common effects upon them, worked so well because it was so flexible and was able to develop and grow with the assistance of the various State governments. Its great virtue was the flexibility that was and is provided to local government by State governments. It just requires a sensitive and sensible State government to amend its legislation where necessary to accommodate the wishes and the aspirations of the local people to ensure that that sensitivity and flexibility is there.

Once we enshrine in the Constitution the role of local government-in this case, of course, it is simply a statement of principle-that flexibility is lost. When that happens we develop a rigid system that cannot be changed or adapted; it is just there. The local groups lose their capacity to reflect their aspirations or have them reflected in legislation somewhere else. To place something of meaning in the Constitution in respect of local government is to destroy local government. It is called local government because it is government by the local people. Once the Government puts local government into the Constitution and the laws are made by a Parliament 3,000 miles away, we can hardly suggest that that government is sensitive to the needs of local people.

We have before us a statement of principle. Anybody who has the slightest care for the Constitution, as Senator Tate has, never mind understanding, will know that the Australian Constitution was never intended to be, never was, is not and never will be a collection of statements of principle. Its provisions are all justiciable. Under those circumstances the statement of principle that the Government is seeking to put into the Constitution will also be justiciable and will be subject to the interpretation of the High Court.

Given that the recognition of local government in this Bill is no more than a statement of principle, who can guess, as Senator Chaney asked earlier, what might be the interpretation, and how wide might be the interpretation, by the High Court? In these circumstances, as Senator Tate will no doubt agree and nod in consent, this statement of principle with respect to local government sits as a total oddity among all the other statements in the Constitution. It is the only statement of principle, yet it sits there, in stark neon, totally incongruous with the Constitution.

Having said that, the words of this amendment, at least as one can read them, give no specific powers and no specific directions. For those who care for the Constitution, their inclusion just makes a mockery of the Constitution. It adds nothing to the Constitution. It simply undermines its intention. One asks oneself: Is there anything that this Labor Party will not corrupt? Is there anything that it will not seek to trample under foot? Is there anything that it will not seek to tear up? On this occasion it is simply seeking to prostitute the Constitution with a superficial appeal to the leaders of local government.

Finally, in respect of the appropriateness of the recognition of local government in the Federal Constitution, I remind honourable senators of what the Law Council of Australia has to say. The committee of the Law Council which is examining this matter is not of the view that the Commonwealth Constitution should deal with the position of local government. It quite properly points out that the Commonwealth Constitution is concerned with the sharing of powers between the national Government and the State governments, the first tier and the second tier of government. That is the total and absolute purpose of the Constitution. It resulted from a coming together of the colonies of Australia to write down the powers which they were giving unto a Federal Parliament and those which they would retain for themselves. Now, in this odd and incongruous way, the Government wishes to insert this rather obscene and absurd passage which does nothing for the Constitution except to belittle it and which adds nothing to local government. Not to understand that is to be blissfully unaware of the very essence of the Constitution or to abuse the purposes for which it is intended.

As the Law Council of Australia says, the basis of the Constitution is a compact between the various State governments which originally federated to form it. The Commonwealth cannot be overlooked. At the end of the day, if what is proposed to be put into the Constitution now is to have moment, if it is to mean anything, it will simply mean the subjugation of the States, the bypassing of the States, taking us back to the Whitlam era. He wanted to have regions of local government and the abolition of the States, as he said publicly, as this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said, as Bill Hayden has said and as the former Leader of the Australian Democrats has said. As I remember, the abolition of the States is still in the Australian Democrats' platform. It advocates a direct relationship-fiscal and financial-legally binding, between the Commonwealth Government and local government. The Law Council is of the view that a declaration of principles relating to the regulation of local government authorities in Australia ought not to be included in the Federal Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have often thought that it is not who you are that matters or even what you say, but it is what you do that matters. When it comes to what this Federal Government has done to local government, I think local government should take heed of that. With the $20m cut from local government in the May economic statement, the $50m that has been taken from it for road funding, the 25 per cent reduction in petrol levy funds that were due to local government, amounting to some millions and millions of dollars, and about the same reduction in the personal income tax sharing will local government, one can see just how much respect this Federal Government has for local government in Australia. The fact that the Government is trying to dress up these referenda proposals with something that may appear attractive to local government-which feels, I suppose, like an unrequited lover in Australia because it is being so badly treated-just shows how gullible local government can be. I understand that the Local Government Association of Australia is mounting a considerable campaign-and raising an enormous amount of money to fight it-to support the doctor that made it sick. It is supporting this referendum proposal, which to my mind is a complete anachronism when it should actually be fighting this Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal seeks to force two States, Queensland and Tasmania, to recognise local government in their Constitutions. I do not think the people of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia want to be involved in forcing their will on the people of Queensland and Tasmania. That is a vital issue. It is up to Queenslanders and Tasmanians to decide whether they are happy with their system of local government. The proposal envisages the implementation of a system of local government in the States. The Government has not defined what it means by `local government'. It has not defined what it means by the `recognition' of local government, and it has not defined what it means by a `system' of local government. Undoubtedly, all of those three terms will have to be defined. Where will they be defined? That will be done in the High Court of Australia, because after the passage of this legislation, once it becomes law, undoubtedly the whole thing will have to be decided in a court of law. I have not got all that much confidence in the current High Court to come to a decision that I think would be in accord with the wishes of the people of Australia.

Should this proposal become law, local government will be mentioned in the Constitution. By that very fact the Federal Government will have a responsibility for local government, and then it will want that responsibility defined. No-one should think that the Federal Government does not want control of local government. Of course it does, and it wants to gain control of it in exactly the same way as it is gaining control of the administration of Aboriginal lands; in other words, it wants to implement a whole system of regional developments with all the strings tied to Canberra and bypassing State and local government. The whole proposal is fraught with enormous dangers for local government. I just hope that it will see the light and reject the proposal wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal before the chamber is to give its concurrence to a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government. I do not think it is true to say, with Senator Stone, that it is nothing that recognition is granted. I believe it is very important that our basic document, which constitutes and in a sense celebrates the fact that we are fortunate to live in a democracy where elected representatives make the laws which govern our lives, contain a recognition of that tier of government which provides for many of the services and many of the facilities which are closest to the people in their everyday lives and habitations.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the Constitution was, as Senator Crichton-Browne quite correctly pointed out, conceived as a Federal compact does not, I think, mean that it can deal only with those matters of relationship between the Commonwealth, in the sense of the national parliament and government, and the States, which were the former colonies. In view of the fact that this document deals with our basic structure as a democracy, it is quite consistent that it should deal with local government. Indeed, the measure provides for the recognition of local government in a way which, quite deliberately, does not set out to fetter State parliaments in their provision for the system of local government that might be appropriate to their State. It simply looks to the provision of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer and to make by-laws for their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State. It was never our intention to fetter unduly the State parliaments in providing for that system of elected local government, but it should be a system of local government, of elected bodies.

It is true that amalgamation, reorganisation and dismissal will continue to be provided for under State law. Obviously, at the end of the day it will be required that a system of bodies elected in accordance with the laws of a State should continue. I believe that that can be achieved and ought to be seen as a considerable advance in the constitutional arrangements of Australia. I think local government throughout Australia sees this recognition as important. I believe that its expectations were not so advanced or high-whatever the phrase might be-that it finds our proposal absolutely dashes its hopes. Indeed, I believe that it fulfils many of its hopes and expectations over many decades and ought to be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not answered any of the questions that were put to him. I now give him the opportunity to do so.

—Many honourable senators have spoken. I regret to say that many made second reading-type comments and went on excursions into history and so on. What was asked for was an exposition of whether recognising local government in the Constitution in the way that is proposed in any way undermined the power of a State parliament or government to provide for the dismissal, for example, of a local authority that was acting in a corrupt or untoward way.
—What about State governments?

—We have said that the provision does not prevent the amalgamation or dismissal of particular local government bodies. That is the understanding that is set out in the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum.

—I have spoken only once at the committee stage of this debate. When I opened the committee's consideration of the Bill, I raised what appeared to be discrepancies in the interpretation of the clause in the explanatory notes and asked the Minister to address those matters. Quite frankly, I expect some response from him before we conclude our consideration of the Bill. If he does not intend to give us a response, I would appreciate knowing why. My questions raised the issues that we have raised generally on the referendums; namely, that we think there is an element of dishonesty in all of them. With respect to the first two, in common with the respected commentators that I have already quoted, we think that the questions being posed do not properly describe the changes to the Constitution which are being sought. With respect to this referendum on local government, I raised a series of legitimate queries about what the Government believes the change means and on what it bases that belief. It seems to me that there is a strong element of Alice in Wonderland in the explanatory memorandum-the words mean what the Government wants them to mean.
—They get curiouser and curiouser.

—Yes. Certainly, they do not appear to me to mean what the explanatory memorandum states. I also asked the Minister what I thought was a fairly civil and reasonable question which was also raised in the debate-although I was not present, I heard the broadcast of the proceedings-by my colleague Senator Alston. He raised the status of the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech with respect to interpretation. Whilst the Minister is tired, so are we, and we are likely to be much more tired if we do not get some reasonable response to these questions. I assume that his assistants have been making a note of the matters that have been raised. I would have thought that by now they would have given him some comment on them. I would like to know whether the Minister intends to respond.

—In relation to the Acts Interpretation Act, it is my understanding that the Act clearly provides that the extrinsic aids, as we call them-the explanatory memorandum, the second reading speech, and so on-can be used in relation to the High Court's interpretation of an Act of this Parliament. In so far as we are in the process of passing an Act of this Parliament, the extrinsic aids mentioned can be used by the High Court in coming to its understanding of the provision which eventually finds its way into the Constitution if it is agreed to by the people at a referendum. What we are dealing with is an Act of the Parliament. That is what we are in the process of passing. Section 15ab of the Acts Interpretation Act refers to an Act of the Parliament, so that is what we are dealing with in relation to that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That answers the narrow point, although I am not sure that somebody in the High Court or somewhere else will not say that that is wrong because he will not be looking at an Act, but at an amendment to the Constitution. I would not have thought that, if the Minister was arguing a case based on this section, if it was inserted in the Constitution, he would produce this Bill or this proposed Act. However, I do not think I can advance that matter at this stage. The Minister has given me what he believes to be the correct position.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised other matters relating to the assertions in paragraphs 3 and 4 of the explanatory memorandum. I do not want to take up another quarter of an hour of the Committee's time to go over the ground. I questioned how the Minister was able to ascertain, from the words used in the actual amendment, that the section does not preclude a State from providing for amalgamation and does not preclude laws providing for dismissal. I accept all of that. It seems on the face of it that the words mean that the State law can say anything that it damn well likes. Paragraph 3 then states:
. . . subject to a new local government body being elected within a reasonable period.
On what basis does the Minister say that that has to be read into section 119a when paragraph 4 of the explanatory memorandum states:
Section 119a is not intended to oblige a State to establish local government bodies throughout the whole of the State.
I assume that that would mean that the local government area could be abolished and there would simply be no local government in the area. I think the paragraphs are inconsistent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Paragraph 4 of the explanatory memorandum recognises that there may be circumstances in which a State parliament provided, in relation to a particular area, that there should be no elected local government body. That is not seen to be inconsistent, nevertheless, with having a system of elected local government in the State. In the terms of section 119a it is not required that the system of local government cover every square inch of the State. In relation to a particular local area it could well be that local government is not provided for in the sense of a situation where bodies elected to administer and make by-laws for that area are provided for. In the system provided for elected local government there are quite properly provisions for dismissal. If there is no replacement by an elected body within a period which allows for the corruption or the problem to be adequately dealt with by an administrator or by some other means, there would not be a system of elected local government bodies operating in the State: the displacement of the elected body would become a sort of permanent feature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has simply repeated what is in the explanatory memorandum as a matter of his belief that the words in section 119a could be made to mean that. If we accept the Minister's word, it follows for example that, if, as governments have found it necessary to do in the States of New South Wales and Victoria, they dismiss the local authority for the capital city and appoint an administrator-something which has actually happened and is not some vague possibility-the Minister is suggesting that the words `require within some reasonable time', which do not appear in the section but presumably he expects that to be read into it by judicial interpretation, will mean that within some reasonable time there should be an election for a fresh elective body. On the other hand, I assume from that that if the State government looked at the situation and said, `We are sick of these chaps. They do not do it properly. We will not have any local government in the capital city. We will abolish local government in the capital city. We will continue to have local government on the north shore, and out in the eastern and western suburbs but we will remove it from the city itself', and in Melbourne the Government said the same thing, on the basis of the Minister's explanation that would be perfectly legitimate. So, the Constitution--
—Yes, Mr Chairman.

—I thank the Minister for intervening and confirming that. It just points out that if the Minister is right-quite frankly I find the interpretation one which I cannot necessarily spell out of the words which are being put into the Constitution-the lovely assumption on the part of local government people, including those here this week, that they have some protection is absolute rubbish. The Minister has just confessed to us that whilst one cannot-according to him-under this constitutional provision appoint an administrator for an indefinite term, one can turn around and abolish the local government authority entirely and put in some other form of State administration that one might call State administration. It demonstrates that this is pretty much a sham.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want the Minister to think that I am being inconsistent in my criticisms. For the purpose of those comments I am simply adopting totally what he has now regurgitated in slightly different words from the explanatory memorandum. I simply say to him that if that is what it means it is absurd. It is an attempt to hoodwink 700 or 800 people. I bet Mr Hawke, when he addressed the meeting, did not say to the people, `You can be protected against this position unless they just abolish your local authority'. In any event, it seems to me that the Minister has not in any way attempted to relate his interpretation to what these words actually say. It seems to me that what these words actually say is no more than that we have to have some sort of system of local government with some bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State. I think that places virtually no limitations on them. I have serious doubts about the point in the explanatory memorandum. I want to put this on the record in case the Minister is right in his other view that the High Court has to take notice of it. I want the High Court to know that, as far as this member of parliament is concerned, those words do not necessarily require that in the circumstances of the appointment of an administrator a new local government body should be elected within a reasonable period. It seems to me that the system of local government in a State might well consist in part of a system of elected local government bodies with other parts of the State having either no local government at all or some system of State appointed administration which might have to operate under some slightly different name. It seems an absolutely confused position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice does not seem very anxious to reply to the very trenchant points that have been made by my colleague Senator Chaney.
