Perhaps he will get around to doing so later in this debate after he has cogitated on the matter. However, while he is doing so perhaps he could also cogitate on one or two other matters. There is an assumption in the explanatory memorandum, to which Senator Chaney has referred, that if a local government council has been dismissed that would require, after a reasonable time, a means of reappointing that council. The Minister has now conceded that he can get around that by abolishing the whole local government authority which is a very odd result. It adds one oddity to another. Let us assume that some right is created-and God knows how one could assume from this extraordinary collocation of words that there is a right. I would like the Minister to tell us very simply how a council, ex-council, a group of people or whoever-maybe there is a problem of standing as well-could enforce that right. Let us assume that we can get over those problems, and that we can get a declaration from the High Court of Australia about what happened in a particular State-most likely it would be New South Wales because of the proclivity of Labor governments in that State to sack democratically elected councils; Labor governments in New South Wales have a much worse record of sacking Labor councils--
—A thing of the past.

—As Senator Bishop says, that will not happen with the change of government there. Let us assume that a council is sacked, that it is not reinstated and that the local authority continues in existence. I am just taking the Minister's assumptions because he has already said that he can get around it by abolishing local authorities. His explanatory memorandum says that we do not have to have local authorities in every part of a State. The Minister is being logical in that respect, strange as the result may be. How does a group of people in the area of a former local authority, or whoever or whatever, enforce the right? Can we get a mandatory injunction from the High Court to force a State parliament to change the laws of the State?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us ponder that for a moment. A State parliament has full powers to legislate with respect to local government. Nothing in this constitutional amendment changes that. In fact, it enforces that. So the only way in which a local authority could be reinstated would be as a result of a change of State laws or State administration. Can the High Court direct a State parliament or a State government to change the laws? Let us assume that it does say, `You have to change the laws to conform with whatever this constitutional guarantee is'. Can the High Court then say in detail how those laws have to be changed?

I am not sure whether the Minister has had experience in settling injunctions by courts. How does a court, even the High Court, word an injunction to a State authority in these matters? How is it done? When the State clearly is given wide discretion to determine the nature of the laws dealing with local government how does the High Court select its orders? That is what we come down to. Let us ponder the case of the High Court settling an order against a State which, in some extraordinary way, has been identified as breaching this constitutional guarantee. How does the High Court settle an order against a State government or State parliament? The order against a State government may be more easily determined, but how is an order against a State parliament determined? If it can be determined, how is that consistent with the recent High Court decision about the Queensland electricity commissioners, which has very clearly laid down limits on the powers of the High Court or the Federal Parliament in relation to laws directed specifically at a State government?

It seems to me that there are insuperable legal problems involved in what the Minister and his colleagues are saying can be done. Even if they can overcome that and can frame orders to be made by the High Court against a State government, how are those orders enforced? What if a State parliament says, `To hell with the order of the High Court. We are not going to carry out the orders that we have been given to set up some local authority or reinstate some council'? That is what we are talking about-reinstating some council. What if the State government says, `To hell with it; we are not going to take notice of it', and the State parliament says, `We support that and we will not change our laws in any shape or form.'? How does the Commonwealth Government then enforce that order? What is the sanction?

There is a very old authority in the common law of contract about specific performance of contracts of personal service. It was decided at common law that that was just not possible. It has been a basic principle of the law of specific performance that we cannot get specific performance of those laws in our court system. It seems to me that the Government is trying to say that in the area of government somehow or other the High Court can force State parliaments to carry out a law. Is the Government going to say that the High Court is going to write the law for the State? That is an extraordinary proposition. I suspect that the Government does not really intend to enforce this at all. This is an exercise in absolute eyewash and window-dressing and the Government knows it. It is just pulling the wool over the eyes of a lot of unsuspecting innocent people in local government who do not know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question of how this matter might get before the High Court of Australia, no doubt a litigant would seek a declaration from the High Court that the action of the State government was incompatible, inconsistent or did not conform with section 119a.
—What standing has he got?

—As to standing, I would have thought that any person who had been entitled to vote in the local government area concerned would have a standing before the High Court in relation to this matter. But as far as the question of a remedy is concerned, as I say, the litigant would seek a declaration from the High Court. A declaration from the High Court carries with it a status which, up till now, has been recognised by State governments in a way which leads to their acting in accordance with the declaration. That is the situation which one would hope would prevail, otherwise one obviously has a situation of complete anarchy. The fact is that State governments are often confronted with High Court decisions which are not satisfactory to them; nevertheless, they act in accordance with the declaration of the Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister might wish to reflect upon the views of the Law Council of Australia. The declaration is not a law and the principles set out in the declaration have not been subject to any legislative process. The declaration ought not to be given the imprimatur of being associated with any body of legislation. There is no precedent in Australian law or government practice for a declaration to be given any formal authority and such a document would appear to have no more force than a manifesto or a political platform.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter seems to be-as best I am able to understand it and as Senator Durack has stated-that this Bill is nothing more than tokenism. Although the High Court of Australia might, in some obscure way, place its own inevitable and perhaps unpredictable-given the recent section 92 decision-interpretation on the phrases which are being offered up, in real terms the words seem to represent absolutely nothing. They offer no promise against wrongful dismissal, no promise against forced amalgamations, and no promise against the abolition of local government in parts of the State. It seems to me that this Government is seeking in a cynical way to exploit sentiment amongst local government leaders, pretending to be offering to them something which is illusory. The Government is crudely and boldly pretending to be offering them recognition as if it means something; of course at the end of the day it means absolutely nothing.

Whilst, given the explanatory memorandum, the leaders of local government may in the short term be hoodwinked into believing that there is something of substance in this Bill, my guess is that at the end of the day-to use Senator Tate's expression-they will realise that it is a cynical bit of tokenism and that they will wake up to that which is understood by the ratepayers now. There is nothing to be gained by having local government in the Constitution, but absolutely everything to be gained by having local government as a creature of State legislation and in a State Constitution. As I said earlier, it gives local government the flexibility and the capacity to interact and to respond to local demands and local wants. What I suspect from my reading and from travelling around Western Australia is that what the local government people want is not constitutional recognition but funds enough to allow them to provide adequate but modest resources for their ratepayers.

Let us reflect for a moment on their present position. Owing to the new funding arrangements for local government commencing in 1988-89, where assistance is tied to percentage changes in respect of general purpose payments to the States, funding for local government will decrease by 2.9 per cent in real terms. Local roads assistance has been reduced and in fact suffered a real decline of 13.2 per cent between 1983-84 and 1986-87. Of course, not surprisingly, there has been a dramatic fall in the total level of Commonwealth road funding from 1983-84 to 1988-89-the black period of this Government. The level of Commonwealth Government funding has declined by 29.4 per cent. This includes a 7.8 per cent real decrease, as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the May economic statement. This decline in road funding has occurred notwithstanding the fact that by June 1988 the Commonwealth Government will have taken an additional $426.6m as a result of its 1983-84 decision to index the 2c per litre levy under the Australian bicentennial road development program set up under the Fraser Government for the purpose of allocating all those funds for roads.

Of course, local government has suffered a massive loss of Commonwealth funding as a result of the decision by the Hawke Government to terminate the community employment program. For example, in 1984-85 funding under this program was worth $168m; in 1985-86 it was worth $75m; and in 1986-87 the Government allocated $100m to meet all remaining commitments under the program. Of course, these funding measures have made an absolute mockery of the Government's so-called continuing commitment to strengthening local government's place in the Australian system of government. This is reflected in the levels of total Commonwealth funding for local government. After a real increase of 2.9 per cent in 1984-85, total Commonwealth assistance to local government declined by 1.5 per cent in real terms in 1985-86 and by 7.3 per cent in 1986-87. While the figures for 1987-88 are not yet available, one can reasonably assume that the decline will be of a similar magnitude. In my judgment this is a reflection of the real care and concern of this Government for local government.

This Government will not satisfy the needs of local government, the wants of local government ratepayers, those people who live in local government areas or those people who are subject to local government provisions by token representation or token recognition in the Constitution. The Government will satisfy them by providing adequate and equitable funding. This Government has not done that. I can imagine only that this Government, in its typically cynical way, has chosen to proffer this constitutional amendment as something of a sweetener, something of a sugar-coated pill, to ensure as best it is able that question No. 1 gets through, to ensure that the powers of the Senate are gutted, and that we have elections whenever the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants them, whenever it is expedient for him and his political party to take the people to the polls again. I do not believe this Government ever intended, at least with this wording, to give any proper recognition to local government in any real way. I have no doubt that if this Government could have its way it would go back to its original 1978 constitutional proposals in which it proposed that there be direct funding. That proposal was rejected not just by the Australian people; most of all the charge was led by local government. I suspect the result will be exactly the same for this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a lot said by the Opposition in this debate, much of it directed towards the suitability of the current Constitution to last over time. If one looks at section 68 of the Constitution one sees very clearly how wrong that view is. It says that the command in chief of the naval and military forces of the Commonwealth is vested in the hands of the Governor-General as the Queen's representative. There is no mention of an air force. I just want to make the point that the Constitution is dated. Senator Boswell made the point--
—That is a constitutional amendment you ought to be putting up.

—Somebody had better bring this booklet up to date. The Opposition has talked about tokenism. If it is tokenism I do not know why it is putting such effort into seeing that it does not take place. Senator Boswell, a learned gentleman in this place, made some points about local government being gullible. Another honourable senator talked about it being innocent and unsuspecting. If that is not paternalism I have never heard it, particularly in the situation where local government over a period of time has asked for these changes in the Constitution. I read the speech made in the House of Representatives recently by a friend of mine, Tom Uren, in which he made that point. He encouraged people in local government to go out and battle for those things they had asked for over a long period. They support their own recognition in the Constitution, and so if the Ron Boswells and the Crichton-Brownes of this world want to say that local government is innocent, naive, unsuspecting and gullible, let them be recognised for the frauds they are. Ron Boswell also said, and of course he has a brilliant legal mind--
—Madam Chair, I rise on a point of order. I ask to be recognised as a senator of the Commonwealth of this nation. I am a duly elected member of parliament and a senator from Queensland.
—A very excellent one, too.
—I thank Senator Bjelke- Petersen. I ask that the honourable senator recognise my full title.
—Senator Boswell, I doubt whether any disrespect was intended but I will make the point to Senator Burns that perhaps he might extend the niceties of this chamber to all honourable senators.

—I feel suitably chastised. Never again will I refer to Senator Boswell as Mr Boswell, but it is a bit difficult to be friendly with someone who wants to be known as Senator all the time. He said he had no confidence in the High Court. The High Court has been given responsibilities since Federation--
—I did not say that.
—Yes, it is in the Hansard.
—You cannot read.
—I heard it on the radio as well. What is being argued here by the Opposition--
—I raise a point of order, Madam Temporary Chairman. I do not recollect saying that I had no confidence in the High Court. I ask you to call on the honourable senator to withdraw that statement.
—I do not believe that there is any point of order.

—Madam Chair, I think that the Standing Orders protect the High Court. If they protect the High Court, it would be disorderly of Senator Boswell to say that of it. I think that if Senator Boswell denies that he said it, that was really an accusation of unparliamentary language. I think that that matter could be reconsidered.

—I think it was a point of misrepresentation rather than any disrespect for the High Court. The debate is getting a little lively. That general comment might be taken as some advice as to how it might proceed.
—I am quite happy to withdraw that remark, but I rely on the Hansard record.
—There are three more speakers on the other side.

—I understand that the Minister had his go. I want to make it clear that I have confidence in the High Court to interpret the Constitution. Senator Durack made the point that it would be difficult for the Court to make certain decisions when there were disputes between local and State governments. I suggest that it had no problem in 1949 when the Labor Government decided to nationalise the banks. It made a decision and it was accepted. Why do not those on the other side of the chamber who are opposed to the interests of local government just get up and say it? Why do they not just say `We believe that local government should be the creature of State governments and should have no recognition', and leave it at that?

—The title of this Bill is incorrect. It is `An Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government'. Indeed, it does not do that. It deals with a system of local government. The Minister would know that, while the Constitutional Commission, in the summary of its first report, put forward a recommendation that local government should be recognised, the Government deliberately changed the wording and proposed that not local government but a system of local government should be recognised. I ask the Minister whether he can tell me why the Government has changed that wording and what the definition of a local government system would be if the Government desired to define it.

—It is very hard to give a definition of a system of local government that is not merely repetitious of that description. Obviously, it means an organised system-I cannot think of another word for `system'-which provides for many local government organisations of the character described; namely, bodies elected in accordance with the laws of a State. In other words, it covers a number of such bodies throughout the State. They obviously require a certain degree of organisation, and that is what a system is. It is a very simple word.

—Would such a system include regional groups, regional councils? Would it include Aboriginal councils, so long as they were elected according to the State law? I have no idea what it would cover. The mind boggles as to what a system of local government would include. I ask the Minister to give this side of the chamber some indication of the breadth of the Government's thinking. It must have had some reason for changing the wording of the Constitutional Commission's recommendation, from simply `local Government' to `a system of local government'. It is for that reason I ask the Minister whether he could give us some indication of the bodies that would cover.

—I have already indicated that the Government did not wish to create a situation where State parliaments and governments were fettered in their ability to deal with a particular local government body that was perhaps guilty of corrupt practices and ought to be dismissed. Therefore rather than make a constitutional provision that provided for the establishment and continuance of a local government body, we talk about the continuance of a system of local government to allow within that organised structure of local government authorities throughout a State, in the particular jurisdiction of a State parliament, for an individual local government body to be dismissed for the sorts of reasons with which we are familiar.
—What about the two I suggested? Would they come under that?

—I do not know the situation in Queensland. Senator Boswell would probably be more familiar with it. I understand there are some Aboriginal communities which are in fact vested with local government powers of making by-laws and administering their areas, and of course they are elected local government bodies.
—That is right; they are elected every three years to local government.
—That is right. It is one of the strong points in Queensland that in fact these Aboriginal communities have local government powers in their particular areas.
—What about the regional government bodies? Would they also come under the Government's system of local government as the Minister sees it?

—In so far as a regional body is given powers to make by-laws and to administer the area of the region, then it is a local government body of that kind, and it has to be elected under this particular provision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said tonight that the Government had departed from the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission because it wants to make the proposal much broader than covering just ordinary local government bodies as we know them today. It would indeed cover regional groups and all the sorts of groups that the Minister indicated tonight. He also indicated that if a city council such as the inner city council in Sydney were dismissed it could be abolished under the legislation. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: A state would be free to determine that, having regard to the nature of a particular region and other relevant circumstances, it would not be appropriate for the region to be administered by a local government body.

The Minister has told us tonight that so long as the State has some sort of local government system somewhere in the State that is all right. It does not need to have local government bodies as we know them today, even the main cities. They can be abolished if because of the special nature of a particular region or any other relevant circumstance the Government wishes to abolish them. This is a complete sham. This is what I explained to the Tasmanian Local Government Association last week in Tasmania. Frankly, Mr Peter Kyle, the President of the Australian Local Government Association and a Western Australian visiting Tasmania for its annual conference, did not believe what I was saying. Fortunately, I can now send him a copy of Hansard to prove that I was correct and that indeed that is just what the Government intends. I am sorry that the Australian local government conference in Canberra today has not had the truth of the matter put to it. It has just had an emotive speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Those attending are unaware of the truth of the matter, but I can assure the Minister that they will not stay unaware for long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not envy Senator Tate, who is in the chamber, and I do not envy his advisers sitting with him, because clearly the Government has not thought this Bill through and has not put itself in a position in which it can answer questions at the committee stage of the debate. This afternoon and this evening a wide range of questions were put by Opposition senators about a Bill that contains only 14 lines-it is as brief a Bill as I have ever seen since I have been a member of this chamber-yet the Minister was unable to give clear and concise answers. Senator Walters has just demonstrated that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney spoke first in this committee debate and in his 15-minute speech he put a range of questions about references in the second reading speech and in the explanatory memorandum that is associated with the 14 lines of this Bill-questions such as what a reasonable time means and whether certain forms of local government may exist under the rubric system of local government. I can only conclude that the Government has made a political decision to make an emotive noise to those involved in local government and to put forward to them the title of the Bill-`An Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government'-as if it were some boon to local government in Australia. It is nothing of the sort. It is completely without substance. It gives no practical benefit, nor can argue that it would have given any practical benefit to local government in any part of Australia in the last 88 years.

I have heard, with good foundation, the words `sham', `fraud' and `smokescreen' used in respect of this Bill. The word `smokescreen' is appropriate. The Government's agenda, which is a political agenda, is to try to do all that it can, even by a biased description of the titles of the referendum Bills, to get up question No. 1-the proposal which would take away the powers of the Senate. In order to maximise a chance to get up the question that matters to this Government-question No. 1-a Bill such as this is introduced: a 14-line Bill which relates to local government, which provides an emotional fog, a smokescreen, and which is meant to get some responsive cord in local government representatives around Australia. That is what it is about. It is entirely about politics. No-one has been able to maintain, in any of the speeches at the second reading stage or in any of the contributions in the committee stage of the Bill, that this Bill amounts to anything of substance. The words that have been used again and again are `tokenism', `sham', `fraud' and `smokescreen'. Yet local government is still being told by this Government that the measure has been put forward in response to its requests.

I can only say that the way in which the committee stage of the Bill has been conducted in the chamber, with the lack of clear and concise answers, even any answers at all, to many of the matters that have been raised shows that there is no well-thought-out position. The advisers are silent, the Minister is silent and we are left with the smokescreen of this political agenda put forward by the Labor Government. It is deplorable that there has been such a fruitless response from the Minister in the chamber. The Minister who was present for all of this debate, Senator Tate, has left the chamber while I have been speaking. In his place is another Minister, Senator Robert Ray, who has not heard the questions, who has not heard the matters that are being sought by the Committee. How can we expect there to be any substance in the replies that he may put to us now?

The whole of this debate reinforces the fact that the third referendum proposal is on the political agenda of this Government as a smokescreen to try to induce the public to a warm feeling that would lead them-if they are deluded-to support the first question, concerning the terms of the House of Representatives and the Senate. I can only say that it is not good enough. I have not previously experienced such a lack of responsiveness and clear answers in the committee stage of a Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a couple of very specific questions to the Minister. A few moments ago, in answer to a question from Senator Walters, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, implied that this Bill would apply to new arrangements being proposed for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. I got the very clear impression that this Bill would have effect with regard to any new proposals for local government. Given that this Bill, according to its title, is a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government, one would have thought that it would have had universal application throughout Australia. Why are there now two categories of citizens in Australia-those in the States and those in the Northern Territory? This proposed Act is not expressed to operate in respect of the Northern Territory. I think that is a very serious omission because, in effect, it means that there are Australian citizens who will not be covered by this local government proposal. It further reinforces the demonstration of how hollow the proposals are. There is no reference whatsoever in the explanatory memorandum or in the Bill to its application in the Northern Territory. Given the confusion that has arisen with regard to the proposed new regional councils for Aboriginal communities, I find that to be a very serious omission and one to which I would like a very serious answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is some confusion on Senator Tambling's part. I did not say that the proposals to do with Aboriginal self-determination and self-management under the proposed new commission for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders would fall within this constitutional provision. I was referring, for example, to the situation that Senator Boswell outlined in Queensland, where certain Aboriginal communities are given local government powers in relation to their own area under an Act of the State Parliament. They hold elections every three years, they make by-laws and administer those areas. I was speaking only about those Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Territories-not only the Northern Territory; there is the Australian Capital Territory, Christmas Island and Norfolk Island-the Constitutional Commission took the view that the constitutional development of the Territories is at a different stage from that which has been the case in the States. In particular, it mentioned the sparsely populated areas in the Northern Territory. It was more to do with the fact that the Territories are at different stages of constitutional development and the provision that it suggested should be made in relation to the local governments in the States should not be required in the Territories of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat alarmed that the Minister has in effect conceded that there are to be two classes of Australians: what is to apply to the States will not apply to the Territories. The Minister took the liberty of quoting from the Constitutional Commission in that respect. But I would also ask him: Would he acknowledge that the distribution of powers advisory committee to the Constitutional Commission advised against recognising local government in the Commonwealth Constitution? It stated that it would be undesirable to entrench another level of government which would be in competition with the States.

—I cannot recall the titles of all the Constitutional Commission committees. I seem to recall that one advised against recognition and one advised for recognition of local government. That does not really matter; the important point is that the Commission came to its decision. The Commission took the view that to impose this constitutional obligation on Territories at their various stages of development was not appropriate, as it was in the case of the States.

—Can the Minister tell me under which part of section 51 (v) of the Constitution, Powers of the Parliament, we are able to make this offer to local government for recognition? As I understand it, that is the list of the functions of the Federal Parliament. I do not see a heading there that readily seems to equate with this section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because we are not looking at the present powers of the Parliament as set out in the Constitution; we are looking to make a new section within the Constitution by way of referendum. For that one looks to section 128.
—Does the offer of this sort of thing not rest with the States rather than with the Commonwealth to make?

—It is really not for the Commonwealth or the States to make an offer-if that is the terminology to be used. This matter will be determined by the people of Australia voting in a referendum. They will make a determination as to whether they consider that local government ought to be recognised in the way that is outlined.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ordered that the third reading of the Bill be an Order of the Day for a later hour of the day.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move-

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, be established to examine and report upon the Government's proposals for the reorganisation and administration of Aboriginal affairs by the formation of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Commission including:
(a) the terms of those proposals and the clauses of any legislation proposed for the establishment of ATSIC;
(b) the effectiveness of the process of consultation undertaken by the Government with respect to the ATSIC proposal;
(c) the proposal of the Aboriginal Development Commission for `an alternative strategy of Aboriginal self-management';
(d) the Government's treatment of the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Commissioners, including the dismissal of 8 of the Commissioners.
(2) That the Committee report to the Senate within six months of the publication of legislation or draft legislation to establish ATSIC.
(3) That the Committee consist of six Senators, as follows:
(a) three to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate,
(b) two to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate,
(c) one to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats.
(4) That the Committee proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the Chairman of the Committee be appointed by and from the members of the Committee.

(6) That the Chairman of the Committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the Committee to be the Deputy-Chairman of the Committee, and that the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(7) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(8) That the quorum of the Committee be three members.

(9) That the Committee and any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations it may deem fit.

(10) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the matters which the Committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the sub-committee.

(11) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee with the approval of the President.
(12) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(13) That, if the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its report, the Committee may provide the report to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy President, and, in that event:
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate,
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this Resolution,
(c) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report, and
(d) the President or the Deputy President, as the case may be, shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(14) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, Have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Committee that the Bill be taken as a whole?

—Mr Chairman, when one looks at this Bill it is quite clear that there are three quite separate propositions. Whilst one might take propositions 1 and 2 together, the reality is that there will be people wishing to address the matters of trial by jury, the acquisition of property and the establishment of religion. We would have a much more orderly debate if we dealt with those propositions seriatim. I therefore suggest that we take the Bill clause by clause because, otherwise, we will have a chaotic debate.
—There being an objection to the Bill being taken as a whole, it will be dealt with clause by clause.

—I want to raise a question with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) about why such disparate questions are being put in the one referendum proposal. I think that clause 1 is the appropriate clause under which to ask this question. Perhaps if I am out of order the Chairman will tell me so-but I do not know of any other clause under which I can raise this question. There are three quite separate and distinct questions. One relates to trial by jury; one relates to the so-called extension of freedom of religion-and we have dealt with that question here before-and the other relates to property. Will the Minister give an explanation to the Committee as to why the Government chose to include these quite disparate matters in the one referendum proposal? That is a simple question. What is the answer?

—These particular proposals have been linked together because their aim is to extend the provisions already existing in the Constitution in relation to trial by jury, freedom of religion and fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by a government. But at the moment, as is well known, these provisions relate only to the Commonwealth and its desire to extend already existing principles in this area to the States.

—Am I to understand that when the Minister says that he is extending these provisions he means extending them to the States, whatever the matter is. For example, if an elector were to consider that the property question should be extended to the States-according to Senator Tate it should be extended to the States-why could the elector not then vote for that and vote against the other two? In this particular instance the Minister is not giving the electors a true freedom of choice. He is saying to the elector, `If you agree with one and you want to vote for that one, you have got to cop the other two as well'. That is what he is saying to the elector. Would the Government be prepared, in the interests of giving electors a true and free choice as to how they vote in these referenda, to split these questions into three parts?

—The Government is putting this question as one in relation to the extension of these particular rights already provided for against the Commonwealth in the Constitution. The decision has been taken to pose the question in that single form.

—I think it is important as we start to debate this Bill and its various clauses that we understand very firmly the point that Senator Harradine has made; that is, that the whole set of propositions must stand or fall together. There is no way one can say, `I like this one and reject that one'. That is a decision the Government has made and it must stand by that. It has to be judged by it. I think that as we go forward to discuss the items separately all of us must understand that the whole package either stands or falls together.

—What is the connection between just compensation and a claim for freedom of religion? What is the connection other than the convenience of putting the three together and seeking to confuse people to try to get a yes vote? I ask the Minister in all sincerity: What is the connection between the two in terms of the question asked in each case?

—The connection lies in the fact that the three matters provided for in this referendum are already provided for in the Constitution in relation to the Commonwealth. What is being sought is a simple extension of those three matters to apply against the States.

—I refer honourable senators to section 115 of the Constitution and to the answer just given by Senator Tate. Senator Tate said that the reason the Government had put all these disparate questions as one question was that they each extended the application of a provision in the Commonwealth Constitution to the States. Honourable senators, please correct me if I am wrong, but that is as I understood the answer given by Senator Tate. I ask Senator Tate: Where do we find the provisions in the Constitution relating to access to property under State law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite understand the question. What is provided for under section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution at the moment is:

SPEECH.PARA: The acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws.

Therefore, there is already a provision dealing with the acquisition of property on just terms in respect of the Commonwealth Parliament. What I am saying is that this referendum proposal extends that into the arena of the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather confused. Is the reason that the Government is putting these three questions as one question that it is extending to the States a provision in the Constitution which now relates only to the Commonwealth? If that is the reason, it is a very shoddy reason indeed. It is an excuse for doing something which will deny to the electors of Australia a true freedom of choice. It is quite likely that there are some people who may say, `Yes, I can understand this issue about property'. However, the extension of the freedom of religion proposal could lead down the track to the erection of an impenetrable wall between the body politic and those persons who choose to adhere to a particular religion and, in fact, if the Murphy judgment were to be followed, would deny education justice to people who send their kids to poor parochial schools. This would not be giving a true freedom of choice to the elector. What the Government is doing is dumping disparate questions into one and then saying to the electors, `Cop one or cop none'. I will forget all about the other questions, but what is to prevent the Government now deciding to put these disparate matters into three separate questions?

—The government is putting these questions in the form that I have indicated not in reliance on but following the Bill proposed by the Constitutional Commission, which also put these matters together for the very reason I indicated, and believes that this particular mode of putting the questions should be continued; and it will not be dividing them into further questions.

—The point is quite obvious to everybody. I have my papers here and I will check in a moment whether the Constitutional Commission was suggesting that these matters were of a kind. I am not sure whether the Government is following this matter on that basis, but it certainly did not follow the Constitutional Commission's recommendations in respect of local government.
—Or question No. 1.
—Or question No. 1.

—I want to give the Minister for Justice the chance to correct something he just said to the Committee and which I am sure, on reflection, he will realise is wrong; that is, the reasons these three provisions would be put in as one is that the provisions are in the Constitution presently and are simply to be extended to cover the States also. That is blatantly incorrect. It is clear that the Constitution does touch upon the subject matters of trial by jury, acquisition of property and freedom of religion. However if we look simply at the first of them, trial by jury, we will find that the provision we are to vote upon tonight is an entirely different provision from that currently in the Constitution. It is not just a matter of extending it to apply to the States. It changes the arbitrary test that is currently in the Constitution, that is, that a trial should be by jury if it is on indictment, to another arbitrary test, that is, that a trial should be by jury if the defendant is liable to imprisonment for more than two years. So I am sure that upon reflection the Minister will agree that it is an entirely different provision from that which is currently in the Constitution. Therefore the reason that he just gave to the Committee for grouping the three together is incorrect and it raises new issues that have to be debated tonight; new issues that will mean if the proposal is passed the constitutional provision for trial by jury will have a new basis entirely. Therefore one is forced to ask the Minister, if he now agrees that this is in fact a new provision based on a new test why does the Government not allow it to be put to the people as a single issue in order that they might resolve it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true to say that in relation to trial by jury the provision presently in the Constitution and which was intended by the framers of the Constitution to provide an adequate trial by jury safeguard for those who were facing a serious charge which might lead to the deprivation of their freedom or even of their life, I suppose, in those days, is being strengthened by overcoming what has turned out to be a very easily surmounted provision that required that trial by jury be provided where the trial was on indictment. Of course, the simple fact was that if one did not provide for a trial by indictment, no trial by jury was required.

SPEECH.PARA: So it is true that it is being modified in that respect and strengthened in order to accord quite clearly with the intention of the framers of the Constitution that persons have the benefit of trial by jury in those more serious cases. But I do not see that that modification and strengthening of that provision necessarily is at odds with the general claim I was making that trial by jury, freedom of religion and acquisition of property on just terms are provided for in the Constitution as against the Commonwealth, and it is seen as desirable to extend all of those matters and rights to be enjoyed by Australians as against State parliaments also. I can only repeat that the questions, to be put as one, take account of that common link which I still see in relation to the extension of matters which have already been thought to be important by the framers of the Constitution when they established the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tempted to be curious and ask why the Government insists on putting these three questions together, particularly if it is serious about getting a Yes result. It leads me back to the proposition I proffered from the outset; that is, the object of these questions is to get a Yes answer to the first question, which is the one that is important. The local government is unimportant to the Commonwealth.
—It is important in order to destroy the Senate.

—That is right. The first question will, of course, destroy the Senate. It will give this avaricious Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a capacity to indulge himself in an election whenever he has a whim or a wish, whenever it is politically expedient or whenever he finds himself running into unpopularity, and, at the end of the day, it will gut the Senate. The question in respect of local government, as we know, comes to nought. As to this question-this point has already been put-the question of alleged freedom of religion, as suggested by Senator Harradine, is perhaps something upon which those who have a strong view will focus. I would have thought, if the Government was serious about its section 51 (xxxi) proposition, if it was serious about its section 80 proposition, it would have put those questions separately. Those who feel strongly about the section 116 proposition will, presumably, vote down the other two. The Government must know that. Inept and incompetent as it might be, it can count. It will know that those people who feel strongly about section 116 will vote against the section 80 proposition and the section 51 (xxxi) proposition. If the Government is serious about getting those questions through with a Yes vote, why does it not separate them?

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly-this brings me back to what I have put to Senator Tate previously-governments have a responsibility in respect of constitutional amendments to offer the public an opportunity to have a free and full understanding of the questions being put to them. We have found that that is not true in respect of the first question; that it is totally untrue in respect of the fair elections questions; and that it is totally untrue in respect of the local government question. Now we find in this case that three questions are to be put together, to deny people at least an equal chance of beginning to make a judgment as to how they feel about the matters. They are compelled, if they feel intensely about one question, to vote against the other two. The voters of Australia are being denied an opportunity to reflect individually on each question.

I ask the Minister: Why does he persist with denying the people an opportunity to have separate and sober reflection upon each question covered? So far, as I have understood his answer-I ask him to forgive me if I have misunderstood him-he has said that it is because in some vague way he is including the States and in some cases the Territories in the question. I can think of no issues more distinct and separate than questions of fair compensation, of trial by jury, and of alleged freedom of religion. They are totally different and disparate questions.

It seems to me that Senator Tate is playing Russian roulette in asking the Australian community to determine those questions collectively when they might have strong views, in different directions, on more than one. I just ask Senator Tate: At the end of the day, what is to be the solution to the dilemma of those in the community who may, for whatever reason, feel intensely against his amendment to section 116 but feel equally intensively in support, for instance, of the amendment to section 8, the trial by jury question? What are those people to do? What is he offering as a solution to those people who have a strong feeling in favour of a Yes vote in the one case and a strong feeling in favour of a No vote in another? Both views might be based on the premise of morality. They might be matters that they feel touch upon them and their rights within this community. What should they do in making their determination? Do they have to make a judgment on balance as to which is most important, which is the most intrinsic right to them? Are they being asked to deny and sacrifice a view about one in order to achieve a result in another? I ask Senator Tate why the Government is not prepared to split these questions in a very simple way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think on this first section it is important to make another point pertaining to why these questions are put together. At a later time when we come to debate specifically the amendments to section 116 I will be able to speak at some length. I think this question has been phrased, and these three issues put together, for the simple reason that the Government believes it will slip through the amendment to section 116 with the issues of trial by jury and fair and just compensation. The real intent of this question is to get rid of State aid to private schools, religious based schools. When we start to examine the proposal and look at the authorities in an analytical and specific way, we will find that is the real intent. Just as the question that is to be posed to the electorate is couched in spurious terms, the so-called extending of freedoms, the true purpose will be seen when we start to debate the specific sections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the concern of a number of my colleagues about lumping together three very disparate issues in this referendum question. It is rather like the pub conversation where one is not supposed to link politics, religion and sex. We are certainly getting a combination of all three in this area-trial by jury, the religious argument and, of course, the sexy one, which is the acquisition of property.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading debate the other day I dealt with the very serious issues raised by the Northern Territory Government as a body politic about how the proposal would affect it. I draw the Minister's attention in particular to that part of the explanatory memorandum relating to clause 3, acquisition of property. The explanatory memorandum states:

This clause inserts new sections 115a and 115b into the Constitution. The purpose of proposed new section 115a and 115b is to extend the obligation to provide just terms to acquisitions of property under State law, to acquisitions under laws made by the Parliament of the Commonwealth under section 122 and to acquisitions under Territory laws. It should be noted, however, that the proposed section 115b does not require the provision of just terms where the property to be acquired is the property of a Territory as a body politic (contrast the reference to a `State' in s. 51 (xxxi) . . .

I have a couple of serious questions in that regard. The first relates to the past practice of the Commonwealth in the Northern Territory, where it has compulsorily acquired property vested in the Northern Territory. I should like the Minister to address seriously those questions which I raised quite properly the other day in the second reading debate.

I should also like Senator Jenkins to take particular note of the implications of this for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The Government has quite publicly announced that it is proceeding down the line of self-government for the ACT. In effect this would create a body politic in the Australian Capital Territory. What would be the application of this particular clause to the acquisition of land in the ACT? Does it mean that we will see similar acquisitions, where the Commonwealth can pass legislation, as it has done in respect of various Aboriginal land and parklands in the Northern Territory. Would this clause give the Commonwealth the power in the ACT to get involved in a set of different and disparate land acquisition rules? Again there would be two types of citizens in Australia, those in the ACT and the Northern Territory, and those in the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite the Minister to address two questions. Can he give any previous examples of disparate referendum questions being combined in the one question, and can he indicate where it is that the Constitutional Commission recommended specifically that the three questions be rolled into one?

—I do not know of any previous example that I can give to the chamber at the moment, but in relation to the second part of the question, at page 805 of the second volume of the first report of the Constitutional Commission dated April 1988, in Bill No. 12, there is provision-in fact, it deals with more than these three matters-for a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to extend the guarantee of the right to trial by jury, freedom of religion, the right to fair compensation for acquisition of property and freedom from discrimination on the grounds of residence in a State. That was the basis of my previous reply.
—I do not believe that the Minister has addressed any of the fundamental questions that I raised.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, as I indicated to you, without actually taking a point of order, I thought that the questions on that matter were not relevant to the clause before us, but were relevant to the discussion of acquisition of property on just terms. I thought that it was more relevant to answer in that context.
—The question before the Committee is that clause 1 be agreed to. The debate on the subsequent clauses-clauses 2, 3 and 4-will provide an opportunity for more particular matters to be raised.

—There is little point in my pursuing this matter if the Minister intends to sit there in abject silence, but I invite him to answer at least the last question I put to him. What does one do if one feels intensely for a Yes vote for the amendment to section 116 but intensely about a No vote in respect of either section 80 or section 51 (xxxi.)?

—I do not know that I can solve that problem for every person confronted with the question that will be posed. I imagine that, as the honourable senators says, it would be a question of the intensity with which a particular matter was held as warranting support or rejection. Some sort of balance would have to be made in that context. I do not pretend that that exercise would be an easy one, but that is the way it would have to be undertaken.
—What the Minister is saying is that, at the end of the day, one may have to sacrifice reasonable compensation for one's religious beliefs. Fair and equitable compensation may be denied because-
—It depends who comes first, God or mammon.

—For the purpose of this exercise, I seek to put God leaps and bounds ahead. If one feels intensely in support of the Government's alleged proposition for freedom of religion and has a sensible and logical approach to what the Government has put as fair compensation, one has to subjugate the normal desire to stand by one's belief in one's religion. Also, if one were to believe, theoretically, in the question put, one would be denying oneself absolute certainty of trial by jury in a State because of one's belief in one's religion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things that I find very confusing with this aspect is that no-one from the Australian Democrats has spoken. If one considers the serious way in which the Democrats nearly always put the priority of personal freedoms and individual expressions, one would have thought that they would have had a very serious view on this potpourri of proposals that has been presented. The Democrats, by their silence, have acquiesced. I wonder where they stand in regard to the consideration of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 2 deals with trial by jury. I foreshadowed my concern during the consideration of clause 1. It seems to me that one arbitrary test that currently exists in the Constitution is simply being replaced by another arbitrary test. I am not sure that the new arbitrary test will strengthen the provision in the way that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) claimed. I remind you, Mr Temporary Chairman, that the existing provision in the Constitution, section 80, provides that the trial on indictment of any offence against any law of the Commonwealth shall be by jury. Therefore, the test is whether the provision in the enacting criminal law provides for a trial on indictment. We all know that what follows logically is that if the trial is to be prosecuted summarily the security provided in the Constitution is avoided. Many cases have come to that conclusion. Therefore, as I indicated, the security provided by section 80 can be fairly easily avoided.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the alternative that this Government is putting to the Committee tonight? It is putting a new provision, the first part of which reads as follows:
80.(1) the trial of a person for an offence, where the accused is liable to imprisonment for more than two years . . . shall be by jury . . .

A number of exceptions are listed. Basically, what is being substituted is the arbitrary test of whether the accused is liable to imprisonment for more than two years, as I said, for the currently existing arbitrary test of whether the trial is to be on indictment.

Why should a penalty provision of a period exceeding two years in prison be the sacred cow in this instance? One is no doubt aware of many offences that exist under both Commonwealth law and State law which any reasonable person would regard as serious. I have thumbed through a few of the key Commonwealth statutes and can remind the Committee of offences that carry a maximum penalty of one year's imprisonment which I would regard as serious and which, in my view, warrant trial by jury. For example, under the Commonwealth Crimes Act, section 30 deals with the offence of seizing goods in Commonwealth custody. Preventing witnesses from attending court, which I would have thought would be regarded by any reasonable person as highly serious is covered by section 40. Possessing or selling tokens resembling coins, defacing coins-one can go on. Under the Bankruptcy Act, section 263 deals with the offences of concealment of property or failure to disclose property, each of which, I would have thought, was tantamount to fraud. They are offences for which there is a maximum penalty of one year. So they would not draw the safeguard that the Minister claims is being given by this new provision in the Constitution.

One can look at other existing Commonwealth Acts. I will mention only a couple. Under the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act the offence of bribery carries a maximum penalty of one year. Surely, Mr Temporary Chairman, if you were accused of that offence you would want 12 fellow citizens to judge whether you were guilty of the facts that would amount to that offence, rather than relying upon one judicial officer. That is the safeguard that we look to in a trial by jury. Section 49 deals with undue influence, which carries a maximum penalty of one year; yet the safeguard of trial by jury is not guaranteed by the provision that this Government now wishes to insert in the Constitution.

One moves to the Royal Commission Act, where the maximum penalty for injury to a witness is one year. That would not draw this safeguard. Section 52 refers to dismissal by employers of witnesses. Again there is a maximum penalty of one year. That would not incur the safeguard. So why adopt this period of two years? There are many provisions currently existing in both State and Federal law that should in certain circumstances entitle a defendant to a trial by jury, yet he will not have that security by means of this constitutional change. I again ask the question: Why a period of two years?

The argument is reinforced when one looks at the opinions of the advisory committees to the Constitutional Commission. One finds that two advisory committees gave conflicting advice. The Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on Individual and Democratic Rights under the Constitution disagreed with the Advisory Committee on the Australian Judicial System. The former proposed that an accused person be entitled to a jury as of right in the case of all offences which are punishable by a term of imprisonment of 12 months or more. Why was that advice disregarded by the Government? Why did it not err on the side of caution? I would have thought that that would have been wise in this instance, particularly if the Minister is going to stand here and claim that this provision gives extra security. Certainly if one looks to the second reading speech of the Minister to try to find an answer to that question one will not find an answer. I want to know from the Minister why this Government chose the period of two years rather than 12 months as was recommended to it by the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on Individual and Democratic Rights.

I take the argument one step further and reflect briefly upon the position in the United States. As I understand it, a provision such as we are debating tonight does not exist in the United States. In the event of a penalty being a prescribed period of imprisonment, in the United States trial by jury is ensured. It is interesting to note that in the statutory provisions throughout the United States it has generally been accepted that in any case where a person is liable to imprisonment for a term of six months that person should be entitled to the protection of trial by jury. Why should we in this country be looking to a safeguard so much less than that which is applied in practice in the United States?

In those circumstances, how can the Minister therefore stand up and ensure us that the provision that he wishes to insert in the Constitution in lieu of the one that currently exists will offer greater security? Is it not a fact that what is happening is that one arbitrary test is simply being replaced by another arbitrary test? The one the Government is seeking to insert in the Constitution by virtue of this debate will be just as easily avoided by simply providing in the statute that the penalty shall be for a period of imprisonment of two years or a period slightly less than two years. These are serious questions. They have not been answered by the Government. I believe they call for an answer tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The test for the operation of the guarantee of jury trial is not arbitrary in the same way as the present test to do with trial by jury on indictment is. What we have is a decision by the Government to guarantee trial by jury throughout Australia to any person, except in certain mentioned cases, who is facing a very severe penalty of imprisonment for more than two years or any form of corporal punishment. Two years was taken not in ignorance of the decision by the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on the Australian Judicial System, which suggested that 12 months might be an adequate trigger mechanism. Honourable senators will recall that the Judicial Committee of the Constitutional Commission spoke in terms of a maximum of two years imprisonment or more, with the exceptions we have taken up. It was in relation to the report by the Judicial Committee that the Constitutional Commission itself thought that, whilst it was not an easy decision to make, given the fact that two years imprisonment appears to be, as it says, the general limit of magistrates' jurisdiction in Australia with very few exceptions, it seemed to be a reasonable line to draw in relation to the availability of this constitutional guarantee. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: If a lesser period was selected, the number of jury trials would be enormous.

I believe that it is the seriousness of the fate that might befall a person if convicted-being imprisoned for more than two years or suffering corporal punishment-that is the reason for selecting that particular trigger mechanism for the operation of the guarantee. Considering the operation of the magistrates courts and the general range of penalties that they are entitled to impose, that would, in a guaranteed form, continue the general range, level and availability of jury trials that we have now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) refer to what the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on the Australian Judicial System said in supporting the argument for two years. The Minister said that it preferred that approach on the basis that, if a lesser period were selected, the number of jury trials would be enormous. Does the Minister regard that as a statement of principle which determines the cut-off points?
—No.

—He does not? That seems to be its best argument, so I would be grateful for any other arguments that would suggest the appropriateness of two years. I draw the Minister's attention to section 42 of the Acts Interpretation Act, which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Offences against any Act which are punishable by imprisonment, for a period exceeding 6 months shall, unless the contrary intention appears, be indictable offences.

Does the Minister suggest that that provision should now be repealed? If not, what is to be the effect of it? Does the Minister regard a Constitution as a document which is intended to enshrine a system of fundamental principles according to which a nation or society is to be governed? If that is so, how does he reconcile the subsections of the proposed new section 80 which go into quite some detail about not only matters of venue but also size and composition of juries, waiver, and several other matters which would seem in themselves to be matters of detail best dealt with by an Act of parliament rather than in a Constitution?

Does the Minister agree that the freezing of two years is an arbitrary proposal which, if considered a mere decade ago, would have been at odds with various State crimes Acts around the nation? If so, how does he explain the Government's choice of two years as the convenient dividing line at this time? Can the Minister give any indication of whether it is suggested by the Government that the notion of trial by jury is under attack in Australia at all? Does the Minister agree that any changes to the Federal Constitution ought to be aimed at formulating a broad protective guarantee which reserves to the High Court the right to police the meaning and operation of that provision and that what this proposed new section does is to spell out detail which, by its nature, could well be the subject of different approaches by different State governments?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Temporary Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion.
—Under the sessional order, the question is put without debate.

—At this late hour of the night, we are addressing matters of very great importance. It was only in the last quarter of an hour, I believe, that honourable senators realised that we are going to be taken into about an hour of extra time this evening, from now until 11.30 p.m., to attempt to finalise this Bill. I can guarantee that it will never--
—Nobody is suggesting we will finalise it.
—That is not correct. There is no guarantee of finishing this Bill tonight.
—I assure the Senate that that certainly will not happen, because these matters are vital.
—Let us get back to debating them. I think it is a good idea that we debate them.

—It is about time that people started consulting around this place instead of just getting into huddles and consulting themselves. It is all very well for a fix-up between the Government and the Opposition of an extension of time for an hour without consulting anybody else. I do not know whether the Australian Democrats were consulted-I certainly was not consulted until I was consulted by Senator Colston for the Government Whip.
—With respect, that is his job.
—That is right. But, with respect, when was this deal cooked up? It was cooked up about only 20 minutes ago.
—That is not correct.

—When was it cooked up? I know that some people on the honourable senator's back bench did not know about it. As far as I am concerned, it is not good enough to make such deals and expect other people to follow along with them. That is all I have to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston raised several questions; I do not know whether I noted them all. He asked why we chose a period of two years. I thought I had replied to Senator Hill in relation to that. I believe I said at the time that it was the view of the Constitutional Commission that if a lesser period were selected, the number of jury trials would be enormous. But I do not see that as being a primary purpose for selecting two years. In fact, I think it would be rather a wrong purpose. What I wish to emphasise-and went on to emphasise-is that it is the simple case that one has to draw a line at a particular point. It seemed that to be faced with the period of deprivation of liberty for more than two years-or to suffer corporal punishment-meant that that was a rational time to choose, given the fact that, in general, it also seemed to coincide with the range of penalties available to magistrates courts. In other words, generally throughout Australia magistrates can impose a penalty of up to about two years. I know I am generalising.
—Generalising, yes.
—I am generalising-but it provides a rational basis, I believe, for selecting more than two years, and that was the view of the Judicial Committee and the Constitutional Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston raised a question concerning the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act-which is yet to be proclaimed. But the honourable senator will recall that that provides that all offences carrying a penalty of 12 months or more imprisonment are indictable. The honourable senator will recall the passage of that legislation. It has not yet been proclaimed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, reconcile that with your current proposal. That says 12 months; you now say two years.

—What we are saying is that, in relation to a provision applying Australia-wide, the setting of the line at more than two years imprisonment is a defensible and rational one. It is a fact that that has been provided for in the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act, but it does not, I think, require that we carry that particular trigger or criterion into the constitutional provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston asked whether trial by jury was under attack at all. I believe it was about a year and a half to two years ago. There were quite serious questions being raised about the jury trial system. I think it was only a bit of a flash in the pan.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom? Mick Miller?

—Yes. I am not sure, but he may have been amongst those who were speaking at the time. I believe that it does not have to be under severe attack to be worth guaranteeing in these particular instances. In so far as it is an important part of our heritage that persons facing a severe penalty be entitled to have the facts determined by a jury of their peers, it ought to be included in our constitutional arrangements.

—I also asked whether the Minister agreed that a constitution is a document intended to enshrine a system of fundamental principles. If so, how does he reconcile the inclusion of items of detail that are contained in the subsections of proposed section 80, which I suggest would be more appropriately included in an Act of parliament which can therefore be amended to suit local State needs if necessary but are not appropriate in a document that is spelling out grand principles?

—It is a longish section, but it makes clear, for example, that in relation to the waiver by the accused of trial by jury the State or Territory concerned can make a law regulating the size or composition of the jury or the provision for majority verdicts. It is simply put in to do the type of thing that Senator Alston is suggesting ought to be done-providing that those matters be dealt with under ordinary legislation.

—Proposed section 80 subsection (5) spells out a number of qualifications to the notion of trial by jury. On one view that could allow a jury of three persons to reach a majority decision after two hours deliberation. If one extended the hypothesis, it could allow for a very restricted form of jury to be chosen. All those things seem to be explicitly provided and allowed for. Does the Minister agree with a statement made by a spokesman for the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in response to criticisms of this very section by the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties that that is not a matter for concern because the High Court of Australia would simply ensure that the notion of trial by jury was determined and would override any State anomalies?

—I do agree with that. The fact is that a trial by jury has to remain a trial by jury. In the determination of the High Court I am sure that the concept which has been with us since Norman times of a jury of 12 persons to determine questions of fact will be the principal criterion it will use.

—But there are situations where, in a very long trial-take white collar crime-it can be highly desirable to empanel a jury of, say, 15 to allow for persons to be sick or unable to serve and, similarly, to take a verdict from a jury that might have been reduced to 10 as a result of sickness. Other arrangements can also be made for majority verdicts, as currently applies, I think, in at least three of the States. Is the Minister saying that any differences between the States would be encouraged by the Government to be overriden by the High Court?

—I think that the position is really the contrary. States are to be left free to determine such matters as the size and the composition of juries and the provision for majority verdicts. However, no doubt there would come a point at which the High Court of Australia would say that the provision has departed so far from the concept of trial by jury that it no longer falls within that proper description.
—Does the Minister agree that the proposed provision gives no guidance as to where the cut-off point should be?
—There is no particular indication as to where that point would be. It would be necessary to rely on the history of trial by jury as we have known it for 900 years.

—I draw the Minister's attention to the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act to which he recently referred, which shifts the onus in relation to offences carrying penalties in excess of 12 months. In view of the proposal here that two years be the benchmark, would the Minister propose that the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act provision be repealed if the referendum question were carried?

—It may be that the Commonwealth could make its own decision that whilst the guarantee provided for under the Constitution relates to offences which carry the possibility of imprisonment for more than two years or corporal punishment, nevertheless we could, as indeed could the States, provide for trial by jury in other situations, which had not reached that sort of guaranteed trigger. In other words, if it was desired to provide for trial by jury in a case which carried a lesser penalty, that would be quite within the province of the Commonwealth or a State.

—Precisely. Therefore, why is it such a fundamental principle that one should rule off the book at two years if the Minister can envisage situations in which a penalty of nearly 12 months might be sufficient to attract trial by jury? Does that not undermine the very notion of a principle? Is that not really saying that there may well be circumstances in which an offence attracting a 12-month penalty deserves trial by jury whereas there will be other situations in which only an offence carrying a penalty of two years will attract trial by jury. In other words, the principle is very flexible and, therefore, is not a principle at all.

—We do say that there is reached a point at which the peril facing a particular person, if that person is convicted and sentenced to imprisonment, is of an order which really leads to the conclusion that the punishment is of a severe enough quality to require that the facts be determined by a jury. In this particular proposal we think that when a person is facing imprisonment for more than two years, that point has been reached. However, it does not prevent one from saying in relation to a lesser term of imprisonment that it may be desirable to provide for trial by jury. However, if one is trying to provide an absolute guarantee to Australians, a point has to be selected. A period of more than two years imprisonment is a reasonably chosen point.
