However, it should not preclude any particular parliament from deciding that, as I say, in a situation of lesser peril, if you like, nevertheless trial by jury might be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If one is talking about fundamental principles, less than 10 years ago we would have had almost all the States treating 12 months as the cut-off period. The Government has had one advisory committee saying to it that 12 months is an appropriate cut-off period. The Government has the Acts Interpretation Act stating that six months is an appropriate cut-off period. The Government now has the Crimes Legislation Amendment Act stating that 12 months is the cut-off period. In other words, all of those other competing considerations are set against the recommendation of a committee which says two years. By allowing that crimes legislation provision to stay in force, the Government really is saying there could well be matters of principle that merit trial by jury where it attracts only a penalty of 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore ask, for consistency, why the Government should not simply retain that 12 months as its benchmark. I suggest the reason why the Government does not is the very reason that the Judicial Committee gave, that is, that the Government would inflate the number of trials that currently would attract trial by jury. That might not be a revenue neutral proposition that appeals. Nonetheless I suggest that if the Government is interested in principles and not simply in keeping down the cost of trials it would look at the weight of the evidence, which is very much in favour of 12 months rather than two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only a matter of repeating my answer. The question of the burden that might be imposed on the court system if we went down to 12 months is something which did provide some of the reasoning for the Australian Constitutional Commission. It is not for me, and I do not believe for the Government, a primary consideration at all. It is the extent of the imprisonment which a person may be faced with. More than two years seems to be such a peril which should attract this particular guarantee.

—Let me continue with the proposition put by Senator Alston. In Western Australia, if my memory serves me correctly, the criminal code provides that all offences which attract imprisonment of six months are indictable offences and require trial by jury. Is it not a reasonable argument that we should pick up the minimum for each State and incorporate that as the benchmark, rather than go for the maximum of two years--
—It is cheaper.

—It is cheaper inasmuch as the Government is purporting to offer safeguards and security, but it is diminishing them rather than starting at the base point to ensure that the present position is incorporated in the Government's constitutional amendment.

—Nothing in this provision will prevent the State of Western Australia from deciding to do that, as it has now, as a matter of response no doubt to its own concern for its citizens and as a consequence of whatever political pressures it might feel require it to make such a decision. It can do so under this referendum proposal. All we are saying is that when the point is reached when the Western Australian Parliament provides for an offence to be punishable by a term of imprisonment of more than two years then the guarantee comes into effect. There is no incompatibility between the two situations. It is obviously not the proposal that the Constitution should impose on the Western Australian Government, an obligation to do what it now does as a result of its own decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an absolute impertinence for the Commonwealth to assume that it has some divine right to impose its arbitrary figure in the Constitution where already without exception there is proper accommodation in the States. What is it that has led now to this proposal, when trial by jury is guaranteed to the extent that it is legislated for in each State? (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: In Western Australia, in general the maximum term of imprisonment which a magistrate may impose is six months. Speaking generally-there may be specific statutes which modify this-in New South Wales, for example, magistrates can impose up to three years imprisonment; in Queensland, two years; South Australia, two years; Tasmania, three years; the Australian Capital Territory, two years; and the Northern Territory, six months. According to the note in front of me, the period in Victoria is not specified. So there are variations amongst the States and two years, as I have said, seems to be a period of sufficient severity to attract a guarantee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I break new ground. I refer to the waiver of trial by jury. Proposed new section 80 (5) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing in subsection (1) prevents the making, or affects the operation, of a law to the extent that the law:
(a) permits waiver by the accused of trial by jury . . .
At first sight that would seem to be a desirable principle, but it does not specify the conditions under which trial by jury may be waived. The Minister in his second reading speech said:
It is not, however, contemplated that waiver of the right to trial by jury would apply in the case of the most serious offences, such as murder or major drug offences.

In view of the fact that murder is usually a State offence, how does the Minister suggest that this constitutional provision would operate to preclude a State government from allowing waiver of trial by jury for capital offences?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the second reading speech indicated that there would be some constitutional impediment of the sort spoken about. We are just saying that as a matter of practice and anticipation, in the case of a very serious trial such as for murder or for a very serious drug offence, one would not expect to have waiver of trial by jury by the accused. I think that is perfectly understandable.

—I wish to deal with the provision relating to members of the defence forces. Section 80 (1) makes exceptions for trial for contempt of court or the trial of a member of a Defence Force of the Commonwealth before a court-martial on disciplinary offences. Does the Minister agree that that applies only to serving members of the forces; in other words, that serving members would not be entitled to trial by jury, no matter how serious the offence, whereas former members of the defence forces and even prisoners of war would, as a result, be entitled to trial by jury?

—The trial of members of the Defence Force before a court-martial under a law relating to the discipline of the Defence Force of the Commonwealth is exempt, so obviously that provision relates to members of the defence forces. Section 61 of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 provides that a member of the Defence Force is guilty of an offence if he does any act or omission which, if done in the Australian Capital Territory, would be an offence against the law of the Commonwealth in the Australian Capital Territory or the Crimes Act in its application to the Australian Capital Territory. Under the current law, non-defence related offences committed by defence personnel may be tried before defence tribunals or civil or criminal courts. The Director of Public Prosecutions has put out guidelines relating to the prosecution of Defence Force personnel in relation to non-defence related offences, and those prosecutions will be required to comply with proposed section 80.

—Does the Minister assert that it applies only to serving members and that, therefore, former members, defence civilians or prisoners of war would have an entitlement to trial by jury that would not be one to which serving members would be eligible?

—As proposed new section 80 (1) says, the exception relates to the `trial of a member of the Defence Force of the Commonwealth before a court-martial'. Obviously the other essentials to which Senator Alston referred-a former member, a defence civilian or a prisoner of war-are not included in that particular exception. The exception relates only to a member.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have learnt that the Government is determined to offer to prisoners a security less than it is the practice of the Supreme Court of the United States of America to offer, I wonder whether the matter might be approached in another way. When we look at the Government's proposed section 80 we find it offers the security of trial by jury to an accused liable to imprisonment for more than two years or to any form of corporal punishment. In other words, it looks also to the quality of the offence in that limited way.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the Government might be prepared to consider extending that provision even further and including also the right to trial by jury in any offence that involves an element of dishonesty. It seems to me that there are offences which are going to incur a potential penalty of less than two years imprisonment and for which the defendant should be entitled to the judgment by a jury rather than by a judge or magistrate. Particularly, as I indicate, I have in mind offences of dishonesty, where an assessment must be made of the state of mind of the person, offences that are going to impose upon a convicted person, a person found guilty, a penalty far beyond that which is imposed in terms of imprisonment or a fine: a mark that will stand with that person for the rest of his or her life.

Surely in these circumstances, where, as I said, the assessment must be made of the state of mind, the defendant should be entitled to judgment by his fellows. Therefore, does the Government have any objection to amending this provision, as we know the Government is prepared to amend another of its Bills, to add the words `or involving a determination of the element of dishonesty' after the words `corporal punishment'? If it is not prepared to do so, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we are not picking and choosing between offences or categories or types of offences. We are making a line in accordance with the penalty that might be imposed by the court. I see no real reason to think that a person is going to carry a greater burden through life because he formed a dishonest intent to deal wrongly with somebody else's property than if he formed an intent to abuse some girl by way of indecent assault. Once we start looking to specific intents or some sort of mental state in the accused person which is an essential element of the offence, I think we will find that the particular category suggested by Senator Hill will not necessarily be the only one where a person might carry a terrible burden through life if he formed that particular intent.
—You might be able to improve it for me, then.
—Not tonight, Senator.

—There is one other subject raised by Senator Alston that I want to explore a bit further because I think the Government's intention in relation to this provision is important; that is, the provision that nothing in subsection (1) prevents the making or affects the operation of a law to the extent that the law regulates the composition of the jury. It seems to me that there are varying practices in relation to the composition of juries. There is a trend, particularly with fraud cases, to move towards juries of specialists. I am interested to know whether that is what the Government intends to cover by inserting these provisions-to allow the States to provide for juries of specialists. Where will the limitation then lie? For example, in the Government's opinion, would it allow a State to provide for a prerequisite of, say, tertiary qualifications in accounting or law in the composition of its specialist jury of, say, three in a serious fraud case?

—I was going to agree up to the end. Obviously, composition is an important matter which could well be approached in the way outlined by Senator Hill, by ensuring that a particular jury had the competence to deal with a particularly complex fraud or tax case. I believe that that sort of composition would be available to a State parliament, or indeed the Commonwealth Parliament, in relation to a jury trial. When the honourable senator mentioned a panel of three he was, in my view, getting too far away from the core notion of trial by jury, which, since Norman times, has been a body of 12 persons. I do not think that a panel of three would qualify as a jury.

—If one believes that the whole notion of a jury is contrary to the idea of specialists determining guilt, does one take it that no security is provided by this constitutional amendment to a person charged with an offence when that person would prefer to be tried by a jury comprising a mixture of skills and experiences rather than particular specialist qualifications?

—I believe that a State parliament, or indeed this Commonwealth Parliament, will have to make a judgment on that matter and live with the political consequences, if you like. A State parliament, for example, is very consciously being given an ability to determine the composition of a jury. No doubt the State parliament would work it out bearing in mind the possible expectations of an accused, such as Senator Hill has in mind, but also the public interest of ensuring that a competent body of persons determines very complex questions of fact. We are leaving it to the parliament concerned to make that judgment on balance.

—I ask the Minister to confirm whether, if a person were charged with and convicted of three separate offences, each incurring a maximum penalty of two years imprisonment, that person may well find that, as the court does not have to provide for concurrent sentences, he comes out of the trial with a six-year term of imprisonment, but yet he does not have the security that is provided with a trial by jury.

—The provision relates to the trial of a person for an offence, so each offence would be taken separately. The report of the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on the Australian Judicial System says that liability to cumulative sentences-I think that Senator Hill said `concurrent'-for separate offences should not attract a guarantee, although a charge attracting a statutory maximum of more than two years because of prior convictions would fall within the proposed test. We are not looking at the cumulative impact. In terms of Senator Hill's example, we are looking at each offence separately.

—It does not give security, therefore, but it still leaves the question as to why it should not attract that guarantee. That question seems to have been left open by the Advisory Committee. Perhaps the Minister will let us know the Government's reason why the security is not to be given in those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

The provision looks to the trial of a person for a particular and single offence. The possibility of an accumulated sentence for a series of convictions is not dealt with by way of a guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have previously, in both the second reading stage and in the committee stage, addressed many questions to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) with regard to the implications of the acquisition of property on just terms. I am particularly concerned that the notes in the explanatory memorandum do not give any answers to those very issues that were raised by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Hatton, in his telex to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That telex was incorporated in Hansard during the second reading debate. Of course, it was quite lengthy. It raised many issues that need to be addressed and properly answered by the Minister. This evening I have also raised the question of how the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) will be treated with regard to the future acquisition of property on just terms. With the proposals to take self-government many steps further, it is very important that the 300,000 people who live in Canberra can rely on this Government to understand fully and to know that the body politic for self-government in the ACT is not, in fact, going to be discriminated against. I look to the Minister for his answers.

—In relation to the Territories, if either the Commonwealth or a Territory legislature makes provision for the acquisition of property from a person in a Territory-for example, one of the 300,000 residents in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) of whom Senator Tambling spoke-that acquisition has to be on just terms. The same relates to a body corporate. In relation to an acquisition from the body politic-that is, the Northern Territory Government, or the ACT government if that comes to pass-the question of acquisition of property from that particular entity will be governed by other relationships determined at less than a constitutional guaranteed level between the Commonwealth and that particular Territory entity. That will be determined, as it is at the moment, by way of ordinary legislation which, in the case of the Northern Territory Government, provides for acquisition on just terms. So it will be done by way of legislation to give flexibility in relation to the various stages and types of Territories which are involved in the Australian political system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to consider further the implications of this proposal with particular regard to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). I am certainly aware that the Commonwealth has on several occasions in recent years legislated to avoid the payment of compensation on specific Territory acquisitions, for example, Aboriginal land granted out of Territory land, the Kakadu National Park, the ban on mining operations in Kakadu and the Petermann land boundaries. I find that the concepts that the Minister is advancing, that the Commonwealth can, if it chooses, acquire from a body politic other than on just terms is, in fact, very discriminatory against average Australian citizens. I fear for the people of the ACT if a similar implication can arise. I would think that the situation is very similar to those issues that were canvassed and raised very properly in this place and in Canberra by Senator Vanstone with regard to other weaknesses and flaws that were ascertained with regard to these constitutional referendum Bills as they related to the ACT. Here again we see a very different set of principles and concepts being developed for the Northern Territory which is clearly on a path towards statehood. I do not believe that the contents of the explanatory memorandum will be fairly reflected in the referendum that will be put to all the people of Australia. The long title of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: An act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion, and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any Government.

The Minister can hang his hat if he likes on the word `person' which appears in that particular title, but any person who is a citizen of a Territory, and therefore is a member of that body politic, is being discriminated against very deliberately and constitutionally by this Government. As they move towards self-government the people of Canberra need to be very fearful of the land acquisition powers that will now be vested in the Commonwealth under these provisions. I would like the Minister to state clearly whether it is the Government's intention to exclude particularly the Canberra self-governing body, its body politic, and to put the citizens of Canberra at a severe disadvantage, just as the citizens of the Northern Territory are, apropos any citizen of any State?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it absolutely clear that the citizens of the Northern Territory or of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), should it be the case that their property is sought to be acquired by the Commonwealth, fall within the constitutional guarantees and will be provided with fair compensation in relation to the acquisition of that property. It is in relation to the governments of the Territories that the constitutional guarantee does not apply. The governments of those Territories-and an example is the ACT should any arrangement be made to allow for self-government to be established-should be aware that the constitutional guarantee would not extend to dealings between the Commonwealth and those bodies in relation to the acquisition of their properties by the Commonwealth.

—We are seeing a typical example of the Commonwealth imposing severe restrictions on the power of the States and Territories while, at the same time, providing nice exceptions for the Commonwealth because it feels it has some fathering role with regard to the Territories. I would like to draw a further matter to the Minister's attention. If the Commonwealth or the High Court of Australia recognises the Aboriginal antecedent titles over property, the Territories, the States and the Commonwealth will be locked into, on any view, what must be regarded as massive compensation by the very issues now being raised in this legislation. I would like the Minister to state what precedents the Government believes will flow from this legislation, particularly with regard to the compensation and Aboriginal antecedent title.

—The High Court has established certain principles in relation to the definition of property. If some form of title comes within the scope of the term property as defined by the High Court, of course the Commonwealth will have to provide compensation in accordance with the just terms provision. That is all that can be said.

—I am amazed at the admission by the Minister that it is obviously the Government's intention to go down the path of providing massive compensation in the instances of the creation of Aboriginal antecedent titles. I also ask the Minister: In what way do the proposals that have been suggested by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, in the preamble proposed to the legislation to create the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission confirm the intent of the Government to ensure that the provisions put forward in that preamble will create an opportunity for both compensation and Aboriginal antecedent title?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are straying a long way from the Bill to alter the Constitution in relation to the acquisition of property. I have already said-and it is all I am prepared to say-that should the High Court decide that any particular relationship of a person to a piece of land can be said to be a property relationship, the acquisition of that property will carry with it the requirement that just terms be provided by way of compensation to the person whose property has been acquired. I am not going to comment on any particular instance where that may prove to be the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —When we began the debate on clause 1 of this Bill I indicated that I was of the opinion that the mixture of propositions that had been put together in question 4 and dealt with in this Bill had been put together deliberately in an attempt to camouflage the real aim of the question, which is to attack state aid for private schools, for religion based non-government schools. I pointed out, as did Senator Harradine, that the question must stand or fall as one, that it is not open to anyone to say that he or she is in favour of the trial by jury proposition or the acquisition of property proposition and against the religion proposition. Because of the linking of these issues, it is not possible to separate out a single question. Therefore, as I said earlier, the questions stand or fall together. A person who disagrees with any of the three propositions must vote no to question 4.

SPEECH.PARA: As this is the committee stage and we are looking at the technical aspects of the Bill, I want to ask three questions. The first concerns what the Bill attempts to do, and I will look at what the explanatory memorandum has to say on that point. Secondly, I want to deal with why the Bill falls short of what it sets out to do and then, thirdly, to examine the consequences of that falling short. I direct the Committee's attention to the following statement in the explanatory memorandum:

There is, however, no change-in the wording of section 116-that would render the decision of the High Court in Attorney-General (Victoria) (at the relation of Black) v. Commonwealth (1981) 146 CLR 559 inapplicable to the new section.

That is a very accurate statement, but what clever wording! It says that the case will not be inapplicable. It most certainly will not be inapplicable. It will be most applicable, but the effect of that will be to reverse the situation that we got to when Black's case was deliberated upon and a majority decision of the judges, the exception being Mr Justice Murphy, found for the defendants and found that state aid to private schools did not breach the Constitution. A close scrutiny of the judgments in that case bear out what I have said. I would particularly like to deal with the judgments of the then Chief Justice, Sir Garfield Barwick, Mr Justice Stephen and Mr Justice Mason, the current Chief Justice. All three of those judgments deal with the words `make any laws for'. Sir Garfield Barwick at page 583 of his judgment said:

A law which in operation may indirectly enable a church to further the practice of religion is a long way away from a law to establish religion as that language properly understood would require it to be if the law were to be in breach of S. 116.
He said further:
The law must be a law for it, i.e. intended and designed to set up the religion as an institution of the Commonwealth.
Mr Justice Stephen said in the judgment at page 606 in relation to the said section:

the conjunction of `establishing' with `law' with `religion' gives it a particular meaning . . . to speak of a religion being established by the laws of a country may well be to include much more than the act of according material recognition and status to a set of beliefs, a system of moral philosophy or particular doctrines of faith; it would certainly include the recognition of a particular religion or sect, with its priestly hierarchy and tenets, as that of the nation.
Mr Justice Mason really made the bottom line statement when he said at page 617:
. . . as I have already indicated, the principal obstacle to an acceptance of the plaintiffs' argument lies in the words `any law for establishing any religion'.
He went on to say:
the form of religious inequality which has been forbidden by s. 116 is that form of religious inequality which is expressed by the critical words `any law for establishing any religion'.

The important point is that the proposed amendment to the existing section 116 deletes the words `make any laws for' and makes a corresponding grammatical alteration to the operative words `establishing, imposing and prohibiting'. The explanatory memorandum contends that the new wording simply extends the prohibition contained in section 116 to Executive action. In the judgments that I have already mentioned, at page 580 the Chief Justice dealt with the question of subsidiary legislation, when he said:
The prohibition will include such subsidiary legislation which is within the authority of an Act of the Parliament but which in itself offends the terms of the section.

Thus the Government must be contemplating actions other than delegated legislation, whether or not it is brought into being by executive action. On the matter of administrative function, the Chief Justice said at pages 580 to 581:

The next observation I wish to make as to s. 116 is that it is directed to the making of law. It is not dealing with the administration of a law but, if that administration is within the ambit of the authority conferred by the statute, and does amount to the establishment of a religion, the statute which supports it will most probably be a statute for establishing a religion and therefore void as offending as against s. 116.

Thus the concern for Executive action breaching the prohibition is not sustained. I was interested to hear earlier tonight, in answer to questions, Senator Tate say that he was of the opinion that under the Acts Interpretation Act the explanatory memorandum, as it would accompany an Act, as he described it, would be pertinent to a subsequent interpretation of the Constitution. That is not necessarily a proposition with which I would agree, but it is one that he put forward. Thus I think that it is particularly important to challenge, firstly, the statement in the explanatory memorandum that it is merely meant to extend the prohibition in existing section 116 to Executive action. That is not sustained. Secondly, Black's case, which is the definitive authority in this area, would remain applicable or, in the terms of the memorandum, would not be inapplicable to new section 116.

Before I go back to the implications of Black's case for the new wording of the section, I would like to say that an overriding concern comes through on the proposed alterations, and that is the concept of extending religious freedom and the necessary fetters which must apply to all freedoms within a democratic society. The overriding concern with the concept of extending religious freedom is the legitimate desire of a society to have religious practices not offending against established interests and freedoms. That was acknowledged by the Constitutional Commission when it said, at page 624 of volume II of its report:
Like all freedoms, however, freedom of religion cannot be absolute. It must be qualified at times by other social interests and freedoms.
The present provision is satisfactory. The proposed alterations render the law uncertain.

Two examples of unacceptable religious practices spring to mind. I have already mentioned one in my speech at the second reading stage. I brought to light the practice of a particular Muslim sect of female circumcision designed to desensitise young girls. The second is a more recent case which came to light in a report in the Age newspaper of 18 May dealing with a case that took place in Melbourne on 27 March 1987 when a man chained his wife to a bedstead and abused and used her in a sexual way as were his rights, he pleaded, under the Koran by way of atonement for his wife's so-called infidelity. He was found guilty of the offence of assault. When the jury had rendered its verdict, the judge said:

And, in so far as the cultures and religious beliefs of members of the community permit serious offences against the law, then the rule of law must take precedence and further efforts must be made to achieve a valid integration.

He was found guilty of assaulting and unlawfully and injuriously imprisoning the woman and detaining her against her will. The offence occurred between 28 and 30 March 1987 and the jury rendered a guilty verdict. That sort of behaviour is unacceptable in the Australian community. Yet, by the so-called extended freedoms, it is conceivable that that sort of so-called freedom of practise of religion could be protected in the guise of a guaranteed freedom. The Constitutional Commission's report contains those concerns expressed by the Advisory Committee when it stated in volume II that the Advisory Committee recognised the possible implications that such an extension of religious freedom could have on other legitimate State activities, particularly in the field of State education; for example, where a State education Act requires the registration of schools.

However, the Advisory Committee was confident that the courts would resolve any problems that might arise. To again render such a fundamental question of state aid uncertain, as the report admits it would do, and hope that it will work out all right is a risk that this nation cannot afford to run. The point is that the state aid issue raged in this country, as did the question of sectarianism generally, for over a decade. There are those in the Australian Labor Party who are as committed as ever to getting rid of state aid to private schools, to religious based schools. Indeed, Mr Halfpenny and Mr Hartley were both original plaintiffs in Black's case. Already there has been an increase in the number of children attending independent, religious based schools. It is projected that, by 1990, 29 per cent of school age children in primary and secondary education will be in private independent schools. So there are plenty of reasons to fire up the anti-state aiders. I think it is well to remember an article in the National Times. That was written in 1979 by one Robert Milliken. The article reads:
Having failed by political pressure to destroy government financial support for Church Schools, the opponents of state aid have launched a final make-or-break challenge in the High Court.
If they succeed in ending state aid then the system of Church Schools in Australia, as we know it, will disappear.
If they fail, then the battle . . . may be finally put to rest.

They did fail, but some people never give up. This proposed amendment could mean that we would again see all the bitterness rage. As long as section 116 remains unchanged, state aid to non-government church-based schools is protected. Should the fourth question be passed and the section be changed, we will render uncertain the future of state aid for schools in this country. The law as it is now is certain. The change that this Government intends to bring in renders it uncertain. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be useful, given the length of Senator Bishop's contribution, to try to deal with some of the points before they completely fade from memory. We ought to put things in perspective. The fact is that the provision of section 116 of the Constitution has only applied obviously to restrict the Commonwealth making laws in ways which are prohibited by that section. Only a few years ago, in mid-1984, the South Australian Supreme Court case entitled Grace Bible Church Inc. v. Reedman was well publicised. It came as a surprise to many people. It was only then that the general Australian populace became aware, as did many religious leaders that I know, that the common law did not provide sufficient protection against a State parliament which wished to infringe on the religious freedom of the State's residents.
—Which State has done anything like that?

—The Grace Bible Church was claiming that it was done in this instance by the South Australian Government in the guise of the educational authority which had the task of licensing non-government schools.
—What was the decision?

—The decision was that the common law has never contained a fundamental guarantee of the inalienable right of religious freedom of expression, nor has such a right ever been created in South Australia. Even if it had, such a right could have been invaded by Act of Parliament of the State. That led to the dismissal of the appeal by the Grace Bible Church against its conviction for contravening section 72f of the Education Act in the Adelaide magistrates court.

—Millhouse said in his judgment, `Thankfully, ours is still a democratic country and its supremacy accordingly may be often curbed politically'. In other words, the constraints of the democratic society--
—Order!

—I do recall Mr Justice Zelling, who was the first judge to deliver a judgment in the case, making a point. Unfortunately, I have not marked any quotes by Mr Justice Zelling but Mr Justice White said:

SPEECH.PARA: The common law has always recognized the supremacy of parliaments . . .
I think that point needs to be emphasised. He went on to say:
There are no fetters upon the power to make laws affecting religious freedom.
This is a point that comes through the judgments. Mr Justice White put it well on page 582 of Australian Law Reports. He stated:

As I said, the common law has never contained a fundamental guarantee of the inalienable right of religious freedom and expression. Rather, the common law has supported the supremacy of the Parliament.

I think it was in view of that decision in particular that persons were led to consider that the sort of protection of the dignity of the individual which is provided for under section 116 in relation to laws made by the Commonwealth ought to be extended in a way which gives protection against the use of the lawmaking power by a State parliament or indeed its executive power. The need to give to our Australian people, wherever they may be and under whichever jurisdiction they happen to find themselves-whether it be Commonwealth or State-that sort of protection we think is important. Obviously the framers of the Constitution thought that it was so important that it was placed in section 116 of the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are different words, aren't they?

—The change of language is meant to extend the freedom by not confining the protection offered by the section to occasions when the freedoms are infringed by a law passed by a parliament. We say that there could be executive action and we are just, out of an abundance of caution, covering the situation. There could be executive action which infringed on those freedoms or attempted to establish a religion. In that situation we say that also ought to be prohibited and rendered unconstitutional. The change of language is designed to embrace a much wider range of possible government activity than would be the case if one spoke about only the making of laws, which is simply the legislative arm of government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop is quite correct in saying that the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) case was an absolute landmark case. Senator Bishop will be aware that the decision which permitted the funding of independent schools was made in the face of the claim that to do so was, on the part of the Commonwealth, to make a law for establishing any religion. The High Court of Australia rejected that particular argument. The explanatory memorandum states:

There is, however, no change that would render the decision of the High Court in Attorney-General (Victoria) (at the relation of Black) v. Commonwealth (1981) 146 CLR 559 inapplicable to the new section.

It is believed that the crucial decision in the DOGS case was that the section in relation to prohibition-shall not make any law for prohibiting the establishment of any religion-has, as its core, the notion of setting up an official religion or church, or giving a particular denomination some particular status within the society. That was important because one was dealing with a law of the Commonwealth. We are simply saying that by deleting those words and extending the scope of the protection to embrace Executive action also of a kind that might not be embraced by the words `shall not make and law for' does not do away with the essence of the decision in the DOGS case, which was to do with the interpretation of establishing any religion along the lines, as I said, of setting up an official religion or giving a particular religion or denomination some specific status within society. (Quorum formed)
The Constitutional Commission, in its first report dated 19 April 1988, says in relation to the sort of clause that we are now discussing:
We do not intend the proposed alteration to section 116 to affect the legitimate legislative capacity of the States and Territories. Section 116 would prevent-
as the amendment has been proposed-

a State or Territory from passing a law to establish an official Church or to impose a religious test as a qualification for any public office. On the other hand, it would not affect the provision of State or Territory aid to independent schools, nor would it prevent a State or Territory from maintaining appropriate educational standards.
So the Constitutional--

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on.
—It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Balanced against the individual's right to freedom of religion is the legitimate right of the State or Territory to maintain adequate standards of instruction. Where conflicts arise we believe that the courts will be able to differentiate between religious activities and those activities which properly become subject to regulation by educational authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would leave it up to a bench of Murphys, would you?

—No, but I believe that the decision in the DOGS case-where we have six of the seven judges putting down a decision which made it very clear that the funding of independent schools with a religious ethos was compatible with the prohibition on the Commonwealth's legislative power as contained in the present section 116-as mentioned in the explanatory memorandum, will help the judges, in any future decision in relation to the new section 116, to adopt a like interpretation. That is a reasonable expectation in relation to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Female circumcision is an important matter. But it is clear, as the Jehovah's Witnesses case in the Second World War demonstrated, that there is a balancing in relation to any rights in our society and that the claim that one is acting at the behest of some religious principle or dictate is not sufficient to override society's ordinary interest in maintaining itself either against an external aggressor or as a society which is regulated by criminal law and criminal codes. I do not want to make any particular opinion or judgment in relation to female circumcision, but in so far as some ethnic communities in Australia are concerned I do not know whether they claim the Muslim religion as their reason for imposing this practice on young females or whether it is not rather something that derives from a certain cultural background. I have certainly understood from my reading that that is the case--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a Muslim sect.

—Yes, I know, and people who practise this come from cultures which are Muslim. I believe the matter is more tribal, if I may put it that way, than religious. But that is beside the point. If the type of operation involved is a severe mutilation, then so far as that assault on the young woman is concerned I believe the court would have the scope to make a decision as to whether the interests of the community in the maintenance of its ordinary criminal laws overrode the claims about freedom of religion. Indeed, in relation to the situation of the woman being tied up and beaten--
—Chained.
—And for some long time--
—Three days.
—Yes, and beaten, then I do not believe that, on the sorts of principles--
—What you believe is not terribly relevant.

—I am saying that it is not unfounded because in the Jehovah's Witnesses case it was made clear by the High Court that there is a balance between the right of a person, in his own mind, to express his religious philosophy in activities without let or hindrance in order to satisfy his religious scruples, and the interests of society in maintaining its proper provision for the protection of persons against criminal activity such as the sort of wounding and battery and forced imprisonment that the honourable senator is describing.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make three points that arise from what the Minister has had to say. Firstly, he talked about what the future may hold for us in terms of what courts may decide in the future. Instead of relying on the settled law as it is now established under the present section of the Constitution, he speculated upon what the changed circumstances may be and was full of conjecture and beliefs and hopes that he may be right in his opinion. The second matter is Black's case, the DOGS case. Each of the decisions of the justices that I mentioned earlier-that is, Barwick, Mason and Stephen-rested upon the fact that section 116 provides for the making of laws for a particular purpose. In each of their decisions they used those words and said that their decision was hinged on those particular words being in the section.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point relates to the American experience. Black's case held that the American experience, as it has been interpreted over the decades, is not relevant to the interpretation of section 116 as it presently stands. Indeed, Mr Justice Mason stated:
What is important for our purposes is that the interpretation of the clause in the First Amendment-
that is of the United States Constitution-
which was accepted at the end of the nineteenth century was that expressed by Cooley and Storey.
Cooley, in his Principles for Constitutional Law, third edition, at page 224, wrote:
By establishment of religion is meant the setting up of or recognition of a state church, or at least the conferring upon one church of special favours and advantages which are denied to others.
Storey wrote in Commentaries on the Constitution of the United States, fifth edition, in 1891:

The changes are to make the section read, `shall not establish any religion', and to add `a State or Territory' to the end of the clause. The Government's intention is to widen the powers of the provision and to include a State or Territory. We should understand the history of section 116 because then we will know that from the outset it was a limitation; it did not confer a new right on Christians. The great irony is that other than the last phrase of the section, which says that no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth, the section is meaningless except in terms of the restrictions or inhibitions it places on people. The powers of the Federal Parliament rest upon and are drawn from the Constitution and are limited to what the Constitution provides. It seems to me that the Federal Parliament has no power to do anything except that which is granted to it expressly or implicitly as necessary.

I read the 128 clauses of the Constitution as being clauses which set out the limitations of the Federal Parliament's jurisdiction. Of course, in certain cases it is restricted by the powers of the States. The Constitution is a document which tells us what the Parliament shall do; what it will do; what it can do. It is not a list of prohibitions. That is why this section is so incongruous by comparison with the rest of the sections. When section 116 was being debated, it was Barton who said in the 1898 debates:

The real question that may arise under the Constitution is whether the Commonwealth can make a law establishing or prohibiting the free exercise of any religion. Given that there was no provision conferring such a power, the clause saying that the Commonwealth is not to legislate in respect of religion seems to me to be somewhat pointless and irrelevant. The truth of the matter is that the Commonwealth, in the 128 sections, has no power to make any law for establishing a religion or for imposing any religious observance or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion.

Ironically, the founding fathers put that section in the Constitution because of the preamble in our Constitution stating that the people in the various States rely on the blessing of Almighty God. It was Henry Higgins who raised the American case in which it was ruled that the United States of America (USA) was a Christian country. In fact, he used the words `Christian country' in the debates. It was put that America was a religious country. That 1892 decision caused very real strife in New York. Some people went out with placards saying that religion should be imposed on the rest of the community. There were those in equal conflict who said that they should be protected from the outrages of those propositions as to what impositions should be cast upon people as a result of religion.

As a consequence of the Supreme Court decision, a law was passed and carried into effect prohibiting the opening of the Chicago Exhibition on a Sunday. I think that that occurred in 1892. Higgins's argument was that because it had been found in a judgment that the USA was a religious country, a law which prohibited an exhibition being opened in Chicago on a Sunday could be upheld. That caused a great deal of pain for people such as Seventh Day Adventists, who believed that their day of rest was on Saturday. Their welfare and their businesses were affected by their not being able to open on a Sunday. So there was a very real conflict and, in the minds of many people, a threat as a result of that decision.

SENATE 31 May-1 June 1988
31 May-1 June 1988 SENATE

The effect of that law was to impose a religious observance. It has been judged in Australia-so far, at least-that closing on Sundays does not constitute a religious observance, although we know that it was and, in the minds of most Christians, it is. It is now judged that it is a normal day of rest and an entitlement of hardworking Australian people, industrious as we are. We need one day a week for rest, recreation and, perhaps, resuscitation. Higgins's concern was that if a country such as the United States did not make reference in its constitutional preamble to the Almighty God what could be done with the laws of Australia where we call upon Almighty God for strength and for help. That is why he was particularly concerned to ensure that section 116 was included to compensate for the preamble which was already included.

Of course, the preamble was not included by accident or because we were a Christian or religious country. It was a deliberate political decision because, of course, the same problems had arisen in the US. At the time of the Philadelphia Convention there was a long discussion, particularly by those people in Massachusetts, which had laws establishing a church. There was grave concern that the Puritans from Massachusetts and others would vote against the American Constitution because it did not include a reference to God. Higgins was concerned to get the numbers. He made a political decision to ensure that the reference to God was included in the preamble in order, if I might put it this way, to get the Christians on side. Having got the Christians on side by including that reference in the preamble, he had to get on side the Seventh Day Adventists and everybody else who felt threatened by its inclusion as a result of the US decision. That is why he included section 116. That is why we have section 116 today. Higgins made an interesting observation. He said:

—Senator Tate quoted that as his authority for saying that there is no intrinsic right in common law to freedom of religion. But for what it is worth, let me just remind honourable senators what Millhouse J. had to say. I think this is the point. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Thankfully, ours is still a democratic community and that supremacy accordingly may be and often is curbed politically.

The bottom line of that-the part that Senator Tate left out-is that as long as we have a democratic political system of the type that we have there is no fear of tyranny. People do not fear the imposition of religion upon their daily lives; nor is there the likelihood of the rights of Christians being taken from them. But ever it is the truth that Bills of Rights and constitutions might set out at the beginning to tell people what they can do; invariably at the end of the day they tell people what they cannot do. Invariably they remove people's rights. As Senator Tate well knows, when the American Constitution was first written there was no Bill of Rights in it; I think it was only Jefferson badgering afterwards that caused the First Amendment to be put in. At the end of the day, as with this proposal, there are restrictions on people's rights. That is exactly what will happen in this case. It has happened in America in numerous cases.

The interesting point about section 116 is that its words are almost absolutely plagiarised from the American Constitution. The American Constitution says that Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion. That is the very modest variation, but the wording was taken straight out of the American system. Of course, the provision was put in the American Constitution because there had been persecution of those who were not of the Christian faith. They were denied a right to vote and in some cases a right to own property. In some cases, if they were not of the right faith they were required to pay extra taxes. It was in that environment that the American Constitution was written-quite a different environment from that which we had in Australia. What Senator Tate is seeking to do is to extend section 116 further to restrict people's rights. I do not need to state the obvious. SPEECH.PARA: Of course there have been many cases in the United States, as we have heard, while on the other hand our section 116 has been interpreted by the High Court of Australia on only a few occasions. It is a reasonable proposition to put that in as much as section 116 was taken from the United States Constitution similar arbitrary interpretations of provisions could apply. I refer to the United States Supreme Court's interpretation of the two limbs of the First Amendment. The first is that Congress shall not make laws respecting the establishment of a religion. To argue about the wording, as Justice Murphy said, is hair splitting. Our words, of course, are `for establishing a religion'. The other limb prohibits the free exercise of such religion.

As I think has been mentioned today, the foundation stone for the United States Supreme Court interpretation of the First Amendment was laid in Everson v. the Board of Education in 1947, when New Jersey legislation authorised school districts to subsidise the transportation of students who attended church schools. Of course from this case came the following famous pronouncement by Justice Hugo L. Black, which has been referred to so often this evening, that the establishment clause means at least this:

Neither a State nor the Federal Government can set up any church, neither can pass laws which aid one religion, aid all religions or prefer one religion over another. No tax in any amount, large or small, can be levied to support any religious activities or institutions, whatever they may be called, or whatever form they may adopt to teach and practise religion . . . In the words of Jefferson, the clause against the establishment of religion by law was intended to erect `a wall of separation between church and State'.
31 May-1 June 1988 SENATE
SENATE 31 May-1 June 1988
31 May-1 June 1988 SENATE

The next year, in 1948, the court had to decide on the so-called release time case, McCallum v. the Board of Education, in which religious instruction was provided to public schools. Notwithstanding that the instruction was undertaken by religious authorities and that the program was voluntary, the court found that it infringed the principles set down in the Everson case because the religious instruction took place in the class room. The court found that the program constituted beyond all question a utilisation of the tax supported public school system to aid religious groups to spread their faith.

Just four years later, in 1952, in Zorach v. Clauson the court held a similar program valid when the only difference was that the religious instruction was conducted off the school property. Of course there are a number of cases related to books and other educational material and resources. Plenty of cases have dealt with establishment clause challenges to the participation of church schools in state funded education programs. The first case was the Board of Education v. Allen, in which a New York statute required local school boards to loan textbooks to students and not to public schools.

It is important that these cases be read into the record so that we can understand that interpretations have been made and can understand where this proposal might lead us at the end of the day. The court affirmed the Everson pupil benefit theory-that is, of course, the general welfare and secular legislative purpose-stating that the purpose of the legislation was to expand educational opportunity by making textbooks available free of charge. Once the states tried to expand this assistance to non-public schools beyond textbooks, however, the court consistently held statutes to infringe the First Amendment. Once they have gone past the point of providing free textbooks they have infringed the First Amendment.

A leading case was Lemon v Kurtzman in 1971 in which a Pennsylvania statute authorised a school to purchase secular educational services from non-public schools. In effect, this was a system of state subsidy whereby the state was to reimburse the schools for teachers' salaries, textbooks and instructional material. The court, in adopting a three point establishment clause test, found the statute invalid. The court held that the arrangements involved excessive entanglement between secular and sectarian activities and authorities.

The three point test since adopted by the court for establishment clause challenges is as follows: the secular legislative purposes of the policy; the policy's purpose and primary effect must neither advance nor inhibit religion; and the policy must not result in an excessive entanglement with religion. Two years later the court held that a New York program providing for non-public school aid through maintenance and repair grants, tuition reimbursement and tax credits, and a Pennsylvania statute also authorising tuition reimbursements, infringed the First Amendment. In the former case the court held that, notwithstanding the high social importance of the state's purposes, it may not justify an eroding of the limitations of the establishment clause now firmly implanted.

A further two years later, Pennsylvania again tried to provide aid additional to textbook loans in the form of a variety of auxiliary services that included counselling, testing, psychological services, speech and hearing therapy, and remedial services for the educationally disadvantaged. In that case, again, only the textbooks survived. In 1983 the court approved a Minnesota tax deduction program for tuition, textbooks and transportation costs as the measure made the relief available to parents of pupils attending both public and non-public schools. This was notwithstanding that the actual effect of the legislation was to benefit the children of non-public schools as the parents of public school children did not normally incur expenses covered by the deductions.

We come to the bottom line of what I see, other than the overturning of the Defence of Government Schools case, as the very real, practical and tangible effects of this legislation. We turn to prayer and religious instruction. There have been a whole range of American cases. Cases have been dealt with on two basic topics: prayer and bible reading at the opening of the school day, and released time programs for religious instruction. The latter has been dealt with earlier in relation to the McCollum and Zorach cases, where it was held that no religious instruction could be given where state aid was provided.

The issue of opening prayers was first before the Supreme Court in Engel v. Vitale in 1962. The question was whether a state composed prayer to be used on a purely voluntary basis in New York schools was constitutionally valid. The court declared that it infringed the establishment clause, although the judges stressed that it was not a prayer but an officially prescribed prayer that was being condemned.

—We are one step ahead of the Minister. Despite this rider and the court's decision, just one year later in the dual cases of the School District of Abington Township v. Schempp, and Murray v. Curlett, the court held that public school opening exercises using the Lord's Prayer and Bible reading violated the establishment clause. I know that that would not offend Senator Bolkus. I know that he would not find that insulting. I know that he would not be terribly upset if his kids could not say their prayers in the morning. He would not find that offensive. But many Christian people in this community believe that that is their right. Adopting the test of purpose and primary effect, the court said that, if either was the advancement or inhibition of religion, the enactment exceeded the legislative power. It made that judgment on the advancement of religion, simply because these kids were saying prayers in the morning at the beginning of the school day.

One other matter of concern in this area is the Reagan Administration's efforts in 1984 to move a constitutional amendment to allow individual or group prayers in schools. That was defeated on 20 March 1984. In June 1984, however, the Senate attached an equal access condition to an education appropriations measure which guarantees any student group wishing to discuss religious issues the use of school facilities on the same basis as any other student group-for example, for political discussions. However, that collapsed. That proposal was not successful as a step to restoring organised prayer in schools as a result of the decision in Bender v. Williamsport School District, which was on appeal. The court in that case held that, based on the three point establishment clause test enunciated in the Lemon v. Kurtzman case, the primary effect of allowing a non-denominational student initiated prayer club to meet during school appointed activity hours would be to endorse and encourage religion. It was in contravention of the establishment clause which in those circumstances prevailed over the student's right to free speech.

This decision was consistent with a decision in Wallace v. Jaffree in 1985, in which Alabama's silent prayer law was found to have an intent to put voluntary prayer back into public schools in direct conflict with the Lemon three point test. It is very interesting. They were banned from private silent meditation in school. One interesting matter decided by the Supreme Court was the 1980 Kentucky case of Stone v. Graham in which the Court refused to allow public classrooms to put up copies of the Ten Commandments on the walls. It was held that the purpose was the advancement of religion. The students in that case overcame that problem by wearing the Ten Commandments on their T-shirts.

The United States Supreme Court's interpretation of the free exercise guarantee has also led to some rather arbitrary and inconsistent decisions. The Court has looked to a test whereby laws would infringe the free exercise clause unless there was a compelling interest which the state may lawfully protect. In the 1961 Sunday closing law cases, Braunfeld v. Brown and Gallagher v. Crown Kosher Supermarket, for example, the Court rejected the claim of a number of Jewish businessmen that the law compelling them to close on Sundays disadvantaged them when they were also closed on Saturday to observe the Sabbath. The Court held:

If the State regulates conduct by enacting a general law within its power, the purpose and effect of which is to advance the State's secular goals, the statute is valid despite its indirect burden on religious observance unless the State may accomplish its purpose by means which do not impose such a burden . . .

That argument has already been put this evening by Senator Tate. Of course, this decision was later reversed. However, Justice Brennan on that occasion dissented. He then went on to enunciate the compelling state interest test, stating that regulations infringing on the free exercise clause could be constitutionally sustained only to prevent `grave and immediate danger to interests that the State may lawfully protect'. This test was adopted in the 1963 case of Sherbert v. Verner in which the court held that the South Carolina Unemployment Compensation Commission had acted unconstitutionally in holding that a Seventh Day Adventist was ineligible for benefits because of her unwillingness to work on Saturdays.

The broad thrust of Senator Bishop's argument is that amending section 116 of the Constitution will make the case law that has developed on the existing words no longer applicable in the same way to the new words. No-one has denied that. In fact, the admission in this committee stage of the debate is that this is a grave matter and that it undermines the established understanding in Australia of what section 116 means. In addition to this grave uncertainty, I raise another broad argument that relates to religious freedom being a hostage to the High Court. The clear, express intent of the proposed amendment to section 116 is to extend its effect to the States and the Territories and to Executive and administrative decisions. Therefore, any defect that flows from the extent to which religious freedom, in the words in section 116, is a hostage to the High Court, is compounded by the extension. This is the main burden of my contention. This is all the more reinforced by the way in which there has been no assurance given in response to this assessment that Senator Harradine, Senator Bishop, Senator Crichton-Browne, some other senators and I, have put.

I object to extending the terms of section 116 to the States and to Executive action, especially because the jeopardy that exists already with regard to section 116 will be so extended to the States and to Executive action. That is why we go on to instance areas of our particular concern, such as the freedom to have prayers in government schools or the very substantial matter that we so strongly support of the ability of governments to give direct financial assistance to religious schools.

I note that section 116, both in its present wording and in the proposed amended wording, includes such words as `religion', `establish', `free', `exercise', `impose' and `observance'. Those six words are just some that are crucial to the meaning of the section. What we are in effect doing by extending the application of this section is extending the application of whatever meaning is put on these words by the High Court. To the extent that the High Court is to determine a practical definition of `religion', we are placing our concerns about religious freedom in the hands of the High Court's definition. Depending upon how the word `establish' is interpreted, as against `prohibit', we are placing a power in the High Court to make decisions that affect the exercising of religious freedom in Australia.

I believe it is much safer for the States to have their freedoms guaranteed by supreme courts-indeed, by the body of existing statutory powers in the parliaments of the States-and, of course, by the accrued common law. Nobody has put forth the view that there is any jeopardy to religious freedom based upon the actions of the supreme courts in the States or based upon the powers of parliaments to enact laws to safeguard and guarantee our freedoms appropriately. The Bill before the chamber brings in an entirely new factor overriding the guarantors of our religious freedom-that is, the supreme courts, the State parliaments and the common law. It brings into effect a constitutional provision which-and I think I have made this point carefully-is a hostage to the High Court. The High Court is not an elected body, and the Ministers participating in this debate have clearly admitted that no absolute guarantee can be given as to what the High Court would decide in the future and that it is not inconceivable that the minority judgment of Mr Justice Murphy in the notorious Defence of Government Schools case might become a majority or unanimous decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —What were they?

—What were they? Mason and Brennan thought that for legal purposes there were two criteria to religion. The first was a belief in the supernatural being, thing or principle; and the second was the acceptance of canons of conduct in order to give effect to that belief, although canons which offended against the ordinary law were not covered by the protection or immunity given to religion. On the other hand, Wilson and Deane considered that religion was more flexible. Their criteria included as an absolute, firstly, a belief in the supernatural; secondly, ideas relating to a man's nature and place in the universe and his relations to things supernatural; thirdly, the ideas are accepted by adherents so as to encourage observance of a code of conduct in practices having supernatural significance; fourthly, these adherents constitute an identifiable group; and fifthly, these adherents see this conduct and practice as constituting a religion.

SPEECH.PARA: With that dichotomy in the High Court in determining the definition of religion, we find there is an ever growing number of exotic faiths, or what we might call unconventional or non-mainstream religions. The difficulty is that some of those religions are excessive in their conduct. Under the proposal provided in the Bill, the Commonwealth and the States shall not prohibit the free exercise of any religion. However, because of the poor definition of that provision, the States may find themselves considerably retarded and restricted. They will have no real capacity to put in place legislation to manage the conduct of some of the more exotic religions.

It is different from most other forms of activity. In this country and around the world we have a great store of knowledge about aviation that has been bought at a very high price. To use that knowledge requires a certain attitude of mind. I do not think we have it from the present Minister for Transport and Communications and we certainly do not have it from this Government. The administration of aviation in Australia in the past was very good-as good as in any other country in the world-but from the time of Donald Anderson onwards there has been a decline, and there has been quite a marked decline in the past few years. It went back to the Department of Aviation under Fraser. In this Government it has been both the Department of Transport and the Department of Transport and Communications. Of the very good people who formed the Department of Civil Aviation a number are still there, but their morale has been destroyed by the lack of leadership from this Government, the changing title of the Department, and the lack of direction as to where it is going.

I do not wish to take up too much time tonight, but there are three critical points I want to talk on very briefly. The first is the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC); the second is the lack of airways facilities, particularly the lack of radar facilities; and the third is the noise at Brisbane Airport. The Federal Airports Corporation, which was set up by this Government, is an undisguised failure. It enjoys the total opposition of the aviation industry. In its short history-it has been in existence only since 1 January this year-it has had a very complex life. The Government tried to get out of the costs of running the airways systems of Australia by setting up the FAC to look after the airports and the Civil Aviation Authority to look after the airways side of it. It created a board which put at least $1m onto the cost of administration of the airfields in this country. It paid the board members a salary, gave them perks and conditions. A number of the people on the board know nothing at all about the aviation industry.

The Government told the Federal Airports Corporation that it was not going to fund it. It said, `You will apply the user pays doctrine and recover your costs from the aviation industry'. It was quite negligent of the fact that the aviation industry in Australia has a very small base. When we come to paying for services, this Government is very keen on the user pays doctrine. I have no objection to paying for services that are delivered, but when we talk about the user pays doctrine, somebody has to get back to a few basic principles. With this Government it means we often pay twice, three times or four times. Everyone pays personal income tax. Many people pay company tax through companies with which they are associated. We all pay excise duties, sales taxes and Customs duties. The reason we pay those to a central government in the form of taxation is to provide essential services. If the Government is going to say to the aviation industry that it has a user pays doctrine and that it pays directly for the airports and so on that it uses, the Government has an obligation to free those people from a proportion of their personal income tax, from their sales tax, from their excise duty and all the rest of it.

The other fault with the user pays doctrine is that it is used as an excuse for booking up very high expenses without asking the customer whether he wants them. As I had to say to the commercial manager of the Federal Airports Commission last week, he cannot go into Myers and book up several thousand dollars worth of goods to my account without my consent, yet that is precisely what he is doing in the management of the airfields around the place. If the Government believes in a user pays concept, then instead of setting up a Federal Airports Corporation to spend money on my behalf and on behalf of other Australians, it has to set up individual boards of management for the 17 airports controlled by the Federal Airports Commission. The majority of the members of those boards of management should be elected by the users of the airfield and the users should elect the chairman of the board. In other words, if there is going to be a user pays doctrine, the people who are going to be billed have to say what the expenditure will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 December 1987 (Hansard, page 2748), Senator Sanders asked Senator Walsh a question without notice concerning proposed logging near Clumner Bluff. The following is the answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Primary Industries and Energy received advice from the Tasmanian Forestry Commission (TASFC), in accordance with the provisions of the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), of proposed logging operations in a coupe know as `Clumner' within State Forest which is adjacent to the Walls of Jerusalem National Park. The coupe straddles the boundary of the Central Plateau National Estate place, but the area is not pristine as logging has previously been undertaken in surrounding coupes in 1979/80 and 1985.

The TASFC provided the Department of Primary Industries and Energy with advice on protection of National Estate (NE) values and the views of the Australian Heritage Commission were also sought. The Australian Heritage Commission subsequently advised the Department that Clumner was subject to consideration as a possible World Heritage `qualifying area' by the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests Commission of Inquiry and that, in the Commission's view, logging should not be undertaken until the Inquiry has reported its findings.

After careful consideration of all the relevant factors, the Government decided, on balance, not to defer the proposed logging. It was conscious of the fact that logging had taken place in the area previously on a satisfactory basis, that measures would be taken to protect the environmental values of the site and that there were no readily accessible alternatives in the region to the particular site involved, which necessitates use of specialised cable logging equipment.

The company involved in exporting pulpwood from the area was notified on 18 January 1988 by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that the requirements of the consultative process under the MOU had been fulfilled and I understand that operations commenced shortly thereafter. The contractor involved in the cable logging operations has sought compensation from the Commonwealth, claiming re-imbursement of costs incurred as a consequence of the Commonwealth's delayed authorisation of operations in the Clumner coupe.
